rec00ENJ5fRPYUpJM.Name: Food 1.6
rec00ENJ5fRPYUpJM.Bottom Body:
**How to avoid snack-related sleep disruptions**

Snacking wisely can help you manage your sweet (or salty) tooth without disrupting your sleep. Here are your guidelines:

1. **Choose wisely**: When youre getting close to bedtime, select snacks that are whole foods. Make sure to include some protein because lack of protein can also impair sleep. Try your best to cut sugar during the day, or at a minimum, time it earlier in the day.
2. **No snacks before bed**: Try your best to stop eating about 3 hours before you go to bed. At a minimum, make sure you only eat light snacks during that period. This will give your digestive system time to break down those good eats before you hit the hay.

rec0Ac8cxGbMH6GqT.Name: Quickwin 1.1
rec0Ac8cxGbMH6GqT.Bottom Body:

rec0RP9jAhpFUz5ZM.Name: relearn 1.5
rec0RP9jAhpFUz5ZM.Bottom Body:
**Knowledge is power**
These two action plans will help build the foundation of your mastery over your sleep. You won't conquer them overnight, and that's ok! 

Like we said, unlearning and relearning takes some time. In the words of Neuropsychologist Donald Hebb:

**"Neurons that fire together wire together"**

**What does that mean? **Simply put, it means that when we do two things at the same time, our brains connect the activities. When we don't do those things together, the strength of that connection weakens over time. 

The stronger a connection grows, the more automatic that behavior becomes! It just takes some repetition.

rec0ULAGdv7G1sYaA.Name: Quickwins 9.5
rec0ULAGdv7G1sYaA.Bottom Body:
Heck yeah, they work!

Your brain loves repetition. Just like how negative thought loops lead to more negative thinking. Positive affirmations lead to more positive thinking.

They can help you feel unstuck and push you out of a rut. Even if it feels like youre just saying words, over time youll begin to feel their impact on your well-being.

Regular repetition of positive and affirming statements encourages your brain to take these positive affirmations as fact! Its a fun brain hack.

Learning to use your brains wiring to your advantage is a great way to crush your goals.

Ok, lets get back to journeys!

rec0hpXspzsoVE9jE.Name: Circadian 1.2
rec0hpXspzsoVE9jE.Bottom Body:
**How does my circadian rhythm work?**
Your circadian rhythm is controlled by a group of cells in your brain that sit right behind your eyes. Its called the suprachiasmatic nucleus (say it with me, _soo-pruh-kee-uhz-ma-tuhk noo-klee-uhs_).

Now repeat it 10 times fast! Just kidding.

Your suprachiasmatic nucleus has a nickname the SCN. Well just call it that. Your SCN takes cues from your environment to regulate your sleep-wake cycle. Why? So your body can adapt when there are changes.

**What sort of cues are important to your circadian rhythm?**

rec0ubK5GoNcsoE1N.Name: Goals 1.3
rec0ubK5GoNcsoE1N.Bottom Body:
**SMART GOALS**
**S**pecific- Don't be vague
**M**easurable- How do you measure success?
**A**ttainable- Small and achievable
**R**elevant- Brings you closer to your big goals
**T**imely- Set time limits 

**An example, please!**
An example of a SMART goal is: dont hit snooze once this week. This goal is SMART because it's very specific, definitely attainable, relevant to the overall goal to sleep better, and is timely (one week time frame). 

Let's try it out...

rec11THIBuwlFzWg0.Name: sleep stability 1.3
rec11THIBuwlFzWg0.Bottom Body:
**2. Stimulus Control**

Good stimulus control means you only use your bed for sleep and sex. This improves sleep stability because it lowers any triggers for wakefulness, reduces stressing and activation in bed, and helps your brain to clarify your bed as a place for sleep. 

Less stress and clear cues make for higher quality sleep!

rec121HKqaj3wsjEB.Name: sleep stability 1.5
rec121HKqaj3wsjEB.Bottom Body:
**4. Add noise**
Adding noise to your sleep may sound a little counterintuitive, right? Let's explore:

Environmental noise during the night is disruptive to sleep. Even if you aren't waking up, research has shown that it can still disrupt the quality of sleep you get. 

One of the best ways to combat environmental noise while improving your sleep stability is a noise machine! Pink noise (such as rain falling and waves rolling in) has been shown to increase sleep stability. 

Many people also find that soothing white noise and nature sounds help them fall asleep faster and maintain a higher quality of sleep. 

So, if you're looking to boost sleep quality  try a noise machine!

rec18QmMTmter16nN.Name: levelup 4.2
rec18QmMTmter16nN.Bottom Body:
**Get 10-20 minutes of morning sunshine**

For at least three mornings this week, we'd like you to aim to get 10-20 minutes of sunshine exposure between 8am to noon. You can combine it with a morning walk, or simply sit out in the sun doing something relaxing. 

You can also use the stay-at-home option of using a light therapy lamp! Use it for around 20 minutes within 24 inches of your face. Make sure the light you use delivers 10,000 lux of full-spectrum light! You can use it while at your computer, television, or while engaging in a light activity. 

**Why?** Light exposure is one of the most important uses for optimizing your circadian rhythm. Light helps to regulate melatonin and serotonin  both very important for sleep and mood.

rec1RcxG19KelPAEn.Name: quickwinFA 5.3
rec1RcxG19KelPAEn.Bottom Body:
Ideally, set aside 10 to 20 minutes during your nightly bedtime routine to journal. 

The purpose of journaling will be to quiet your mind, vent your thoughts, and give your brain closure on the day. 

How? There are many ways, choose what works for you. 

**You can try:**

- Writing a general "dear diary" style log about your day
- Making notes of any positive experiences you had that day
- Free association- this means setting a timer and writing absolutely anything that comes to your mind (this one can get fun)
- Creating a to-do list for tomorrow with actions(this one works really well for sleep)
- Listing all the reasons that Rested Health is your number one favorite app

**TIP:** If you cant solve a problem, simply write will revisit tomorrow this will allow your brain to close the curtain on the item for the night.

rec1nmct4y8ZKpIin.Name: worry 1.3
rec1nmct4y8ZKpIin.Bottom Body:
**How does it impact sleep?**
When the subconscious mind has anxiety, it can negatively impact your programming for sleep. That anxiety ripple can even follow you into slumber, disturbing your sleep and even impacting your dreams.

It's why some people anticipate sleep problems before even getting in bed. 

It's why sometimes your head hits the pillow and you suddenly feel awake. 

It's why sometimes you wake up in the middle of the night alert and filled with thoughts and worries. 

But, we have some great news for you...

**Your mind can be reprogrammed for better sleep!**

rec26qjwj74UvX87H.Name: Oriented 1.2
rec26qjwj74UvX87H.Bottom Body:
## 1. Journey cards
Journey cards are where you'll:
- Access your personalized sleep program
- Learn the core skills you need to improve your relationship with sleep
- Tell us more about your sleep problems and goals so that we can offer you solutions!


**WEEK 1**
In the first week you'll learn about some common dysfunctional beliefs about sleep (a.k.a. sleep myths), the basics of your sleep system, and you'll get an introduction to popular techniques for reducing anxiety! You'll also officially begin your action plan to reboot your sleep. 

**WEEK 2**
Week 2 is all about the basics of rebuilding your relationship with sleep, unlearning bad habits, relearning good habits, tracking your progress, and how certain substances can sneak in and mess up your sleep. You'll also continue building on your action plan and working on awesome techniques for reducing stress. 

**WEEK 3**
In week 3 we'll learn about the stages of sleep and how to optimize your slumber, what makes a good sleep sanctuary, and problem-solving for restless nights! You'll also continue building on your action plan.  

**WEEK 4**
In week 4 we take a look at daytime activities that impact sleep, how to eat your way to better slumber, supplements for sleep, natural ways to boost melatonin, and how meditation can change the way you sleep!

**TIP:** We suggest you complete journey topics at least three times a week for the best results.

rec29oa4E8wlgdBwo.Name: Architecture 1.1
rec29oa4E8wlgdBwo.Bottom Body:
Sleep architecture is one of the key measurements used to gauge how well you sleep. It refers to the quality of your sleep and how much time you spend in each sleep stage!

Understanding how it works can also help you understand why your sleep sometimes _feels_ better than other times.

By learning how to optimize your sleep, you can improve your sleep architecture and gain incredible sleep benefits.

**But, like, what is sleep architecture?**

rec2EPtDEJdTpuniN.Name: restructure 2.1
rec2EPtDEJdTpuniN.Bottom Body:
**It's time to practice some more cognitive restructuring**! 

As a reminder, cognitive restructuring is when you play rational scientists to your dramatic/exaggerated/doom-filled thoughts 

Here are some examples of the types of thoughts that could use some restructuring: 

For instance, if you find yourself forecasting the future with a thought like:  "I just know I'm not going to be able to sleep tonight"

You can try rephrasing it in a way that's less stressful and more based on logic, like: "I have had trouble sleeping in the past, it may or may not be a reality for me tonight"

rec2EthYAXMrfQKI7.Name: restructure 2.2
rec2EthYAXMrfQKI7.Bottom Body:
As a reminder, here are the steps:

**Step 1**: Identify the thought- e.g. "I'm going to get sick and die if I don't fall asleep"

**Step 2**: List evidence for or against it-
**Evidence for**: Losing sleep can weaken your immune system and sometimes makes you feel off.
**Evidence against**: Nobody has ever died from lack of sleep. I've missed sleep before and it didn't kill me.

**Step 3**: Reframing the thought- "If I don't sleep well I may not feel my best tomorrow"

Let's try one...

rec2S5DumUbJzgfv8.Name: Wokeuptired 1.2
rec2S5DumUbJzgfv8.Bottom Body:
**1. You didnt get enough quality sleep**

One of the more obvious reasons for not feeling Rested is because the sleep you got was lower quality. It may have felt like you slept all night, but its possible you spent more time in light sleep than in the more restorative deep sleep stages.

This could be caused by problems with your sleep environment like noise, consuming alcohol or caffeine too close to bed, snoring or sleep apnea, stress, or many other reasons.

**Fix it**
If it happens every now and then, its likely not a big deal and improving your sleep habits will help boost your slumber. Focus on your action plan and getting some early morning sunshine to help! 

If this happens most nights, you may want to talk to your doctor to see if there are any underlying health concerns.

**Lets look at other reasons you may be tired in the morning...**

rec2a5m6UYEz2GdYP.Name: Sleep Basics 101 Overview 1.4
rec2a5m6UYEz2GdYP.Bottom Body:
Your circadian rhythm uses its **circadian alerting system** to send you WAKE UP alerts throughout the day so you dont feel sleepy too early in the day.

For every hour that you are awake, your circadian alerting system increases so you wont fall asleep prematurely.

By the end of the day, your circadian rhythm turns off this alerting system so that your body can receive the signals from your sleep drive that its _finallyyyyy_ time to sleep.

**Exercise loves sleep and sleep loves exercise**

Were sure youve heard before that exercise is good for you. But do you know that exercise can have an incredible effect on your sleep? Exercise is soooooo good for sleep that its sometimes prescribed as an alternative treatment for sleep problems.

Even though exercise is so good for sleep, its sometimes hard to find accurate information about how to do it, when to do it, and how it actually helps sleep. Luckily, were here to help sort that out!

rec3gvAfPczbr8zyL.Name: racingmind 1.2
rec3gvAfPczbr8zyL.Bottom Body:
Here's the scene: You're laying in bed. Your mind is racing. You just want some peace.

**Here's what you can do:**

**Step 1:** Place a hand onyourheart and feel its rhythm. Thump. Thump. Thump. 

Now, breathe in deeply through your nose for 4 seconds, then take a long, slow breath out through your mouth. 

Repeat this pattern until you can feelyourheartbeat slow down.Your thoughtsshould soon ease up as well.

rec3rHy7qCsBZpAeb.Name: Sneaky 1.1
rec3rHy7qCsBZpAeb.Bottom Body:
We want to empower you to make great choices that give you the best sleep.

That's why it's important to make you aware of the sneaky sleep disruptors that commonly cause issues for people.

Let's take a look at some pesky little sleep disturbers and tips on how to avoid them...

rec3wy44WKNmwYIam.Name: Food 1.2
rec3wy44WKNmwYIam.Bottom Body:
**Timing your food**

Your metabolism shifts throughout the day and most people benefit by eating larger meals earlier in the day. Research has shown that meals eaten later in the day can lead to poorer sleep quality in many people. 

Part of the reason is that your body is working hard to digest food. If you use a wearable you'll notice that later meals are associated with a higher heart rate during sleep. This is because your body is working hard when you eat late!

**How to eat on time**
Skipping breakfast, eating large meals late at night, and fasting can all be disruptive to your circadian rhythm. However, everyone is unique. As always, you should do what works best for you. 

However, if you are experiencing circadian rhythm disruption, eating breakfast at the same time every morning can help to optimize your circadian rhythm. 

**Stay regular**
The most important factor with diet and sleep is to remain fairly consistent in your meal times so that your natural rhythms arent disrupted. Your body loves to be able to predict your schedule and functions best when things are consistent.

rec46ZSKTZ8JZDzbE.Name: fa 1.1
rec46ZSKTZ8JZDzbE.Bottom Body:
Having difficulties falling asleep can be incredibly frustrating. There are several reasons that this problem can occur. One of the biggest reasons is stress.

Learning how to better handle stress during the day will help reduce the impact at night. However, on those nights where you find yourself feeling wide-awake and begging for sleep, it's great to have some tools in your back pocket. 

Fall asleep quicker in 5,4,3,2...

rec495F2UJ0EMKU5J.Name: caffeineSleep 1.3
rec495F2UJ0EMKU5J.Bottom Body:
**Rule # 1**
**Don't consume caffeine within the first 90 minutes of waking up.** 

**Why?** When you first wake up, your body boosts you with wakefulness-promoting chemicals. This natural process ends around 90 minutes after you've woken up. 

Drinking coffee during this window blunts the impact of caffeine. meaning you need more to get the same effect. 

**The fix?** get your caffeine hit after 90 minutes or after lunch. Both of these times are when your body will use it best!

rec4BHnDnugqfBqQA.Name: Noise 1.2
rec4BHnDnugqfBqQA.Bottom Body:
My brain can still process environmental noise when Im asleep?

Yep. You read that right.

Not only can your brain process noise when youre sleeping, but it leads to **less quality deep sleep**. Not good. Not good at all.

Studies have found that noise pollution during sleep causes disturbances that lead to subjective distress. Were talking  daytime sleepiness, decreased well-being, lower cognitive performance, mood changes, and it can even exacerbate or contribute to mental illness!

You still hear and process sounds while you sleep, even if you dont recall being disturbed.

So, lets talk about how to eliminate environmental noise so it doesnt interrupt your slumber...

rec4UgHE7KsND1QQo.Name: Sleep Basics 101 Overview 1.2
rec4UgHE7KsND1QQo.Bottom Body:
Your circadian rhythm controls your sleep-wake cycle.

Your SCN takes cues from your environment and sends the info to your circadian rhythm.

Environmental cues that affect your sleep include light, temperature, eating, and activity!

rec4hZ4FX1aDYzdxr.Name: pickingbedtime 1.3
rec4hZ4FX1aDYzdxr.Bottom Body:
**When to go to bed**

While it's good to have an idea of your ideal bedtime, it's not worth stressing over if you aren't sleepy at your bedtime. 

In fact, we recommend only going to bed when sleepy!

**Sleepy vs tired**

Learning to differentiate when you are sleepy vs when you are tired is important. Why? Because if it's just fatigue, you can find yourself tossing and turning in bed "trying" to fall asleep. 

Trying to sleep is generally only going to cause more sleep issues. In fact, you should always leave your bed after 20 minutes if you can't fall asleep. Go do something relaxing and come back to try again.

rec5TNfBiov5plhxV.Name: CR 1.1
rec5TNfBiov5plhxV.Bottom Body:
**Cognitive restructuring**

Cognitive restructuring is a popular technique used by psychologists to help people think differently about events. 

Our brains constantly use thoughts to evaluate situations and make appraisals about the world around us. Although this is generally helpful, sometimes our initial thoughts and reactions can actually cause us a great deal of struggle. 

**How it works**
In every situation you experience a thought  emotion  then a Behavior. 

**Thoughts** are influenced by core beliefs about the world (i.e. right vs wrong)

**Emotions** are your feelings based on your thoughts (they are not always logical)

**Behavior** is your reaction to the thoughts and feelings

Cognitive restructuring is an exercise where you pause to challenge your initial thought and reframe it in a way that is more rational, less emotional, and leads to healthier reactions!

**Why you need it**
Every single human being knows what it's like to experience thoughts that lead to pain and unhelpful reactions. Gaining the skills to stop and evaluate the situations in a logical way will significantly improve your interactions with your world and your reactions to uncomfortable situations. 

The more you practice  the easier it gets!

rec5ggZgk96IXzlhr.Name: habittips 1.4
rec5ggZgk96IXzlhr.Bottom Body:
**4. TALK TO YOURSELF**

Nobody knows you better than yourself. If you're having trouble implementing changes or find that you're feeling stuck  explore why! 

Ask yourself  **"what is holding me back?"** 

Sometimes you may need to remove hurdles or break your goals into even smaller tasks that help you get unstuck. 

Whatever the case, having honest discussions with yourself will help you continue to grow and help you overcome obstacles. 

**We got you**
You can also talk to your sleep coach who can help give insight into some issues you might be facing. Life happens, we are here to make sure that no matter what some your way  it doesn't derail you.

rec5tQGd8Vp5bk1ML.Name: Overview 2.5
rec5tQGd8Vp5bk1ML.Bottom Body:
**How to track your sleep**

**Wearables** have cool features that give you interesting information about your sleep. The data from your tracker get analyzed and put into graphs that help you get an idea of your sleep.

There are a bunch of fun options: wrist wearables, finger wearables, and head wearables, and even some that you dont wear at all.

Or, another alternative is to keep a **sleep diary.**

A sleep diary is helpful because it captures things that a wearable cant, such as your emotions or what you ate.

You can download a sleep diary app, download a template online, or simply make notes in a journal. Include any and all sleep-related info and try to use it for at least 2 weeks.

Use whatever option you enjoy the most to track your sleep progress!

So, keeping your changes small, your goals SMART, and your self-talk positive will keep you on the path toward better sleep.

rec61LQUVAECAnUPm.Name: Food 1.8
rec61LQUVAECAnUPm.Bottom Body:
So the takeaway for todays Reboot Camp is:

1. Certain foods can disrupt your sleep
2. Avoid snacking 3 hours before bed if you can. If you absolutely must eat, pick something light and balanced (a little protein, carbohydrates, and fat).

**Sleep inducing snacks**
Certain foods have been found to help you sleep due to naturally occurring compounds. In fact, some snacks can even boost your melatonin levels! Check out the next quick win for some delicious and nutritious melatonin-boosting snacks!

rec61ovcdKyGuTCWY.Name: Circadian 1.7
rec61ovcdKyGuTCWY.Bottom Body:
**Activity**
Physical activity is a strong cue for your circadian rhythm. The time of day you exercise can have a direct impact on your sleep-wake cycle. Exercise can even be used to adjust your circadian rhythm forwards or backward.

For instance, people who fall asleep too early can use evening physical activity to push their circadian rhythm later! Cool, right?

rec63XXhO8cs9IFI3.Name: Quickwin 12.2
rec63XXhO8cs9IFI3.Bottom Body:
**Tryptophan**
Your body uses this amino acid to make serotonin and melatonin. Both chemicals are important to sleep.

Have you heard of turkey comas? That sleep thanksgiving snoozy feeling is due to the high amounts of tryptophan in turkey! (ok it might also be related to the 12 lbs of mashed potatoes and 3 slices of pie you ate)

**Sleep-inducing snacks and the amount of tryptophan per serving:**

- Whole Milk (211mg)
- Turkey (687 mg)
- Salmon (203 mg)
- Soy beans (a.k.a. edamame) (416 mg)
- Pumpkin seeds (164 mg)
- Oatmeal (94 mg)

rec6Nk2qukoJEOBMu.Name: alcoholSleep 1.5
rec6Nk2qukoJEOBMu.Bottom Body:
**3. Melatonin Reduction**

Studies have shown that drinking reduces melatonin by around 20% around 3 hours after you drink it. Disruptions to melatonin negatively impact your sleep quality and circadian rhythm. 

**4. Sleep Architecture Disruption**

During alcohol metabolism, slow-wave non-REM sleep increases while mentally restorative REM sleep decreases. Therefore, alcohol delays the onset of REM and reduces the total time spent in REM. 

Lack of REM sleep is associated with sleep disorders and can have detrimental effects on concentration, motor skills, and memory.

A study of over 4000 people found that alcohol before bed caused 25-40% less restorative sleep ([link](https://mental.jmir.org/2018/1/e23/)).

rec6QoOSeaAEWAcVu.Name: QuickwinFA2.4
rec6QoOSeaAEWAcVu.Bottom Body:
**Making Lists**
Laying in bed struggling with a busy mind sucks. To use this technique you don't even have to move. 

**To begin:** Lay there with your eyes closed and relax your jaw (you'll be surprised how much tension lives in there).

Next, you'll begin making lists! The first grounding technique for sleep that we want to share with you is listing random objects.

**Listing random objects:**  It's as simple as that. Start naming random things in your head and keep going.

For example: "Potato, car, pen, jeans, notepad, etc."

This technique will pull you out of any unhelpful thought loops and allow your mind to find peace. It's an extremely effective and easy-to-use tool that many people find helpful for falling asleep. 

Try this one out and see how well it works for you!

rec6YDhokC5I2sgzd.Name: week 2.3
rec6YDhokC5I2sgzd.Bottom Body:
**Blue light**

You probably already knew this one was coming! Whether we like it or not, blue light has a huge impact on our circadian rhythms. 

We'll teach you how blue light can be helpful and harmful to your slumber and what you can do about it! 

Don't worry, we're not asking you to throw away your cell phone (we live in here, after all)

rec6gGHZurMaxBdiK.Name: Decompression 1.6
rec6gGHZurMaxBdiK.Bottom Body:
**Sample Routine**

9:30pm  Alarm goes off as a cue that it's time to begin to unwind
9:40pm  Change into PJ's and wash face
9:50pm  Journal for 10 minutes
10:00pm  Do skincare routine, brush teeth, floss, look in the mirror and say "hey, nice work today, I'm proud of you"
10:15  Climb into bed and get cozy under the sheets then cue up a progressive muscle relaxation track
10:30  Zzzzzzzzzzz

**Some tips**
The key to a successful routine is consistency. So, do what works for you. Choose activities you enjoy doing. For instance, have fun with journaling, use your imagination or simply treat it as a log of your daily life.

Its true that new habits can be hard to stick with. The point is always: **progress not perfection**. So, try not to get discouraged if things dont always go as planned. Change takes time.

**Learning new tricks**
It usually takes about four weeks for a new habit to feel automatic, so be patient with yourself. After that point, it takes much less mental energy to engage in your new behaviors.

This is why it's fine (and even encouraged) to take your time and slowly add new things to your bedtime routine. 

**Get started**
Let's get started by adding some evening decompression to your current action plan.

rec6luzW4LAw742pr.Name: cantsleep 1.6
rec6luzW4LAw742pr.Bottom Body:
**WHEN TO GO BACK TO BED**

Wherever you escape to get bored and find some peace it's important that you try not to fall asleep in that location. The purpose of your escape is to strengthen your relationship with bed + sleep, not couch + sleep. 

So, once you feel yourself getting sleepy or starting to dose off, relocate back to your bed. 

**Tips for entering Snoozeville**
When relocating back to your bed, you may initially find it hard to sleep again. Try these tips to help your body ease into sleep:
- **Eye mask: **Youll be shocked to find what a difference an eye mask can make for falling back to sleep. The complete darkness is a signal to your brain for melatonin. Melatonin helps us sleep. Choose one thats comfortable, silk is always a nice choice.
- **Earplugs:** Noise in your environment always seems amplified in the wee hours of the morning. Keep emergency earplugs in your nightstand for these moments. It will help you find your peace.
- **Soothing sounds:** You can also try soothing nature sounds, white noise, or a guided meditation to help lull you back to sleep. Even just laying and imagining yourself in the most peaceful of surroundings is sometimes enough.

Try to imagine yourself relaxing on a warm sunny beach with the waves gently ebbing and flowing. 

You can also pick your most relaxing and happiest moment and imagine yourself there. Maybe it's watching a sunset on a hike or the wind in your face during a beautiful boat ride. 

Find your relaxing space and rest there.

rec6qaQIC0g0RJ05Y.Name: Architecture 1.3
rec6qaQIC0g0RJ05Y.Bottom Body:
**Good Sleep Architecture**

Your sleep architecture will differ every night. Why? Because no two days are exactly alike!

Your sleep architecture can change due to your activity levels, stress, food consumed, sunlight exposure, or even the sounds occurring in your environment as you sleep! 

Your sleep architecture will also change as you age. As you get older, you tend to spend less time in deep sleep stages. 

What does this mean? Just like everything else with sleep, you'll never reach perfection with your sleep architecture. However, there is plenty you can do to improve it!

rec6rkao4Ioemu3c3.Name: BasicsQ 1.9
rec6rkao4Ioemu3c3.Bottom Body:
Ok, wow, we only have 3 left. Look at you go! Your dedication to completing these quizzes is awesome.

You remember this one, right? Let's go get'em...

rec6wA5Rz9PiFA8kr.Name: Science 1.3
rec6wA5Rz9PiFA8kr.Bottom Body:
During the night you move through several stages of sleep. These stages each have specific benefits and unique qualities. Your sleep architecture is your pattern of sleep stages across the night (it looks like a city skyline).

There are two types of sleep: 
1. **Rapid-eye-movement sleep (REM)**
2. **Non-rapid-eye-movement sleep (NREM)**: which includes stages N1, N2, and N3. 

REM sleep is primarily when you dream, you spend more time in REM during the second half of the night.

As for NREM stages, N1 and N2 include lighter sleep while N3 includes deep restorative sleep. 

Each stage is very important and impacts your daily health and functioning in unique ways. 

We'll learn more about sleep stages later. 

Improving your sleep architecture means improving the **quality** of your sleep. Let's look at a quick tip on how to optimize sleep architecture!

rec6wMA7f5LOupyqU.Name: Goals 1.2
rec6wMA7f5LOupyqU.Bottom Body:
Knowing your own goals is important.

Smaller goals are vital because they:
- Increase your chances of success
- Boost morale (i.e. "yay, I achieved a thing!")
- Bring you closer to your big goals!

In order to set you up for success, we want you to make **SMART** goals. 

**Wait, what's a SMART goal?**

rec70N5b8RjPabmDl.Name: mythBuster 1.3

**As a rule, the number of dreams you can recall is _not_ an indication of your sleep quality!!**

When you wake up they are gone with the wind. Out the door. Adios. Byyyyyyeeeeee. 

**That's why dreams are never a good way to rate your quality of sleep!**

Isn't myth busting fun? 

We've gathered a ton of cool sleep facts, research, and little "wow" moments that we'll keep sharing with you. 

You'll become the "sleep person" in your friend group in no time!

rec72EkQ1yEC3BYea.Name: Blue light 1.7

To get started, you can try swapping in bedtime light bulbs (easily found on websites like Amazon) or 40-watt bulbs in any lamps you may use in the 2 hours before bedtime.  Simply turn off overhead lights and set the mood for relaxation!

Bedtime bulbs are often green or red-tinted which means they have no sleep-disrupting properties.

rec7HWwhioQ1eSxlv.Name: QuickwinFA 12.2
rec7HWwhioQ1eSxlv.Bottom Body:
**Melatonin**
Previously it was believed that you could only find melatonin in animalss pineal glands. It is now well known that melatonin also naturally occurs in certain plants, fungi, insects and bacteria (bacteria and insect sandwich, anyone?)

Your body uses melatonin to regulate your circadian rhythm and keep you snoozing at night. Research has shown that eating foods containing melatonin can enhance your bodys natural production.

When it comes to melatonin, you only need a little. Research has shown that taking 0.3 mg is more effective for improving sleep than higher doses. Thats because it better imitates your bodys natural levels.

**Lets look at some melatonin-rich snacks!**

rec7LFi1k5JSHHtNe.Name: habittips 1.3
rec7LFi1k5JSHHtNe.Bottom Body:
**3. PLAN TO FAIL**

Nobody just changes overnight. It takes time, it involves ups and downs, and sometimes you feel like you're going backwards. The important thing is to get back on track.

Acknowledging that change involves failure is vital to success. One great piece of advice is "never miss twice." That is to say, don't skip anything twice in a row. If you missed making your bed once, don't miss it twice. 

Failure is an option! Learn from it and move forward.

rec7LrMeLvdgX1j4S.Name: circrhythm 1.6
rec7LrMeLvdgX1j4S.Bottom Body:
**Finding your rhythm**
Light, temperature, eating, and activity are the key environmental cues that help to regulate your circadian rhythm.

**LIGHT:** One of the most effective ways to help optimize your circadian rhythm is by getting 20 minutes of sunshine each day, ideally, early morning sunshine. We'll cover this topic more in-depth in the next section.

**TEMPERATURE:** Your body temperature fluctuates throughout the day to sync with your sleep-wake cycle. Your body temperature begins dropping toward the night as your body releases melatonin for sleep. Sleeping in a cool room at night can help induce better sleep by increasing melatonin production. 

**EATING**: Eating is an important cue for your circadian rhythm and eating at unusual times can be disruptive. The relationship between the timing of meals and your circadian rhythm is primarily controlled by insulin. This week, we'll show you how to eat to optimize your rhythm in the section on diet and sleep.

**ACTIVITY:** The time of day you exercise and do other activities can have a direct impact on your circadian rhythm. Exercise can even be used to adjust your circadian rhythm forwards or backwards. We'll talk about how you can strategically use physical activity to optimize your rhythm and boost your sleep in the section on exercise and sleep. 

**Change takes time**
Knowing how to identify when your circadian rhythm is healthy and when things have gone askew can help you make healthy decisions to optimize its function. Over the next week, we'll highlight some of the most effective ways to find your rhythm!

rec7OwSM1lnGnypED.Name: Hydration 1.5
rec7OwSM1lnGnypED.Bottom Body:
**Yes! It is possible to hydrate your way to better sleep!**

Here are our basic tips to help:

- **Choose water**: Avoid drinking too much caffeine, alcohol, or sugary beverages as they are known to cause sleep disturbances. Choose clean tap water, filtered water, or one of many delicious sparkling waters on the market.

- **Balance your diet**: Fruits and vegetables have a high moisture content which can increase your water intake. Watermelon, for example, is 92% water. So, eat your fruits and veggies!

- **Monitor your intake**: Try using a large jug or drinking vessel that has markers to let you know how much you've drunk each day. Most experts recommend around 15.5 cups (3.7 liters) of fluids a day for men and 11.5 cups (2.7 liters) of fluids a day for women. 

As always, the amount of water that's right for you will depend on your body composition, needs, and activities each day! Proper hydration can make a huge impact on your quality of life and quality of sleep, so take this as a friendly reminder to drink some water.

Heck, why not start every day with a glass of water! (See, you're already on the right path!)

**Sleep actually improves your ability to handle stress!**

**Sleep:**
- Increases your patience
- Regulates your stress response
- Makes more space for logical thoughts
- Cools your temper and irritability

**Your world on sleep**
Getting adequate sleep boosts happiness and helps us meet the best version of ourselves. It enriches our inner lives and makes the world around us kinder and easier to navigate.

rec7X8z9A435YBsaL.Name: CR 1.3
rec7X8z9A435YBsaL.Bottom Body:
**Exercise in Cognitive Restructuring**

In order to begin using this techniques, it's necessary to be able to identify your thoughts that lead to your emotional reactions. To improve this skill it helps to write down your thoughts and feelings in a situation. 

**For instance, let's look at an example:** 
Situation: I can't fall asleep
Thoughts: "There's something wrong with me"
Emotion: Stressed/worried
Reaction: Gets agitated in bed 

**If we combat the original thought with one that is less inflammatory, the emotion and behavior also changes:**
Situation: I can't fall asleep
Thoughts: "Not being able to sleep is difficult, but it will be ok"
Emotion: Accepting
Reaction: Leaves bed and does relaxing activity until tired

Although the concept seems easy, it's actually pretty difficulty to play "rational scientist" with your own thoughts. The important thing to remember is that you do have control over your thoughts and you can change the way you react to situations. 

Let's practice!

rec8XWEoLOiv24POi.Name: Mornings 1.4
rec8XWEoLOiv24POi.Bottom Body:
**Mornings with Sunshine**

Currently, you have a simple morning routine  get up at the same time every morning and drink a glass of water. 

Let's look at different ways you can boost this routine by adding in some sunshine:

1. **Take a walk**: Grabbing a morning walk in the sunshine is an awesome way to relieve stress, get in your morning sunshine, and boost your activity levels. If you have a pet, they'll also appreciate the bonding time (unless it's a goldfish). 
2. **Sunshine decompression**: Taking 10 to 20 minutes in the morning sunshine to meditate, journal, or set your intentions for the day is another great way to start off your morning and optimize your rhythm.
3. **Fake it:** You may not always have access to sunshine in the morning or you may want a more convenient way to get it! Fortunately, light therapy lamps, or happy lamps, are a great substitute. You can set one up at your work computer, the breakfast table, or in an area where you stretch or do yoga. Anywhere is fine! Aim to use it for 20-30 minutes each morning between 8am to 12pm.

rec8dhgww1WB7MdJA.Name: Wokeuptired 1.3
rec8dhgww1WB7MdJA.Bottom Body:
**2. You woke up on the wrong side of the sleep cycle**

During the night you go through several 90 minute sleep cycles. If your alarm goes off while you are in deep sleep you may experience **sleep inertia**.

Sleep inertia is temporary but can be pretty intense. It makes you feel groggy, disoriented, and stuck between sleep and wakefulness.

Most people feel better within 15-30 minutes but it can take hours to actually feel awake. It can happen when youre abruptly awakened from any stage, but is much worse if awoken from slow wave deep sleep or REM.

**Fix it**
You can solve this issue by getting a smart alarm that wakes your up when your sleep is lighter. You can also calculate your ideal sleep schedule so that you wake up at the end of a sleep cycle

**As a reminder  calculate your ideal sleep time:**
- The average sleep cycle is 90 minutes long and you should get around 4-5 full sleep cycles a night.
- 90 x 5 = 450 minutes, or 7.5 hours
- Starting at your wake time, work back 7.5 hours to find your ideal bedtime!

rec9GttV7sIVVpvuo.Name: QuickWinFA 10.3
rec9GttV7sIVVpvuo.Bottom Body:
There are a couple of ways to try this method, one of the more popular ways is to turn the tables on your inability to sleep!

rec9H1wauLXd7cp6B.Name: Food 1.4
rec9H1wauLXd7cp6B.Bottom Body:
**High-fat food and sleep**

High-fat foods may cause you to have a **fragmented sleep** at night.

Researchers have found that high-fat foods can decrease sensitivity to the brain chemical, orexin, which is helpful in maintaining the bodys sleep and wakefulness.

A high-fat diet may also lead to disruptions of sleep signals by delaying a sleep protein called elF2a.

Overall, research consistently shows that a high-fat diet is associated with shorter sleep times. Its especially worse when its a high fat, low protein, high sugar diet (sorry to come for potato chips and cookies like that).

**Not all fast are equal**
In general, when consuming fats, stick with healthy fats like those found in nuts, avocados and salmon which tend to have more health benefits and less detrimental impact on sleep. Saturated and trans fats generally come with more side effects.

**What about a keto diet?**

Things are a little more complicated with a keto diet. The shift in your energy needs with this diet generally causes changes to your sleep needs. Many people on keto actually find that they need less sleep to function!

If this is a topic youd like to learn more about, reach out to your sleep coach for more info! You can also read more in this [article](https://intercom.help/rested-health/en/articles/5081494-how-to-eat-your-way-to-better-sleep).

We arent done though, theres another type of food that impacts sleep...

rec9UmUZrzRgvi7AZ.Name: relearn 1.6
rec9UmUZrzRgvi7AZ.Bottom Body:
**Reboot and rebuild the smart way**
Many of the habits we have that aren't helpful to sleep also bring us comfort, so getting rid of them can be tricky. Fortunately, you'll learn the most effective tips for change through this app! (So clever of you to join us).

**We got your back**
We'll keep reminding you and continually give you tips for success. For now, just focus on the fact that your bed should be restricted to sleep and sex only and that learning by association is a very real thing.

**Get started**
Keep working on using your bed for just sleep (and sex). We'll continue to give you some more specific action plans as you move through each week.

You don't have to change everything overnight! It's all about progress, not perfection.

rec9WKwIQyqFPblIv.Name: architeture 1.6
rec9WKwIQyqFPblIv.Bottom Body:
Optimizing your sleep really means optimizing your sleep architecture. Although there is still a great deal we don't understand about the mysteries of sleep, we do understand that each stage of sleep has valuable properties and the way it is mapped each night impacts our well-being. 

In week 3 we'll revisit sleep stages and talk more about what happens during each stage! 

**Quick tips on boosting sleep architecture**
- Keep a consistent wake time
- Get 20-30 minutes of sunlight each day
- Exercise for 15-30 minutes each day
- Skip late meals
- Skip alcohol or nicotine before bed
- Avoid caffeine late in the day
- Block noise while you sleep

rec9XPHgOJFuvAzdy.Name: Trackingprogress 1.3
rec9XPHgOJFuvAzdy.Bottom Body:
**Other ways to track**
Sleep diaries aren't the only way to track your sleep. 

There are now many wearable health and fitness trackers that also have sleep tracking built-in!

You can find them for your wrist, finger, head, or even beside your bed. 

These trackers measure things like heart rate, activity, and even brainwaves to measure the quality and length of your sleep.

**Are they accurate?**
Wearables do a pretty good job of tracking total sleep time. They aren't the most accurate when it comes to sleep stages, so don't rely on that information to guide too many decisions about what's working. 

However, the information they offer is useful and more accurate than our own estimations.

rec9ZMVlGr9gWx0Uq.Name: sleepstages 1.4
rec9ZMVlGr9gWx0Uq.Bottom Body:
**Sleep Stability**

One of the key goals of improving your sleep is to improve your sleep stability. 

**What is sleep stability?** Sleep stability means keeping a regular sleep schedule and passing through three to four 90 minute sleep cycles each night. Simply put, it means getting fairly regular and stable sleep.  

It's ok to wake up during the night, move during sleep, and never remember a single dream. It's also common to have nights where sleep doesn't come easy. 

Fortunately, there are many things you can do to boost sleep stability and hone in on the many benefits that good sleep has to offer.

rec9lHMjltXa2xdSV.Name: Why  1.5
rec9lHMjltXa2xdSV.Bottom Body:
**Look at the psychology of it all**
According to Maslow's hierarchy of needs, in order to reach the best versions of ourselves, we need to have our basic needs met. 

**The foundation**
The foundation of this model is our physiological needs. Things like food, shelter, breathing, and **sleep**. 

If we constantly struggle with sleep, it can make us feel stuck at the bottom. We might even obsess over it.

That's one of the reasons that sleep issues can feel like a dark cloud that's hovering above you.

recA8tGH7qnJxBUtB.Name: Hydration 1.6
recA8tGH7qnJxBUtB.Bottom Body:

Staying hydrated is important to ensure you maintain healthy sleep.

Try implementing strategies into your daily and bedtime routines to ensure you are getting the benefits of hydration without it negatively impacting your sleep!

Now we journey onto learning about supplements that can help improve the quality of your sleep...

recAJgAKpGK9rDj2m.Name: change 1.3
recAJgAKpGK9rDj2m.Bottom Body:
**Overestimating your own ability causes you to**:
- Miss out on important learning opportunities
- Set ineffective goals 
- Underestimate your own strengths and weaknesses

**How do I avoid it?**
By approaching every change from the position of an amateur, you'll be able to more honestly assess what needs to be done and the appropriate first steps to take. 

In other words, start from the bottom of the competence ladder to avoid making any blunders.
recAJgAKpGK9rDj2m.Top Body:
**1. Ability**

Remember when we learned about the competence ladder? One of the most common mistakes people make when trying to make changes is overestimating their own ability.

This is known as the **DunningKruger effect**. According to psychologist Dr. David Dunning, the first rule of the Dunning-Kruger club is you dont know youre a member of the Dunning-Kruger club.

recAMaqpGDvTHFnp1.Name: levelup2 3.1

recAZV2z4MYsiv3Gn.Name: pickingbedtime 1.4
recAZV2z4MYsiv3Gn.Bottom Body:
You can use your bedtime as a general guideline for when to go to bed. That means you don't go to sleep way earlier and you try your best to begin your routine about an hour before you want to be sleeping. 

BUT, if you aren't sleepy, or if sleep isn't coming after 20 minutes, go do something relaxing outside of your bed until you feel sleepy!

If you're having significant sleep issues, it's actually very important to only go to bed when you are sleepy. This will help strengthen the relationship between bed + sleep AND it helps to reboot your relationship with sleep! 

So, pick a bedtime and use it as a general guideline but learn to focus more on going to sleep when you are tired (and waking up at the same time every day).

To induce Yoga Nidra, you must listen to a set of instructions, similar to a guided meditation. So, select a recording from an app, online, or elsewhere. You can find free sessions for sleep from apps like Insight Timer.

Once youre in that cozy state-of-mind and you have your yoga nidra app ready, choose your recording and be prepared for relaxation.

The session will involve visualizing your body parts and letting yourself sink into the relaxation of yoga nidra until you become aware of your entire body.

Ahhhhhhhhhhh.

recAjt1EUFmHxco1p.Name: unlearn 1.1
recAjt1EUFmHxco1p.Bottom Body:
In order to really understand how to transform your relationship with sleep, we need to go back to the basics.

**What basics? **The basics of all human behavior and how our brains build the programs we use to navigate our worlds. These programs tend to have a pretty big impact on how you sleep. 

**How do we learn behaviors?**
For the most part, we rarely think about how we learn behaviors that we do every day. That's because our brains are very good at building automatic programming. 

There are two basic types of learning in human behavior:
1. **Classical conditioning**- Learning by association!It's a passive form of learning where you are building an association between a previously neutral stimulus (ice cream truck music) with a naturally existing stimulus (the yummy taste of ice cream). The result? Hear ice cream truck music and crave ice cream! (there may also be a little salivation involved). 
2. **Operant conditioning**- The strength of a behavior is modified by reward or punishment. For instance, making your bed in the morning makes you feel accomplished  so you're more likely to keep doing it. Also, eating ice cream tastes good so you're more likely to chase down the ice cream man and give him your coins. 

Even though we don't always think about how we learn, we are constantly reacting to environmental cues and engaging in behaviors due to these programs. 

Going back to the basics is one of the key ways that psychologists help people modify their behaviors and reprogram their minds and body's to react in healthier ways! 

**Learning and sleep**
A lot of sleep issues are actually caused by passive learning (e.g. classical conditioning).  Let's take a closer look...

recB30Sck046aukXj.Name: Sleep Basics 101 Overview 1.5
recB30Sck046aukXj.Bottom Body:
During the night you move through several stages of sleep that have unique qualities and benefits. This is referred to as **sleep architecture.**

Stages 1 and 2 include lighter sleep.

Stage 3 includes deep restorative sleep.

REM sleep is primarily when you dream, and you spend more time dreaming in the second half of the night.

recBGp7TCH5dHhCTC.Name: Decompression 1.3
recBGp7TCH5dHhCTC.Bottom Body:
**Meet the Power Down Hour**
Start thinking of beginning your evening decompression one hour before bedtime. Starting out you can aim for 30 minutes (the power down half hour, if you will). 

**Set an alarm**
To make your life easier, set an alarm about an hour before bedtime. Many smartphones have this setting available. The alarm acts as a cue that it's time to stop whatever activity you're doing and begin your bedtime routine. 

**The purpose of your power down**
A power down hour is designed to help your mind unwind from the day, prepare your body for bed, and physically decompress to ease you off to sleep.

**Build a routine**
You may not be ready to build an entire routine yet, so we suggest starting out with the most important element  **mental decompression**. 

To get things started, let's focus on some awesome (and scientifically proven) decompression techniques that you can use in your power down hour...

recBZCX6ZJmEpTMrk.Name: Quickwin4.2
recBZCX6ZJmEpTMrk.Bottom Body:
Fortunately, there are many ways to boost your melatonin levels the old natural way!

Melatonin is also known as the Dracula hormone because it loves the dark. Too much light exposure before bed can leads to lower levels as you're trying to drift off. 

So, how do you get ready for bed AND boost melatonin?

recBdyRO20ngPQKZp.Name: checkin 3.1
recBdyRO20ngPQKZp.Bottom Body:
Over the last two weeks, you were given two action items to help you reboot your relationship with sleep. 

1. **Waking up at the same time every morning**
2. **Unplugging and decompressing before bedtime**- setting an alarm for bed, putting away electronics at least 30 minutes before bed, and engaging in some mental decompression exercises (i.e. journaling). 

Let's do a little check-in!

recBhxkDyUBklg38e.Name: mythBuster 1.2
recBhxkDyUBklg38e.Bottom Body:
**Myth: Dreams are an indicator of sleep quality**

A lot of people believe that if they can't remember their dreams, they didn't sleep well. Likewise, people also believe that remembering a lot of dreams means you slept well. 

**The truth?** Your brain isn't programmed to remember your dreams! Here are a few reasons why:
1. The neurochemical conditions of your brain during sleep means memories don't form in the same way
2. Dreams are weird. It's hard to remember illogical and nonsensical things (epic or emotional dreams sometimes stick better in our memories)
3. A chemical called norepinephrine, which helps move experiences into memory form, is not active during sleep

**In general, people only recall dreams that get interrupted**. If youre having a restless night, you may remember more dreams than usual.

recBnZcUnJFnkdjcb.Name: BasicsQ 1.11

recBow4sWiXHQ7515.Name: action 2.3
recBow4sWiXHQ7515.Bottom Body:
**2. UNPLUG AND DECOMPRESS BEFORE BEDTIME**

You just learned all about the importance of a bedtime routine and reducing the impact of blue light. 

This week, we want you to begin working on creating a bedtime routine that reduces blue light exposure and helps you decompress! 

**Step 1: Unplug**
Start out by setting a bedtime alarm on your phone for an hour before you want to be sleeping. 

When that alarm goes off it's time to power down. That means, turn off Netflix and begin your bedtime routine. Try to stop using electronics at least 30 minutes before bedtime. You can start smaller if needed! The goal will be to gradually increase that window. 

**Step 2: Decompress**
Next, we'd like to suggest journaling as your first mental decompression technique. Even if you aren't a fan of writing, journaling will act as an awesome way to bring closure to your day, express your feelings, and mentally decompress before bedtime. 

Try just 5-10 minutes to get started. You can write about anything! We suggest beginning with a to-do list or log about your day. 

(An alternative decompression technique could be: Reading)

recBpKfKPKIxDaF33.Name: cantsleep 1.4
recBpKfKPKIxDaF33.Bottom Body:
**GET BORED**

If** **20 minutes or so have passed and you still arent falling back to sleep, its time to leave your bed. Staying in bed will only train your brain that the bed is a place to ruminate and rage over not falling back to sleep.

Head into another room and get ready to bore yourself back to sleep. **Pick somewhere cozy, snuggle up with a blanket and get bored.** Try listening to talk radio, a boring podcast, or read the manual from your dishwasher. 

TV isn't an ideal escape, but if you insist, try wearing blue light blocking glasses and watch something relaxing or boring.

**An escape plan**
If you regularly have awakenings during the night and need a safe space to chill, you can create a **Hygge Space**!

**Getting Hygge with it**
Hygge (pronounced hue-guh) is the Danish and Norwegian word for coziness. In general, hygge refers to the concept of happiness and encompasses all things cozy and relaxing. Sounds nice, right? Think blankets, pillows, a cup of tea, and soothing sounds. 

Here are some tips on how to create this space....

When building new habits its best to keep them simple and attainable.

Implement your new habit at least three times this week and take note of how it impacts your sleep. 

You can take actual notes about your sleep in your journal if you want to double-dip on productivity. Stack those habits!

recCQfRjlajj9Hga8.Name: week4summary 4.4
recCQfRjlajj9Hga8.Bottom Body:
**3. Diet, hydration, supplements and sleep**
- **Food and sleep**: A healthy balanced diet can improve your sleep. Foods that are high in sugar and saturated fats may be especially disruptive to sleep quality. To get better sleep, aim to stop eating around 3 hours before bed, or opt for healthy balanced snacks like almonds and a small banana. 
- **Hydration**: Dehydration can leave you feeling drained, foggy, and disrupts sleep due to exacerbating snoring, high blood, pressure, dry mouth, muscle cramps, and reducing melatonin. Proper hydration optimizes all the cellular repair processes during sleep and helps you sleep more soundly!
- **Supplements:** Nearly half of the population is deficient in common minerals and vitamins that are important to sleep. Before jumping into sleep supplements, make sure to cover your basics with vitamin D, a multivitamin, check your iron, and take magnesium. When you're ready to level up a little you can try hops, valerian root, chamomile, or glycine for some snooze-inducing benefits.

recDiFg43iHOEY8Za.Name: mythBuster 2.1
