A lot of people believe that getting more sleep means you are getting more rest! 

The truth? Our sleep needs vary. In general, quality sleep is better than sleeping for longer periods. There are also genes that impact sleep needs...

recDj66uqIIRW1COw.Name: Relearn 1.1
recDj66uqIIRW1COw.Bottom Body:
In order to help reprogram your mind and body for better sleep, you need to reboot the association between bed and sleep.

**A quick review before we get started:**

In your last journey, you discovered that learning by association can lead to many sleep problems.

The two key ways to decondition or unlearn an unwanted association is to:

1. **Weaken the association**
2. **Build new associations**

If they no longer occur together, that association begins to weaken.

**So, how do you get started?**

recDqvU2UNEXmDJ6J.Name: Quickwin 6.2
recDqvU2UNEXmDJ6J.Bottom Body:
**Blast some upbeat music and bust out some dance moves!**

When you wake up in the morning your body has natural mechanisms that gradually boost your alertness. Getting some activity in your morning ritual is a great way to capitalize on these processes, and doing it in a way thats fun and brings you joy is going to be the best way to start your day!

**The research**
A 2013 study in the Journal of Positive Psychology showed that 2 weeks of upbeat music significantly boosted people's moods and happiness levels! 

This means that playing your favorite tunes in the AM not only boosts your energy but also boosts your happiness. We could all use some more happiness boosting, couldn't we?

recDyL8gOxoVaf340.Name: sneaky 1.7
recDyL8gOxoVaf340.Bottom Body:
**Allergy (and flu) medications and sleep**

Sometimes you need to take a certain allergy or flu medication and its sleep-disrupting problems are the least of your concerns. 

However, knowing how to select medications that have a minimal impact on your sleep is important! Especially if you regularly suffer from allergies.

**Stimulants**
Many over-the-counter medications contain **Pseudoephedrine**. This decongestant can lead to sleeplessness and lowered sleep quality. It's fine from time to time but try to limit your use before bed if possible. 

**First-generation**
There are also many first-generation allergy medications that may lead to excessive drowsiness that lingers long after you've woken up. They can also disrupt the quality of your sleep and reduce REM.

These include **diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine,** and **doxylamine.**

**TIPS**:
- Limit your use of sleep-disrupting medications to 7 days
- Swap out your allergy meds for ones that are less disruptive to slumber such as **loratadine.**
- Use saline sprays or a neti pot to help with allergies

\*Always talk to your doctor before discontinuing or changing your medications

recEAqtql4jeHJ8D9.Name: week3summary 1.4
recEAqtql4jeHJ8D9.Bottom Body:
**3. Your sleep environment**
- **Sleep sanctuary:** We discused how your bedroom should only be used for sleep and how to optimize your sleep santuary to create an inviting and relaxing environment. 
- **Darkness**: using an eye mask or blackout curtains can seriously enhance your slumber
- **Bed basics**: Choosing moisture-wicking sheets, a quality pillow, and keeping the room temperature at 65 (18.3)
- **Lights**: Grab motion sensor night lights and swap out any bedroom bulbs that might disrupt your sleep.
- **Noise**: Environmental noise is very detrimental to sleep. Try ear plugs or a noise machine to improve your sleep stability.

recEFaIa4L2sq1s5t.Name: Sleepdrive 1.6
recEFaIa4L2sq1s5t.Bottom Body:
So, to recap  Your circadian alerting system goes off the clock at the end of the day so your sleep drive can send you to snoozeville.

Your circadian rhythm keeps the alerting system quiet during the night and sends all those good sleep chemicals your way so you can maintain your snoozefest!

Rinse and repeat.

recEKpBIDPmC7QTuF.Name: habittips 1.2
recEKpBIDPmC7QTuF.Bottom Body:
**2. STACK IT**

Habit stacking is an awesome technique that eases the burden of starting something new. If you want to start a new habit or behavior, add it on to an existing habit or behavior. 

**How to habit stack**
For instance, want to kickstart your mornings with a made bed? As soon as you get out of bed in the morning, make your bed! You can also add things like meditation to morning coffee, or stretching right after you brush your teeth. 

Think of habit stacking as your built-in scheduling system for new habits

recEQQQEyZyMxT9Bx.Name: sneaky 1.5
recEQQQEyZyMxT9Bx.Bottom Body:
**Alcohol and sleep**
You may or may not be aware that alcohol is commonly used as a sleep aid, referred to as a nightcap".

This is because it causes a sedative effect by mimicking an important chemical messenger in your brain, called GABA.

So, a little booze in the evening may **feel** like its helping you fall asleep, but in actuality, it is secretly wreaking havoc on your peaceful slumber.Even just one drink within 3 hours of bedtime can disrupt your sleep.

**Your sleep on alcohol**
- Alcohol reduces REM sleep
- It sends excitatory signals as it's metabolized
- Booze reduces sleep quality
- Worsens snoring and sleep apnea

**TIPS:**
- Avoid drinking within 3 hours of bedtime
- Stay hydrated to help your body metabolize alcohol
- Swap out for a non-alcoholic beer in the evenings 

The tricky thing with alcohol is that you may not even notice your sleep was disrupted. You will, however, notice how much better you feel on nights you don't drink.

Try swapping in a non-alcoholic beer (the hops can make you sleepy), chamomile tea, or a club soda with a twist of lime.

recESXWrO92QYHXtr.Name: quickwinFA 3.3
recESXWrO92QYHXtr.Bottom Body:
Want to start meditating? Add 10 minutes of meditation time right after you brush your teeth in the morning. 

Want to stretch more? Do a stretching routine during your favorite show!

See? Scheduling a new habit alongside one that's already well-established sets you up for success and takes out a lot of the hassle. 

It's all about working smarter!

recEj0Z7J2AwKSgsu.Name: Oriented 1.5
recEj0Z7J2AwKSgsu.Bottom Body:
## 3. Your Sleep Coach 
Your sleep coach is always available to answer your burning questions about sleep. Simply send them a message and you'll receive your reply within a few hours. 

Sleep coaches are professionally trained sleep experts who have a passion for helping you sleep better! You can use your coach to help you with accountability by scheduling reminders for new habits. Your coach will also check in on your progress and help you along as you make changes!

You'll even be given opportunities to have one-on-one sessions with your sleep coach!  _Sweeeeeet_.

recEr3ekA8IpLMdgD.Name: Trackingprogress 1.1
recEr3ekA8IpLMdgD.Bottom Body:
You may be wondering:
**How do I track my progress?**

You may or may not be interested in tracking your progress, but it can be extremely helpful (especially at the beginning). Tracking your sleep can be tricky. The number one way to track your sleep is with a sleep diary. 

A sleep diary is simply a log of when you went to bed, when you woke up, and some other details about your day and night. 

Tracking your sleep will help you identify habits that may be messing with your sleep and will also let you know over time how some new habits may be having a positive impact on your sleep!

recEs2lOJVbATpwPh.Name: HypeUp 1.3
recEs2lOJVbATpwPh.Bottom Body:
We also reviewed how activities in your morning, daytime, and night can impact your sleep.

**Morning:** Wake up at the same time every morning, grab a glass of water, and get moving!

**Daytime:** Daily exercise for just 20 minutes improves the quality of your sleep

**Night:** A power-down hour where you mentally decompress and put away electronics can be a game-changer for your sleep!

recEypu4TERi9n60V.Name: Grogginess 1.4
recEypu4TERi9n60V.Bottom Body:
Wouldnt it be great if we had some tips on what you can do to beat the grogginess?

Oh, thats right! We DO have some tips for you to beat that groggy monster. We told you wed always have your back, and we werent lying homey!

Lets start with the first tip!

recF2DxLiwpnJOmt0.Name: quickwins 3.2
recF2DxLiwpnJOmt0.Bottom Body:
**Habit-Stacking**

You may or may not have heard of habit-stacking. Either way, it's important to understand how you can use this concept to help you build new habits around sleep!

**What is habit-stacking**
Building new habits is hard and mentally taxing. One excellent technique that makes building new habits WAY easier is habit-stacking. 

You take your new habit that you want to build and you combine it with a habit you already have! For instance, if you want to add journaling to your day  combine journaling with your morning cup of coffee.

recFBCYIhwm3eOcfT.Name: unlearn 1.3
recFBCYIhwm3eOcfT.Bottom Body:
**Learning by association**
When you engage in activities in bed that aren't sleeping, your brain creates associations between those activities and sleep!

Sleep therapists call this **stimulus dyscontrol**.

Let's learn by emoji for a moment...

**Stimulus control**
 +  = Good stimulus control
 ++++ = Stimulus dyscontrol

**Ok, you want an example?**
Let's look at watching TV in bed as an example of a stimulus. If you regularly watch TV in bed, your mind associates bed with TV. 

Laying in bed will then activate pathways in your brain that say "hey, put on our show, we're ready to be entertained!"

Ideally, when you lay in bed, the only pathway you want to be activated are the ones that say "Zzzzzzzzzzzz."

**Practice makes ummm ....imperfect**
The more things you do in bed, the more of these unhelpful programs get formed.

The more frequently you do that activity in bed, the stronger (and more powerful) those pathways become.

Good stimulus control is very simple: Bed + Sleep (and sex). We like simple. So do your body's internal clocks.

recFCZ24FYeFPRS7E.Name: levelup 4.1
recFCZ24FYeFPRS7E.Bottom Body:
This week you've been working on the following action plan for rebooting your sleep: 

1. **Wakeup at the same time every morning**
2. **Unplug and decompress before bedtime**
    1. Put electronics away at least 30 minutes before bedtime
    2. Do mental decompression as part of bedtime routine (journaling or progressive muscle relaxation)
3. **Only go to bed when sleepy! **
4. **Drink a glass of water as soon as you wake up**

and, we just recently added

5\. **Get 10-20 minutes of morning sunshine**

recFMh5fNLp0mE5pT.Name: Blue light 1.2
recFMh5fNLp0mE5pT.Bottom Body:
**All about blue light**
Have you ever noticed how a bright blue sky gives you energy? The main reason is due to the high-intensity blue light that comes from the sun. Blue light is a short wavelength, which means it produces higher amounts of energy. 

The sun isnt the only source of blue light, you get a ton of it from artificial sources such as:

- Television screens
- Digital devices (phones, tablets, computer monitors)
- Fluorescent lights
- LED lights

**Is blue light always bad?**
When used correctly (i.e. during the daytime), blue light can help you focus, boost energy, and even help regulate your sleep-wake cycle.

However, most of us are getting way too much, especially late in the evenings.

Lets take a look at why thats a problem...

recFZSwIvXJXhYeW6.Name: Quickwin 14.3
recFZSwIvXJXhYeW6.Bottom Body:
**Setting your bedtime: The Dr. Breus method.**

**Step #1**: Set your wake time..

**Step #2**: Work backward from your chosen wake time.

**Step #3**: Assume youll have 5 sleep cycles, consisting of approximately 90 minutes each (90x5 = 450 minutes)

**Step #4**: Subtract 450 minutes from your chosen wake time (or 7.5 hours).

**Step #5**: Give yourself 20 minutes to fall asleep.

And Voila! You have your bedtime set.

Need an example?

Ok so if you want to wake up at 7am:
1. 7am - 7.5 hours = 11:30pm
2. 11:30pm - 20 minutes to fall asleep = 11:10 bedtime!

Easy peasy!

Try this out for yourself as a way to get your ideal schedule on. It may take some adjusting. When things are well aligned, youll find yourself waking up 5 to 10 minutes before your alarm clock.

recFca7JbrVhdiM2h.Name: CircRhythm 1.4
recFca7JbrVhdiM2h.Bottom Body:
**It predicts sunrise and sunset**
Your circadian rhythm is able to predict what time the sun will set based on when you wake up. It resets each morning during that first burst of daylight and uses that information to also predict when the sun will rise the next morning.

**Why?** Our ancestors needed to be able to predict daylight hours in order to actively hunt and return to their villages or caves for safety. 

**It adjusts for seasons**
Circadian rhythms run a little longer than 24 hours to adjust for changing daylight hours of different seasons.Under natural circumstances, people tend to sleep a little longer in the winter months and less in the summer. However, with so much artificial light, most peoples bodies are now tricked into believing its forever summer.

**Why?** During hunter and gatherer times it was important to use those long summer days to work, hunt and grow food. It was more important to conserve energy in winters since supplies were lower.

recFlJl0GgfWXMLht.Name: Lighting 1.3
recFlJl0GgfWXMLht.Bottom Body:
**Motion sensor night lights!**

You should use night lights with motion sensors to help guide you during bathroom breaks or any other disruptions.

By relying on this type of night light, you avoid having to turn on overhead lights in the middle of the night, which can mess with your melatonin production and make it harder for you to fall back asleep.

If the lights only turn on when youre already awake, theres less of a chance that they cant mess with you while youre sleeping, too!

Theyll also help save your toes from injuries when attempting to navigate in the dark.

recFliZhbIZrNqI69.Name: quickwin 3.3
recFliZhbIZrNqI69.Bottom Body:
Want to start meditating? Add 10 minutes of meditation time right after you brush your teeth in the morning. 

Want to stretch more? Do a stretching routine during your favorite show!

See? Scheduling a new habit alongside one that's already well-established sets you up for success and takes out a lot of the hassle. 

It's all about working smarter!

recFp1vYOevvtvoMn.Name: intake 3.1
recFp1vYOevvtvoMn.Bottom Body:
Before we reach the end of week 4, we want to check in on how you're doing!

This will only take about 3 minutes of your time and will provide valuable information about where you're at in your sleep journey!

recFpMXtDjz0ONO02.Name: Substances 1.7
recFpMXtDjz0ONO02.Bottom Body:
**Alcohol pumps you up!**

When you first drink that nightcap it leads to a relaxing sedative effect. However, as your body metabolizes alcohol in the wee hours of the morning, it blasts excitatory chemicals.

Excitatory chemicals arent exactly helpful for sleep.

**Alcohol disrupts your sleep cycles!**
Alcohol can help you slip into deep sleep more quickly but it is disruptive to your sleep architecture.

Alcohol leads to a reduction in REM sleep. REM sleep is when you mostly dream and is extremely important for mental restoration, memory reconsolidation, and emotional processing!

**Alcohol makes you a bad bed partner!**
Alcohol can also make snoring and sleep apnea worse.  Its also a diuretic, which means more bathroom breaks. Aside from disrupting your own sleep, these qualities make you less fun to share a bed with!

recFzWkm85oSfXxev.Name: Grogginess 1.4
recFzWkm85oSfXxev.Bottom Body:
**Try a Green Smoothie! Nom nom nom.**

This likely isn't new info, but ithelps to be reminded that food can be a huge energy boost when we need it!

Not only are green smoothies DELICIOUS, but they can help boost focus and reduce inflammation. Inflammation causes a lot more feeling bleh than you realize.

You can find a plethora of green smoothie recipes online, but we have a super quick and simple recipe to share with you right now that you can try:

Rested Health Green Smoothie
- 1 handful of kale
- 1 handful of parsley
- 1 cup of mixed fruit
- 1 Tbsp flax seeds
- 3/4 Cup green tea - (cooled) or tsp Matcha
- 1 Tbsp hemp seeds

Ok, so you've got your mind filled with positive thoughts. You're "acting" energetic. You've got your green smoothie in hand.

Now what?

recG7dMb8slNIgYtZ.Name: goalsleepthrunight1.2
recG7dMb8slNIgYtZ.Bottom Body:
**1. Mental decompression routine**

Not properly decompressing before bed can lead to midnight awakenings and reduced sleep quality.

**Why?** When you fall asleep with lingering "to-do" lists and hovering worries, your mind keeps working on these problems as you try to sleep. Remember subconscious sleep stress? It's real, and it will quite literally haunt your dreams!

**How do I decompress?** You should aim to wind down from your day about an hour before you usually go to sleep. One of the most effective techniques you can try is journaling! 

Try making a to-do list for tomorrow with an action plan for any items that are up in the air. This allows your brain to have closure from your day.

recG9HmwglVMVVVGG.Name: HypeUp 1.5
recG9HmwglVMVVVGG.Bottom Body:
Dont forget that change takes time so be patient with your journey and GET PUMPED UP to learn so much more about how to reboot your sleep system.

This week, were going to dig a little deeper into the techniques you can use to start sleeping better or how to improve the techniques youre currently using!

recGGxvlxdUvrGPAr.Name: pickingbedtime 1.1
recGGxvlxdUvrGPAr.Bottom Body:
**Going to bed "on time"**

In an ideal world, we would all have a set bedtime, get tired right before that bedtime, and fall asleep as soon as our heads hit the pillow. 

Unfortunately, the world isn't ideal. 

Sticking to a set bedtime can be detrimental when you get yourself into a habit of "trying to fall asleep."

However, it does help to have an idea of a healthy bedtime. So, let's take a look at how to calculate your "ideal" bedtime...

recGKjkhun4BBANsO.Name: Importance 1.2
recGKjkhun4BBANsO.Bottom Body:
**Why is a sleep sanctuary important?**

Creating an environment thats relaxing and inviting can actually help your sleep.

An inviting and peaceful environment helps to create helpful associations between bedroom + sleep.

You can get incredibly advanced with building a state-of-the-art sleep sanctuary.

For now, lets check out the basics!

recGUCs93ISsxjAFV.Name: Quickwin 10.1
recGUCs93ISsxjAFV.Bottom Body:
Its that time again! Time for another Quick Win!

This next one can help to boost your sleep-wake cycle, and can even help to sync a circadian rhythm that might be thrown off track!

Lets find out what it is...

recGXd5SRrRcG96jC.Name: levelup 3.2
recGXd5SRrRcG96jC.Bottom Body:
As we just discussed, going to bed when you aren't sleepy can lead to more stress when you are "trying to fall asleep."

Learning how to identify fatigue vs sleepiness will help you to be mindful about when you need to stretch or grab a glass of water (both help with fatigue) vs when you should be heading top slumber town! 

**But, what if I don't get sleepy until late?**
Staying up past your ideal bedtime may induce a little stress. Remember, rebuilding your relationship with sleep doesn't mean getting perfect sleep every night. In fact, you may have some days where you get less sleep. 

As you strengthen the relationship between bed + sleep and regulate your sleep schedule by getting up at the same time every day, your body will naturally optimize your sleep system. 

This means that it's possible you may have some nights where you sleep less. 

A few bad days now will help you have more good days in the future.

recGZnlAGpFm6DCv5.Name: Elimhabits 1.1
recGZnlAGpFm6DCv5.Bottom Body:
We want to help you reach your goal of reducing electronics before bed. 

**Defining your goal**
As you now know, using electronics before bed can disrupt your sleep in a number of ways. For instance, the blue light emitted from electronics reduces melatonin two times longer than other types of light.

To get you started, we're going to talk about two things you can do to help you reduce electronics before bed!

1. Get alarmed 
2. Swap it out

recGc7Xafb6UKp5aZ.Name: Difficulty Falling Asleep 1.2
recGc7Xafb6UKp5aZ.Bottom Body:
Here is one actionable tip that you can begin implementing tonight to help better unwind and fall asleep:

1. **Journaling a to-do list:** If you're new to journaling it can feel a little intimidating at first. However, journaling a to-do list is one of the most effective ways to quickly unwind from your day. It also creates a **cue for your brain** that it's time for sleep.  Your brain likes cues. 

**How to do it:**
If you don't already have one, pick up a journal and pen you like using (trust us, it'll make it more fun). Next, set aside 5-10 minutes before you go to bed to journal. You can do it before you wash your face and get ready, or just before you're ready to settle under your sheets. 

**What do I write?**
One of the most effective ways to bring closure to your day and ease your mind for sleep is to make a to-do list. List out any impending duties, plans of action, or notes like "to be determined."

recGrCBjeFmVtoTot.Name: Why  1.2
recGrCBjeFmVtoTot.Bottom Body:
**YES! REALLY!**
Sleep is an essential need, but there is zero evidence that you can actually die from lack of sleep. 

**The case of Maureen Weston**
In fact, the Guinness Book of World Records even used to hold world records for wakefulness (a terrible idea which they eventually suspended). 

As an example: In 1977, Mrs. Maureen Weston of Peterborough, Cambridgeshire stayed awake for 449 hours. Yeesh, Mrs. Weston, take a nap. 

Sure, she wasn't exactly thriving by the end, and she began to hallucinate a little. BUT, she was alive and fully recovered once she allowed slumber back into her life. 

**How did she survive?**

recGyNUUwTzLCVnBl.Name: alcoholSleep 1.3
recGyNUUwTzLCVnBl.Bottom Body:
**1. The Rebound Effect: **
Alcohol mimics an important chemical in your brain called GABA. GABA has calming effects by blocking an excitatory chemical called glutamate. Under normal circumstances, your brain would balance these two chemicals. 

**What happens when I drink?**
Due to alcohol's disruption on the balance of GABA and glutamate, as alcohol is metabolized, your brain boosts glutamate in an attempt to restore order. This generally occurs around 5 hours after you consume alcohol. 

**The result? **At a minimum, you'll have disrupted sleep. Sometimes, you'll find yourself wide awake at 5am ready to race Usain Bolt.

Even if you don't remember any sleep disruptions, alcohol has been shown to disrupt your slumber as it gets metabolized.

recH07U0L9PAOsmVD.Name: Importance 1.6
recH07U0L9PAOsmVD.Bottom Body:
Are you ready?

Great! Lets explore the basics of an awesome sleep sanctuary!

**TIP:** As you begin making changes to your room, feel free to refer to it as your sleep sanctuary. Theres no scientific reason, it just sounds cool.

Lets go!

recH4wdkq0Sio0Y2P.Name: Exercise 1.4
recH4wdkq0Sio0Y2P.Bottom Body:
When you exercise during the day this is a good thing for your circadian rhythm because as your body cools down it can help trigger evening sleepiness.

**How to exercise your way to better sleep**

If you currently arent exercising, any exercise that you enjoy is a great start. You should aim for around 20 minutes a day.

There are three general categories of exercise that promote better sleep:
1. Aerobic exercise (aim for 80% max heart rate)
2. Strength training (pump the iron)
3. Flexibility training (yoga, pilates, etc)

recH5vl3fgbPg1o7J.Name: BasicsQ 1.3
recH5vl3fgbPg1o7J.Bottom Body:
Now, let's take a moment to remember everything you learned about "Don't worry, your body will sleep."

You do remember absolutely everything, right? 

Let's take the quiz...

recH7YByTuMo4xwu0.Name: Needs 1.1
recH7YByTuMo4xwu0.Bottom Body:
In the last journey, we asked you how much sleep you think you need.

**Want to know the truth?** The official recommendation for adults of all ages is somewhere between 7-8 hours per night. 

Some people need a little less. Some people need a little more. 

You will also find that your body needs more or less depending on your activities that day! 

Later on, we'll teach you how to find the optimal amount of sleep for **you**.

recHAvAjiLXbKfquO.Name: goals pre quiz
recHAvAjiLXbKfquO.Bottom Body:
Now that you've got building goals down, let's get started on some tips made just for you! 

We want to help you build your own SMART goals by giving you personalized and actionable advice based on your needs. 

To kick things off, let's look at the number one thing you'd like to focus on this week...

recHQx5tSy1tdosvI.Name: Tracking 1.5
recHQx5tSy1tdosvI.Bottom Body:
The data from your tracker gets analyzed and put into graphs that help you get an idea of your sleep.

Heres what they offer:

- **Sleep/Wake Times**: Gathered using measurements of movement and heart rate and sometimes even breathing patterns.

- **Sleep Duration**: Measure sleep time and awakenings during the night to calculate total **sleep duration**.

- **Sleep Quality**: Devices use metrics such as heart rate, movement, and even brain waves to assess sleep quality. Some apps even plot out sleep stages and cycles per night. 

**NOTE**: Unless you're wearing a tracker that measures brain waves, the measures of sleep stages aren't too accurate. However, they can give you a general idea of your sleeping patterns!

recHY1drRvUGlatMm.Name: Supplements 1.5
recHY1drRvUGlatMm.Bottom Body:
Youve got the basics down, so here are some next-level sleep-inducing supplements you can try. 

\*\*Always make sure to talk to your doctor before taking any new supplements or discontinuing any medication. 

**Next Level options**
- **Valerian Root-** This is one of the most researched all-natural sleep aids commonly used for insomnia. It can help you fall asleep more quickly and reduce your bodys response to stress.
    - Try: 300 to 600 mg 30 minutes to two hours before bedtime

- **Hops: **Hops has long been used as a sleep aid and works extremely well when combined with valerian root. Hops has natural sedative effects and lowers your core temperature, which helps you fall asleep.
    - Try 300 to 500mg on its own or 40-60mg when combined with 300 mg of valerian root.

**Fun tip**: If you like beer at night, switch to a **non-alcoholic beer** to get your hops on without disrupting your sleep! Studies have even shown that a non-alcoholic beer with dinner can improve sleep that evening!

- **Chamomile Leaf- **Youve likely seen this one in tea form. Chamomile is soothing because it binds to benzodiazepine receptors in the brain causing a calming effect. You can have it in tea form or get a more potent dose with a supplement.
    - Dose: 220 to 1,600 mg daily 

- **Glycine-** Glycine is an amino acid and neurotransmitter important for skin, muscles, brain health, and sleep. When taking it before bedtime it lowers your body temperature which helps improve your progression into sleep. It has also been shown to improve sleep quality, reducing daytime sleepiness and can elevate serotonin levels.
    - Dose: 3 to 5 grams taken orally before bed

recHZoVq7KiIWr3w6.Name: habittips 1.1
recHZoVq7KiIWr3w6.Bottom Body:
As you go about setting small achievable goals each week, it helps to have some pro tips in your back pocket. 

The first tip is:
**1. START SMALL**
Trying to make a change? Start small. Make it something so achievable that your success rate is 100%. For instance, if you're trying to start meditating, do it for 1 minute. That's it! 

The important thing is to get started and earn a win. This creates momentum, moves you closer to your goal, and gives you the confidence boost of that "ok, I **can** do this" feeling.

recHfkvewlXWQZIsK.Name: Mornings 1.6
recHfkvewlXWQZIsK.Bottom Body:
**Boost your mornings**

Building a morning routine doesn't have to be complicated. By making some minor changes to your morning you can have huge results. 

This week, along with waking up at the same time every morning and grabbing a glass of water, start also including some sunshine into your mornings. 

If this is new, you can aim for 3 days a week to get you started!

recHrbVNyO1IZPWP0.Name: Food 1.3
recHrbVNyO1IZPWP0.Bottom Body:
**Sugary food and sleep**

Sugar tastes good, but it can really mess with your sleep.

High levels of sugar consumed throughout your day leads to sleep disturbances and less time in deep slow-wave sleep. Deep sleep is incredibly important for feeling Rested.

To complicate matters even more, your kidneys work hard to rid your body of excess sugar by sending you to pee a lot. As a result, too much sugar can also impair your sleep by repeated bathroom trips!

Excess sugar also leads to inflammation which can exacerbate pain and make it harder to maintain sleep. 

But, is all sugar the same? No

**Sugar vs other sugar vs a different sugar**

Not all sugar is equal when it comes to impacting sleep. The worst offenders are added refined sugars and syrups like you find in sugary drinks, candy, chocolates, deserts, cakes, and cookies.

Fruits are often high in sugar but do not appear to have the same detrimental impact on sleep. So, if youre having a sweet craving before sleep, grab a banana or some mango!

Controlling your sugar intake is a great plan for health and better sleep.

However, sugar isnt the only food that impacts your snoozing...

recHsVywcVVJeK3Z0.Name: Science 1.5
recHsVywcVVJeK3Z0.Bottom Body:
Sleep might seem complicated, but some of the solutions to better sleep are actually pretty simple. There are a lot of different things you can do to optimize your sleep.

But first, lets learn a little bit more about how to track your sleep.

recHtV4hIeX8gO5ju.Name: QuickwinFA 7.2
recHtV4hIeX8gO5ju.Bottom Body:
**Sauna Time!**

Regular Sauna use has been shown to have a plethora of health benefits. It can improve how well you sleep, boost heart health, and research shows it can even reduce risk of dementia!

Some of the sleep benefits to sauna use are believed to be a product of the increased temperature at the surface of your skin (which cools your core temperature for bed) and increased heart rate.

Think of it like cardio without the ummm...cardio.

In general, regular sauna sessions improve continuity of sleep and can **help you fall asleep faster.**

recHue0fUEVIwzYiU.Name: sleepmyths 1.4
recHue0fUEVIwzYiU.Bottom Body:
**3. "Getting up on the wrong side of the bed"**

Everyone knows what it's like to wake up and just feel...well...cranky.  People who struggle with their sleep are much more likely to blame daytime moodiness, fatigue, and irritability to sleep issues. 

Psychologists call this "**Attribution."** 

The truth? While it's entirely possible that poor sleep contributed to your mood, it's also possible it was caused by other factors in your life! 

When you find yourself blaming poor sleep, take a minute and reflect on other things that may be causing you to feel this way. Try hydrating, writing it out, and maybe even a short walk. 

**Resiliency**
Your body is pretty incredible and resilient! It does a good job of handling stressors like sleeplessness. So, it's important to remember that not all of your issues are due to sleep.

recI1YdKUqoALZx1h.Name: unlearn 1.5
recI1YdKUqoALZx1h.Bottom Body:
**Reprogramming for better sleep**
Just like how repetition helped you learn the association, repetition will also help you unlearn it (it just takes a little longer to do the unlearning part).

The two key ways to decondition or unlearn an unwanted association is to:

1. **Weaken the association**
2. **Build new associations**

**How do I weaken the association?** If they no longer occur together, that association begins to weaken.So, basically, you have to stop doing it. 

**Out with the old, in with the new!**
Even better is that by learning new associations (a.k.a. good habits), you can stomp that weakened association even harder into the ground. Unlearn and relearn. 

These concepts apply to pretty much every learned habit and response. 

It also explains why that song that made you cry in 7th grade because it reminded you of your ex doesnt quite hit the same anymore.

**You and your brain**
Understanding these basic principles of neuroscience can be incredibly helpful when you're struggling to stick with changes. Life is complicated, but the basics of behavior change are pretty straightforward.  

**So now what?**

recI5DUHXoOdRehad.Name: levelup4 1.3
recI5DUHXoOdRehad.Bottom Body:
So, a summary of your action plan for rebooting your sleep:

1. **Wakeup at the same time every morning**
2. **Unplug and decompress before bedtime**
    1. Put electronics away at least 30 minutes before bedtime
    2. Do mental decompression as part of bedtime routine (journaling or progressive muscle relaxation)
3. **Only go to bed when sleepy! **
4. **Drink a glass of water as soon as you wake up**
5. **Get 10-20 minutes of morning sunshine**
6. **Build a consistent meditation practice **

This plan is the foundation of completely rebooting your sleep. You should also keep in mind that the bed is just for sleep (and sex), stress is terrible for sleep, and it's all about progress, not perfection. 

Congrats on making it through week 4!

recI6sXMCSCAZZkA3.Name: Quickwin 9.4
recI6sXMCSCAZZkA3.Bottom Body:
Sticking with change is hard, A positive affirmation that reminds you WHY you are making all these tough changes can be motivating. You can also design them to be simple little sentences of encouragement. The only rule? Make them positive.

Try something like:
I appreciate what my body does for me every day, and I engage in habits that improve my health

Changing my behavior is as easy as changing my thoughts

I challenge habits that do not serve me and engage in ones that bring me closer to my goals

Or keep it simple:

I am awesome

I am always trying to be better

I am loved

**But, do they actually work?**

recIBU7Uo6Qy6hvP9.Name: goalfallasleepfaster1.3
recIBU7Uo6Qy6hvP9.Bottom Body:
**2. Only go to bed when you are tired**

Imagine this... It's 11:30pm, you know you have to get up at 6am, you know you won't feel Rested if you don't get 7 hours of sleep.
BUT
You aren't tired. You feel fatigued, but not sleepy. 

You go to bed anyways, because that's what we do when the time comes. You lay in bed, feeling awake, trying to will sleep to happen, and...

nothing. 

You stay there a while, thinking about how tired you're going to be. You feel the stress build, the existential dread, the frustration.

Sleep isn't coming.

recIIpQyuKI4PihFZ.Name: Goals 1.5
recIIpQyuKI4PihFZ.Bottom Body:
The key to achieving success is starting small. Small goals make us more confident and keep us from feeling overwhelmed by change. 

You don't have to conquer everything at once. The important thing is to focus on making some progress. Even just 1% of change per day will bring you closer to your goals!

Don't worry  we'll help you pick some specific habits to work on to help you reach your current top sleep goal!

recIKS2YOeQQVJEvA.Name: relearn 1.6 copy
recIKS2YOeQQVJEvA.Bottom Body:
The principles of conditioning seem pretty straightforward, but it can be hard to follow these guidelines. Many of the habits we have that aren't helpful to sleep also bring us comfort, so getting rid of them can be tricky. 

**We got your back**
Don't worry, we'll keep reminding you and continually give you tips for success. For now, just focus on the fact that your bed should be restricted to sleep and sex only. 

**Get started**
Start out by eliminating one unhelpful activity three nights this week. You don't have to change everything overnight! It's all about progress, not perfection.

recIQiw0wC6UuSaxl.Name: actionplanweek2 2.1
recIQiw0wC6UuSaxl.Bottom Body:
This week you've been working on two habits to reboot your sleep:

1. **Waking up at the same time every morning**
2. **Unplugging and decompressing before bedtime**- setting an alarm for bed, putting away electronics at least 30 minutes before bed, and engaging in some mental decompression exercises (i.e. journaling). 

Let's do a little check-in!

recITDM9xu0ENTBkF.Name: Quickwin 7.4
recITDM9xu0ENTBkF.Bottom Body:
Breathing techniques are fantastic skills to have in your little toolbox. Any time you feel overwhelmed by thoughts, feelings, or life in general, give your body a little peace with some breathwork. 

Being able to send your body into a calmer state will also allow you to think more clearly and feel more in control. 

Remember that it may be difficult at first, that's normal. Practicing breathing techniques will make you more efficient at breathing!

recIYAka66Z3vanDq.Name: Overview 1.6
recIYAka66Z3vanDq.Bottom Body:
Most importantly, dont forget that change takes time. Even if you implemented all of these changes tonight, it would still take some time to see the effects.

Be patient with yourself, have fun with the changes, and get excited to start feeling more Rested!

Now, are you ready to put all this knowledge to the test?

recIZAOdFaT380m7G.Name: blue light 1.1
recIZAOdFaT380m7G.Bottom Body:
**You vs Blue Light**

You probably aren't surprised to see this topic. What you may be surprised to hear is that we aren't here just to bash blue light. 

Blue light isn't evil. In fact, there are some well-known benefits of blue light exposure. 

However, there is also ample scientific evidence showing that blue light can be very detrimental to your sleep.

**Our goal in this section is to**:
- Inform you about the positives and negatives of blue light
- Talk about how you can avoid blue light-related sleep disruptions

recIib4krSMfuBnr0.Name: general 1.1
recIib4krSMfuBnr0.Bottom Body:
A little stress is ok, but when stress feels out of control it can be very detrimental to your health. 

Fortunately, there are many ways that you can control your stress for better sleep. 

In order to better manage your stress, there are two areas we'll focus on today:
1. **Mental decompression routine**
2. **Managing stress in the moment**

recIjcAMmtqAJaVWa.Name: summary 2.6
recIjcAMmtqAJaVWa.Bottom Body:
You also continued to practice cognitive restructuring and you were introduced to the **two-arrow approach**. 

In week 3 you'll continue building on your action plan for rebooting your sleep, learn about boosting sleep stability, optimize your sleep environment, and level up your bedtime routine!

Great job finishing week 2! You've learned a ton and made a bunch of progress. GO YOU!

recImTUHj2HxIMG0x.Name: Sleepdrive 1.7
recImTUHj2HxIMG0x.Bottom Body:
Now you know how your sleep drive works directly with your circadian rhythm to promote the healthiest sleep-wake cycle.

To end off, here are a few tips you can use to help boost your sleep drive:

1. **Try waking up at the same time every day **(you're on this one already, right?)
2. **Go easy on the caffeine** - caffeine blocks adenosine
3. **Avoid long, late, or unnecessary naps** - they relieve your sleep pressure prematurely


That's it! You're basically a sleep drive expert now.

recImq261S1Of81Or.Name: Quickwin 10.2
recImq261S1Of81Or.Bottom Body:
**Pack your nightstand.**

You can stock your nightstand with supplies that you can use in case you have trouble getting back into la-la land.

- **Earplugs:** It might get noisy sometimes, silence is conducive to sleep. Noise in the middle of the night can be especially irritating, so let those earplugs mute the disruptions.

- **Eye mask:** Unexpected awakenings can lead to unintended light exposure. By blocking light from hitting your eyes your body responds with more melatonin. Melatonin = sleep.

- **Headphones**: Sometimes we need a little extra help falling back to sleep. If you share a bed with someone you may need to keep things quiet so keeping headphones nearby means you can listen to relaxing meditation tracks, nature sounds, or soothing music to help you fall back to sleep any time.

- **Book and a booklight**: Reading is an excellent relaxing activity if your mind is having a hard time settling. Keeping a book and booklight in your supply drawer is an excellent strategy for when you need to lull yourself back toward sleep.

recInh4KWpgSBxRJa.Name: week4summary 4.5
recInh4KWpgSBxRJa.Bottom Body:
**4. Meditation and sleep**

- **Meditation and sleep**: Meditation is one of the most effective habits you can adopt to improve your sleep and overall wellbeing. Studies show that it boosts sleep stability, sleep stages, and even boosts melatonin production. 
- **Meditation and brain health:** Brain scans of meditators show that they have enhanced emotional regulation and resilience. That means they are better able to handle stressful situations with less "damage." Regular meditation can repair the brain and improve brain structure, function, and connectivity.
- **Consistency is key**: Even just 10 minutes a day is enough to reap the benefits of meditation. You can do it before sleep or any time during the day to get the benefits on your nightly slumber. It's ok to start small, even just 1 minute a day. The key is to find a time that works for you and remain consistent.

recItDVARQdTg0zID.Name: QuickwinFA4.1
recItDVARQdTg0zID.Bottom Body:
Oh, wow, look what time it is! It's time for another Quick Win!

**Today's quick win is all about lights!**

Light can be your friend, but too much light close to bedtime can seriously impair your sleep.

Since you're trying to fall asleep faster, we found this cool little hack just for you!

What is it?

recIzQVedLkVQCRP8.Name: Food 1.7
recIzQVedLkVQCRP8.Bottom Body:
But what if youre reeeeeeally hungry before bed?

Wait! Before you reach for that bedtime snack...are you actually reeeeeally hungry or are you just craving a snack?

The best way to answer that question is to think of something less appealing to eat. Ask yourself will this less appealing food hit the spot? and if you answer no, youre probably not that hungry.

If you answer yes, maybe you do need a little bedtime snack. We dont want you going to bed hungry, which is also not good for your sleep.

**Some bedtime safe snack ideas:**
- **A handful of almonds plus a banana**
- **Cashews and a slice of cheese**
- **A casein protein shake with oat milk**
- **Oatmeal with cinnamon and walnuts**

recJAEyr8ufhYY7li.Name: Food 1.5
recJAEyr8ufhYY7li.Bottom Body:
**Spicy food and sleep**

Spicy foods close to bedtime can cause heartburn, acid reflux, and in more severe cases gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

This makes sleeping more difficult because the symptoms get worse when you lie down. 

So, avoid any spicy food for at least 3 hours before bedtime. We wouldnt ask you to cut it out, because...yum.

**Now that you know how foods impact your sleep, lets look at how to sleep better while still enjoying your treats!**

recJIftoLcMsDYmRl.Name: action 1.3
recJIftoLcMsDYmRl.Bottom Body:
This week, we'd like you to do your best to get up at the same time every morning. Remember that it's all about progress, not perfection, and we'll be there to cheer you on along the way! 

We want you to succeed in rebooting your sleep and this is the first step.

**Here are the general rules for getting up at the same time every morning**:
- Don't sleep in for more than an hour after your regular wake-up time (aim for the same time every morning)
- If it's been a real tough night and you're still tired by the afternoon, grab a 20-minute nap! (squeeze it in before 2pm)
- If possible, grant yourself an easy day and clear out major responsibilities if you're running on hardly any sleep!
- Trust your body (a.k.a. sleep homeostat) to grant you extra restorative sleep as you recover during the week.

recJbEoY4vp9vndSu.Name: QuickwinFA 11.1
recJbEoY4vp9vndSu.Bottom Body:
Its that time again! Time for another Quick Win!

This next one is great for relaxation and can help you** fall asleep faster**!

If you thrive on organization, this is the Quick Win for you!

What is it?

recJfIBLC9sbCKeC0.Name: action 2.2
recJfIBLC9sbCKeC0.Bottom Body:
We're confident that you're getting the hang of waking up at the same time every morning. 

Now we have another addition add to your plan:

2\. **UNPLUG AND DECOMPRESS BEFORE BEDTIME**

recJjcNXbBkPkYtsL.Name: Quickwin 14.2
recJjcNXbBkPkYtsL.Bottom Body:
**Setting your bedtime!**

You thought youd get to escape bedtimes in adulthood? WRONG!

Your body loves a schedule. If you want to boost your sleep, improve your metabolism, and help basically every other bodily process  youll learn to stick with a schedule.

Strategically setting a bedtime can do wonders for building a healthier sleep-wake cycle and overall sleep quality!

recJpQndq015YuutZ.Name: restructure 4.1
recJpQndq015YuutZ.Bottom Body:
It's time to practice some more cognitive restructuring! 

As a reminder, cognitive restructuring is when you play rational scientists to your dramatic/exaggerated/doom-filled thoughts 

Here are some examples of the types of thoughts that could use some restructuring: 

For instance, if you find yourself forecasting the future with a thought like:  "I just know I'm not going to be able to sleep tonight"

You can try rephrasing it in a way that's less stressful and more based on logic, like: "I have had trouble sleeping in the past, it may or may not be a reality for me tonight"

recJuPwyDOxZ9WigL.Name: CheckIn 1.4
recJuPwyDOxZ9WigL.Bottom Body:
Ok, that's it! We toooold you it would be quick!

Now, let's learn more about you and your needs!

recJwjBo9AVjNsfRt.Name: restructure 4.4
recJwjBo9AVjNsfRt.Bottom Body:
Great work! 

Learning how to minimize the impact of stressful thought patterns will help reduce your overall stress load and your frustrations around sleep (and other things). 

Learning how to play logical scientists with your thoughts is an incredibly useful skill! 

Great job and keep going! You can practice these any time on your own. We encourage it.

recK2DggCpXs3joBn.Name: checkin 4.7
recK2DggCpXs3joBn.Bottom Body:
Thanks for answering that! Remember, if you want any encouragement or tips, be sure to hit up your sleep coach. 

We'll be building on your action plan this week to make sure you keep improving your sleep as you complete each journey! By the end of this week you'll likely begin to notice a significant difference in your quality of sleep if you've stuck with the plan.

If you're still struggling to make changes, that's ok. We're here to support you every step along the way. 

Great work so far! You're really dedicated to making some changes and it shows.

recK6Lb5AKFoXCSnQ.Name: Science 1.2
recK6Lb5AKFoXCSnQ.Bottom Body:
Your sleep architecture can help you understand why you feel more rested some mornings compared to others.

Substances like caffeine and alcohol can negatively impact your sleep architecture while activities like exercise can improve it!

By learning how to optimize your sleep, you can improve your sleep architecture and gain incredible sleep benefits.

But, like, what is sleep architecture?

recKGnPDnzITQrWR8.Name: Supplements 1.3
recKGnPDnzITQrWR8.Bottom Body:
**The basic sleep supplements**
Not many people realize this, but many common vitamins and mineral deficiencies can reduce your quality of sleep and make it more difficult to fall asleep!

These supplements cover the most common vitamin or mineral deficiencies associated with sleep problems:

- **Vitamin D:** Vitamin D deficiency can seriously interrupt sleep and **over 40% of us are deficient in the sunshine vitamin**. Getting 600 to 800 IU daily can help with that.

- **Multivitamin:** A daily multivitamin covers your recommended intake for a variety of vitamins and minerals that can help sleep.

- **Iron:** Iron deficiency can be disruptive to sleep and increase anxiety and restless leg syndrome. Have your levels checked and supplement as needed to improve your sleep.

- **Magnesium:** Low magnesium can result in insomnia, restless sleep, frequent waking, and anxiety. **Around 50% of people dont get enough magnesium**. Try taking 500 to 800 mg daily of magnesium glycinate. Many people find it helpful to take right before bed as it can aid in relaxation and stress relief.

recKL0GUqYYT9u7gj.Name: Sleepdrive 1.2
recKL0GUqYYT9u7gj.Bottom Body:
Adenosine is an **inhibitory neurotransmitter.**

**A what, now?** It basically just means that this brain chemical is responsible for **slowing things down.**

The more adenosine, the sleepier you will feel.

After 12-16 hours of being awake, adenosine levels peak and you might start to notice the sleepy effects, such as finding yourself yawning a lot and maybe even starting to nod off if youve really built up a lot of sleep pressure.

Adenosine will continue to accumulate until you succumb to sleep, where it will then become cleared from your body and the process will start all over again the next day!

recKM2RS39rjzEU0V.Name: QuickwinFA 13.1
recKM2RS39rjzEU0V.Bottom Body:
Are you ready for another quick win?

Not only can this one improve your sleep, but you can do it anytime and anywhere!

PLUS it can help you **fall asleep faster! **Winning!

Lets find out what this quick win is...

recKNrwFwo5NXUDZA.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.3
recKNrwFwo5NXUDZA.Bottom Body:
**Choosing sheets**

The first rule of bedsheets is: **Higher thread count doesnt mean higher quality.**

**Wait, what?**

Heres the truth  thread counts above 500 often lead to changes in fibers that resemble synthetic fibers. This means that the natural qualities of the fibers get lost in production.

While it may feel silky smooth, high thread count sheets may also hold moisture and be less helpful for temperature control.

Nobody enjoys night sweats.

So, save yourself some money and stick with natural fabrics! Youll gain the benefits of temperature control and moisture-wicking. You can use that extra money you saved to buy a silk pillowcase or a nice eye mask.

**Lets look at how to pick your natural sheets...**

recKiouGQLs9PQlMb.Name: general 1.2
recKiouGQLs9PQlMb.Bottom Body:
**1. Mental decompression routine**

Mental decompression is an essential need if you want to live a better life. You can choose a number of ways to decompress  exercise, yoga, meditation, journaling, and more. It's important to choose something you enjoy doing. 

**When to decompress**
You can use mental decompression techniques any time of day, but they are especially effective at the end of the day. That's when your mind is tired and the stress of the day is sitting on your shoulders. 

We suggest that you take 10 to 20 minutes before your bedtime to wind down from your day.

You can choose whatever technique you like, today we'll talk to you about one powerful (and fun) technique...

recKnou0mercVYlwF.Name: meditation 1.5
recKnou0mercVYlwF.Bottom Body:
**A meditation practice**

In order to get the snooze-inducing benefits of meditation, you don't necessarily need to do it before sleep. The important thing is to find a time that works for you and stick with it. 

If you are just starting out, even just 1 minute a day will help you build that meditation muscle and gain benefits. 1 minute of mindfulness is better than 0 minutes of mindfulness!

Most studies show that people gain the widespread benefits of meditation by practicing as little as 10 minutes a day for 4 weeks. 

**Get started**
There are multiple free and paid apps that offer meditation tracks or timers. Reach out to your sleep coach for some recommendations!

recKpUZlM4SzLXIY1.Name: goalsleepschedule1.2
recKpUZlM4SzLXIY1.Top Body:
**1. Get alarmed**  

Alarms aren't just for mornings anymore. In order to help you stay regimented, set an alarm for your evening winddown hour. Many smartphones have this feature built-in!

When your evening alarm goes off, it's time to drop all activities and begin your bedtime routine. Try some meditation, journaling, and a relaxing skincare regimen. 

**As for morning?** Put your alarm away from your bed so you can't reach snooze. It's simple, but it works!

recKqZ3Bji9QFS4X2.Name: Orientation 2.3
recKqZ3Bji9QFS4X2.Bottom Body:
**Your life vs your sleep**
Well focus on important aspects of your life that significantly affect sleep and how to level up.

Were also going to introduce you to the best ways to track and measure your sleep using wearables or a sleep diary! This will help you build that accountability muscle.

Well also give you more tips on how to strengthen your relationship between your bedroom + sleep. Its gonna be a fun time!

recKqrqUd2kM2XPnq.Name: restructure 4.2
recKqrqUd2kM2XPnq.Bottom Body:
**As a reminder, here are the steps**:

**Step 1**: **Identify the though**t- e.g. "I'm going to lose my job if I can't sleep"

**Step 2**: **List evidence for or against it**-
Evidence for: Losing sleep can make it difficult to function optimally and interfere with work quality
Evidence against: I don't have to perform 100% all the time and my body is resilient in the face of sleep deprivation.

**Step 3: Reframing the thought**- "If I don't sleep well tomorrow may feel more difficult for some tasks but I'll still be able to work hard on what I can do well"

Let's try one...

recKwuTJ3vSyveH41.Name: QuickwinFA 9.3
recKwuTJ3vSyveH41.Bottom Body:
**How to do positive affirmations for sleep**
Once youve completed your bedtime routine and cozied up in bed, try doing positive affirmations before you intend to drift off.

Choose one affirmation that resonates with you and repeat it 10 times. You can keep track by dropping fingers as you say them.

Dont rush through them, say them with intention and try to really believe the words. You can say them out loud or in your head.

**Lets take a look at some sample affirmations for sleep...**

recL3HNqr4QP1oQdM.Name: sleepmyths 2.5
recL3HNqr4QP1oQdM.Bottom Body:
**Awareness is power**
Understanding the truth about common sleep myths and misperceptions is an important part of your sleep journey. 

Many people have a complicated relationship with sleep which can contribute to sleep problems.

Learning a little more about the mechanisms of sleep, what "good sleep" means, and how to discern fact from fiction is vital as you reboot your relationship with sleep. 

Sleep doesn't have to be so complicated. 

Let's get Rested!

recL6b8NQO3tfKb79.Name: sleepstages 1.3
recL6b8NQO3tfKb79.Bottom Body:
**Consequences of disruptions during each stage of sleep**

- **During stages 1 or 2: **You are still in a light enough sleep phase that you can move in and out of sleep fairly easily without causing health consequences. However, frequent or long disruptions make it harder to pass into the restorative phases of sleep. 

- **During stage 3:** In addition to feeling super groggy and overall crappy when waking up during this stage, your body could miss out on the important repairing and strengthening that would otherwise occur in your muscles, tissues, and immune system.

- **During REM sleep: **It is easier to be woken up during this stage of sleep but that doesnt mean it is any easier on your body. Missing out on REM sleep can lead to serious emotional consequences, such as **self-esteem issues and mood disorders. **REM sleep is also important for memory reconsolidation so missing out on this portion of sleep can make it difficult to form long-term memories. Although, one perk of being woken from REM sleep is that youre more likely to remember your dreams!

recL7dbm7YlvyfueH.Name: Importance 1.4
recL7dbm7YlvyfueH.Bottom Body:
**Space concerns**
Not everyone can restrict their bedrooms to just sleep. You may have a studio apartment, a bedroom office, or some other constraint that limits you from banning all non-sleep activities.

**Good news!**
Your Rested Health sleep pals to the rescue! We have tips and tricks for any problem that comes your way!

In the case of limited space in your living area, we have a couple of suggestions to separate life from bed:
- Stop activity a few hours before bedtime
- Change your environment at bedtime, such as covering screens with blankets (this creates a cue for your brain that the activity has ended)

Clearly separating non-sleep activities from sleep is an essential step in optimizing your sleep environment and allowing your brain to wind down for slumber!

recLEc0UjKeFAe2T2.Name: QuickwinFA 1.3
recLEc0UjKeFAe2T2.Bottom Body:
**Quick win of the day**

Did you know that taking a warm shower or bath one hour before bed can help you fall asleep up to 36% faster? It's true! 

But why? Your body sleeps better when it's cool. Believe it or not, a warm shower or bath actually cools your core temperature, making ideal conditions for sleep!

ummmm, wait, what? how?

recLIPdaEATpplgYs.Name: wakingup 1.1
recLIPdaEATpplgYs.Bottom Body:
**Awakenings during the night can often be very distressing**. 

If you regularly find yourself waking up in the middle of the night feeling stressed, it's possible that you haven't found an effective way to decompress before bed. 

However, in order to fix this problem, we also need to address what you do when you wake up in the middle of the night. 

So, the action plan to handle "waking up in the middle of the night stressed" is:
1. **Mental decompression routine**
2. **Hygge space** 

Let's look at how to execute each plan!

recLNWhmqHTpifYKG.Name: Noise 1.4
recLNWhmqHTpifYKG.Bottom Body:
**Have ear plugs handy!**

A great way to cancel out all environmental noise, ear plugs are inexpensive and take up very little space!

You can keep them right in your nightstand!

Ear plugs may not be your thing, but we have another option!

recLYRuPadMmWeua8.Name: Quickwin 12.1
recLYRuPadMmWeua8.Bottom Body:
Quick Win time!

Let's get back to food that helps you sleep better. We're really into food this week. 

For this quick win, lets take a look at some sleep-inducing snacks with tryptophan...

recLYtD4TuX1BI43M.Name: models 1.1
recLYtD4TuX1BI43M.Bottom Body:
Remember when we said we wanted to show you how to achieve **mastery over your sleep habits**? We're serious.

In order to become a master sleeper, it will take some time, work, and practice.

Before we roll up our sleeves and begin all of that hard work, let's take a look at how we master new skills and habits! 

This will help you better manage your expectations and be kinder to yourself as you implement new habits and changes.

recLccNZXTBfO5yNw.Name: Sleepdrive 1.3
recLccNZXTBfO5yNw.Bottom Body:
You may be wondering _if sleep pressure increases all day, why dont I feel tired all day long?_ and yes, we have the answer for that too!

Remember everything you learned about your circadian rhythm? Great! That info comes in real handy here.

Sleep relies on a two-process model. Your sleep drive is one process and your circadian rhythm is the other (like a dynamic duo of sleep!)

One of the functions of your circadian rhythm is your _circadian alerting system._

recLg6WLrmeJQvyS5.Name: restructure 3.4
recLg6WLrmeJQvyS5.Bottom Body:
Great work! We'll keep practicing more of these. 

Learning how to minimize the impact of stressful thought patterns will help reduce your overall stress load and your frustrations around sleep. 

Learning how to play logical scientists with your thoughts is an incredibly useful skill! 

Great job and keep going!

recLlHYSWVXcqajei.Name: QuickwinFA 1.2
recLlHYSWVXcqajei.Bottom Body:
You can easily implement quick wins into your daily routine to help you sleep better, fall asleep faster, or just feel better. 

When you completed the first Rested Health survey, you indicated that you had trouble falling asleep. So, today we're going to give you a tip to help you out with that!

So, are you ready for today's quick win to help you fall asleep faster??

recLnIOeIBPB8lgGL.Name: spower 1.7
recLnIOeIBPB8lgGL.Bottom Body:
**Your body on sleep**
Sleep improves every area of functioning in your body.

**Sleep:**
- Boosts immune functioning
- Improves heart and vascular health
- Reduces pain and inflammation
- Boosts metabolism and regulates hunger (lack of sleep makes your hunger hormones soar)
- Improves your skin and aids in muscle repair
- Increases your lifespan

There's a reason you feel like a million bucks after a good night of sleep. We'll explore more the specific mechanisms of how quality sleep boosts your health later.

For now, just know that when we say that sleep is your superpower  we mean it!

recLo1Sgw4O4yU7nf.Name: cantsleep 1.5
recLo1Sgw4O4yU7nf.Bottom Body:
**The place**
Choose a quiet corner of your home, maybe even a closet! Make sure it's not in your bedroom.** **

**The set-up**
The most important aspect of your hygge space is something to sit or lay on and some blankets. You can use cushions, memory foam, a comfy chair, or even a mattress. You can have fun, just make sure you surround yourself with things that feel cozy.

**The activities**
Keep phones out of the hygge space and equip it with relaxing activities like reading or music. 

You can then add in your other supplies such as:
- A warmly scented candle,
- Good books
- Fairy lights
- Night lights
- Puzzles
- Coloring books

You can use your hygge space any time you want to relax and it serves as an excellent action plan for leaving your bedroom and relaxing on nights you can't sleep!

Ok, now that you have somewhere to go, let's look at what to do and when to return to bed...

recM9PJHxUObqPmpA.Name: action 2.4
recM9PJHxUObqPmpA.Bottom Body:
**In summary:**

This week you have two action items that will help you move toward rebooting your relationship with sleep:

1. **Wakeup at the same time every morning**
2. **Unplug and decompress before bedtime**

Do your best to implement these changes this week. We'll be checking in to see how it's going! If you have any questions or want some alternative decompression techniques, feel free to message your sleep coach! They are always there for support or guidance.

recMBTcTNObMPCHsy.Name: Orientation 1.1
recMBTcTNObMPCHsy.Bottom Body:
It's Reboot Camp orientation time! We are so excited to teach you more about how to **master your sleep**.

You are now officially up to speed on all of the sleep language we'll be using.  

You've also leveled up your general sleep knowledge. 

All of these sleep smarts you've gained will not only make you excellent at sleep trivia, but they'll also help you understand why we use certain approaches to improve your sleep!

Each week of Reboot camp will build up your base of sleep knowledge and help you gain mastery over each element of good sleep.

recMBqyi14hmp3FkZ.Name: Goals 1.4
recMBqyi14hmp3FkZ.Bottom Body: The more you practice, the more natural it becomes to set SMART goals.
recMBqyi14hmp3FkZ.Top Body:
**Choosing SMART goals that you can work on each week will bring you closer to your overall goal!**

Whether it's putting your phone away 2 hours before bed, not watching TV in bed, or maybe it's getting up at the same time every day  SMART goals will help you get there.

**Get SMART**
Think of a SMART goal right now. If you're feeling dramatic  use a tube of lipstick to write it on your mirror.  Otherwise, write it here!

**Remember: Specific, Measurable, Relevant, Timely**

recMDWwHo9mweBvja.Name: Why  1.6
recMDWwHo9mweBvja.Bottom Body:
What we want you to understand is:
- **It's normal to feel stressed when you can't sleep**
- **Your brain is often dramatic about its essential needs**
- **Gaining some mastery over your sleep will help you feel** **more empowered in every area of your daily functioning!**

Sounds worth the effort, right? We want you to meet the best version of yourself. 

Dedicating your time and efforts to this program will not only help you gain the benefits of better sleep, but it will also make you stronger psychologically. 

It's bicep curls for your brain (brainceps curls?) 

It's brain day every day.

You can absolutely learn how to work with your body's natural rhythms and take back control of your sleep.

recMFMRzYk771F3jJ.Name: Grogginess 1.1
recMFMRzYk771F3jJ.Bottom Body:
So youve got the groggies. Were not sure if thats a real word but were sticking with it.

Feeling groggy, tired, or low energy sucks.

Whether its due to missed sleep, disrupted sleep, or its out of the blue  there is plenty you can do to still have a good day despite feeling low energy!

But, first of all, lets take a closer look at the source of those groggy feelings...

recMKDmsYzLglC1tE.Name: snoring 1.1
recMKDmsYzLglC1tE.Bottom Body:
**Snoring and sleep**

It's estimated that nearly 50% of all adults snore occasionally and 25% snore regularly. 

**Is snoring a big deal?** It can be! 

Snoring can be a sign of a serious sleep disorder called sleep apnea. You can see if you may be at risk by [taking this quiz](https://www.mdcalc.com/stop-bang-score-obstructive-sleep-apnea). Always talk to your doctor if you feel like you may be experiencing sleep apnea!

Snoring alone can also be a major sleep disruptor. That chainsaw running in the back of your throat as you sleep can cause micro-awakenings during sleep. This results in disruption of sleep cycles and reduced overall sleep time for both you and your sleep partner. 

In fact, snoring can result in around 20 awakenings per hour of sleep! Not exactly ideal.

recMPJWdRDpT6hXUt.Name: Sleepstability 1.1
recMPJWdRDpT6hXUt.Bottom Body:
Boosting your sleep stability means getting more out of your sleep. Since the health benefits of sleep are endless, it's worth investing some effort into these habits!

**How to boost sleep stability**
1. **Get Regular**
2. **Stimulus control**
3. **Move it**
4. **Add noise**

By optimizing your sleep schedule, working with your body's natural rhythms, and implementing sleep-enhancing strategies, you can reap the many benefits that good sleep has to offer.

Let's take a closer look...

recMPmNHtqOsKELO8.Name: Bedroom 1.5
recMPmNHtqOsKELO8.Bottom Body:
**KEEP YOUR ELECTRONICS OUT OF THE BEDROOM!**

You should avoid having any electronics in your bedroom, if possible, to avoid blue light exposure before bedtime.

Make the decision today that your bedroom is for sleep (or sex) only and keep your electronics in another room!

If you absolutely cant avoid it, try using dark tape or other coverings over digital lights at night.

**Can having electronics in your room really be that bad?**

Yes, lets find out how.

recMVwNAtVT7VvQrC.Name: Wokeuptired 1.4
recMVwNAtVT7VvQrC.Bottom Body:
**3. Social jet lag**

We all know that jet lag sucks, but do you know about social jet lag?  We talked about this in week one! Social jet lag is the term used by sleep experts to describe the disruptions in your circadian rhythm that occur from differences in your sleeping patterns on weekdays vs the weekends.

It can take your body up to a week to catch up on one hour of missed sleep. This means that significant disruptions to your weekend schedule can actually leave you jet-lagged during the week. Depending on the disruptions, it can be the equivalent of traveling through multiple time zones.

**Fix it**
If you find yourself extra snoozy in the mornings, have a look at your weekend schedule and work on waking up at the same time every day.Try not to stretch your weekend wake-up time beyond an hour of your weekday wake-up time.

**TIP:** Stay up late? Waking up early and grabbing a nap in the afternoon is better than sleeping in!You may not feel at your best in the morning, but getting up and napping later will help keep your sleep system in check. 

It really likes consistency.

recMYoNtlZcbG4k5R.Name: sneaky 1.4
recMYoNtlZcbG4k5R.Bottom Body:
**Sneaky Caffeine**
Caffeine is not just in coffee. You also get a significant dose of caffeine in many teas, sodas, chocolates, and even over-the-counter headache medicine. 

Caffeine shows up as other ingredients like:
- Yerba mate
- Matcha
- Guarana
- Kola

**Easy on the stimulation**
Many over-the-counter diet pills, workout supplements, and energy drinks have huge doses of caffeine that will surely have sleep-disrupting side-effects.

**TIPS**:
- No caffeine after 2pm
- Limit intake to around 400mg/day 
- Read labels and go easy on evening sodas (especially diet sodas since they tend to have more caffeine)

It's possible to enjoy the perks of caffeine and also get good sleep. Keep an eye on your intake and make your evenings stimulation-free to optimize your sleep! 

Ok, on to the next one...

recMZQBJYrSvbBeP9.Name: mythBuster 1.1
recMZQBJYrSvbBeP9.Bottom Body:
There is a lot of misinformation out there about sleep. 

Unfortunately, a lot of these myths can lead to extra stress about your actual sleep needs and what quality sleep looks like!

We want to help you fully understand what good sleep means and what it doesn't. So, let's bust some myths!

This one is about dreaming.

recMdGQ8GNYa4DqoT.Name: Quickwin 8.1
recMdGQ8GNYa4DqoT.Bottom Body:

recMdrSa5myYlDggg.Name: Tracking 2.5
recMdrSa5myYlDggg.Bottom Body:
**It helps you track progress**

One of the most useful aspects of a sleep diary is that it helps you measure your progress. You can see which tips and techniques work for you to improve your sleep.

As you try to improve your sleep, a sleep diary can help you determine which things are working for you! 

Everyone is unique and so is their sleep.

recN9FImP1wo3oheX.Name: Bedroom 1.6
recN9FImP1wo3oheX.Bottom Body:
**No TV in bed!**

Did you know if youre falling asleep to your favorite tv show at night, then youre exposing your brain to blue light through the entire night?! If the sound is on youre disrupting your sleep even more.

Research has shown that even if you dont wake up, TV and environmental sounds through the night disrupt the quality of your sleep.

Additionally, depending on what you watch, the content can be stimulating or emotionally driven in a way that can make it hard to quiet your mind.

If you absolutely refuse to remove your TV, avoid watching it within an hour of bedtime as it can be disruptive to sleep quality. We highly suggest you remove it, though. Please remove it?

recNBFtZwTKnjWmbL.Name: Decompression 1.5
recNBFtZwTKnjWmbL.Bottom Body:
**Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR)**

Research has found that PMR increases your levels of mental quiet and joy. It can even help reduce pain!

PMR is perfect for mental decompression and can teach your body to fall asleep quicker!

There are plenty of guided tracks available. 

**You can start simply by following these steps:**

1. Lay comfortably in bed with your eyes closed
2. Beginning with your face  tense each muscle group as you breathe in then release the muscle group as you breathe out
3. Work your way down your body, tensing and relaxing each muscle group

This simple technique counteracts your flight-or-flight response which lowers physiological stress! In other words, it sends signals to your brain that it's "relax time."

You can do it anywhere and any time you want your body to relax.

recNE6RH6vMUvpa4Y.Name: Architecture 1.2
recNE6RH6vMUvpa4Y.Bottom Body:
**Stages on stages**
During the night you move through several stages of sleep. These stages each have specific benefits and unique qualities. Your sleep architecture is your pattern of sleep stages across the night.

Stages 1 and 2 include lighter sleep while stage 3 includes deep restorative sleep. REM sleep is primarily when you dream, and you spend more time dreaming in the second half of the night.

We'll learn more about sleep stages in week 3.

For now, let's look at what "good sleep architecture" looks like...

recNE9equqXjizwiK.Name: QuickwinFA4.4
recNE9equqXjizwiK.Bottom Body:
**Boosting your melatonin the natural way**
Your body starts producing melatonin around 2 hours before bedtime, so dimming the lights during that time period and using a red lightbulb beside your bed are excellent techniques to optimize this process. 

Check out this [article](https://intercom.help/rested-health/en/articles/5187543-how-to-naturally-boost-melatonin) for more tips on how to boost your melatonin levels naturally. 

See? You'll be falling asleep faster in no time.

recNGoFUzRsS6wz1o.Name: general 1.5
recNGoFUzRsS6wz1o.Bottom Body:
**2. Managing stress in the moment**
Learning how to effectively calm your body when you feel stressed or overwhelmed is extremely valuable. There are many techniques and tools! Let's look at an awesome and effective one!

**The 333 rule**
Whenever you find yourself caught up in stressful thoughts, irritability or feeling overwhelmed  use the 333 rule. 

You can use your imagination if you're in bed, or use your surrounding if out of bed.

Here's how it works: 

**Step 1:** Look around you and name three things you see

**Step 2:** Look around you and name three sounds you hear

**Step 3:** One at a time, move three parts of your body (such as your ankle, fingers, or arm). 

This technique will help center you and pull you out of any unhelpful thought patterns!

recNLzVPCPaK2AqgG.Name: restructure 3.1
recNLzVPCPaK2AqgG.Bottom Body:
It's time to practice some more cognitive restructuring! 

As a reminder, cognitive restructuring is when you play rational scientists to your dramatic/exaggerated/doom-filled thoughts 

Here are some examples of the types of thoughts that could use some restructuring: 

For instance, if you find yourself forecasting the future with a thought like:  "I just know I'm not going to be able to sleep tonight"

You can try rephrasing it in a way that's less stressful and more based on logic, like: "I have had trouble sleeping in the past, it may or may not be a reality for me tonight"

Pull that one out at your next family gathering!

**Your brain on sleep**
Good sleep boosts your productivity, can help ward off cognitive diseases like dementia, and improves your memory and creative thinking. 

See? We told you sleep was great for your mind. Now, let's look at sleep and mood!

recNt0ec7E7vtb4sX.Name: meditation 1.4
recNt0ec7E7vtb4sX.Bottom Body:
**Improved brain function**

Meditating is very healthy for your brain and has even shown to be neuroprotective. Regular meditation can repair the brain and improve brain structure, function, and connectivity. This enhances overall function and can help prevent diseases and age-related decline. 

Researchers have recently found that meditation can also boost anti-aging hormones that promote longevity. People who engage in regular meditation practices were found to have higher levels of growth hormone and DHEA. These hormones are responsible for essential processes like heart health, tissue repair, immunity, muscle building, and bone density. 

Overall, meditation has been proven to make your brain healthier, younger, more resilient, and better at sleep!

**Now, how to do it for sleep...**

recNwiG3sOEbWhHa8.Name: sleepmyths 1.3
recNwiG3sOEbWhHa8.Bottom Body:
**2. SLEEP QUALITY**

How do you determine whether you've had a good night of rest? Unless you're in a sleep lab, it can be pretty tricky to accurately gauge how well you slept. 

Here are things that **DO NOT** determine how well you slept:
- **Dreams:** Many people think that if they remember a lot of dreams that means they slept well. This is not true at all! Due to changing levels of chemicals called acetylcholine and norepinephrine, your brain forgets dreams.  In general, you only remember dreams if you were awoken from them or if they had highly emotional content. 
- **Hours:** Sleeping longer isn't always better. Six high-quality hours of sleep is better than ten poor quality hours. Your body prefers consistency in your sleep schedule. 
- **Sleeping like a log:** People assume if they move during the night or have awakenings that they aren't getting good sleep. Moving during the night and waking up is normal! You can have awakenings and movement and still get a great night of rest.

recNwta5exf7cYsoe.Name: QuickWinFA 10.2
recNwta5exf7cYsoe.Bottom Body:
**Paradoxical intention**

This tip is going to sound kind of funny, but it works. Believe it or not, for many people, telling yourself to stay awake can actually cause you to fall asleep faster!

**What? How? Why?**
Trying to sleep can increase anxiety. It also leads to subconscious sleep stress which can make the problem worsen.

If you are regularly stressed out about falling asleep, worried about the consequences of sleep loss, or "striving for sleep"   trying to stay awake may be your ticket to falling asleep faster!

**How do I do it?**

**The dream team (quite literally)**
The combination of deep breathing plus a soothing mantra is an extremely powerful way to quiet a busy mind before bed. 

We'll give you a lot of other ways to calm a busy mind before sleep. You should definitely try this one out next time this is a problem and see how well it works for you.

**Picking those sheets**

Try **cotton, silk, or bamboo** fabrics. They are excellent for temperature control.

If you want to indulge a little, go with an **Egyptian cotton or pima cotton** which are combed with precision to remove all impurities. A sateen finish is often preferred due to its smooth feel on the skin.

If you live somewhere with seasons you may want to have specific sheets for each season. Try a jersey sheet in winter and a lighter sheet for summer.

**Sheets to avoid**: Stay away from synthetics fabrics like polyester, which trap heat and can leave you feeling hot and sweaty at night.

Unfortunately, many prescriptions and over-the-counter medications are overused. They are meant as short-term solutions due to the fact most are habit-forming and can **reduce the quality of your sleep**. recOP0T1Wyo5E6hSs.Name: basics 1.4
recOP0T1Wyo5E6hSs.Bottom Body:
**3. Sleep Architecture.**

In order to understand "optimal sleep" it helps to to have a brief understanding of how your sleep is structured! 

In the same way that architecture describes the design and construction of buildings, **sleep architecture describes how our sleep is designed and built.**

During the night you move through several stages of sleep. These stages each have specific benefits and unique qualities.

Your sleep architecture is your pattern of sleep stages across the night (and ironically enough, it looks like a city skyline).

**Building better sleep**
Certain habits and activities during the day can impact your sleep architecture in different ways. This is often why sometimes you feel more or less Rested with the same amount of sleep!

The only accurate way to measure sleep architecture is in a sleep study. However, some wearable devices can give a general estimate of sleep stages.

**2. Leave the bed when you cant sleep**

This is another tip well repeat because it deserves repetition. If you are laying in bed trying to sleep and its been longer than 20 minutes  leave the bed!

**Why?** Because by laying in bed feeling alert and building mounting frustration over your inability to sleep, you are building unhelpful associations between your bed and those feelings.

**Where do you go?** Ideally, go somewhere that you can relax and do something boring. You can head to your living room, a cozy nook, or any room other than your bedroom.

The important thing is to just get out of bed!

**But, follow these guidelines...**

recOygMFuorWUzXg1.Name: Sleep Basics 101 Overview 1.3
recOygMFuorWUzXg1.Bottom Body:
Your circadian rhythm works closely with your sleep drive (the dynamic duo of your sleep!) to keep your sleep-wake cycle at its healthiest!

Your sleep drive is your bodys need for sleep.

Adenosine is a brain chemical that builds all day while youre awake and creates **sleep pressure.**

Your sleep pressure will peak after 12-16 hours of being awake, and it will cause you to feel uncontrollably sleepy.
