One of the biggest challenges of taking back control of your sleep is dealing with negative and activating thoughts at night or when trying to sleep. 

However, even stressful reactions in the daytime can lead to an activation of your stress system that makes finding sleep more difficult. 

Therefore, learning how to deal with your inflammatory, irrational, or exaggerated thoughts can significantly reduce your stress and improve your relationship with sleep.

Remove the clutter and you remove the chaos.

Making your bed first thing in the morning will help you induce immediate unconscious relaxation when you step into your bedroom at the end of the day!

recPIafo1a16hwRk8.Name: Tracking 1.7
recPIafo1a16hwRk8.Bottom Body:
**Wrist wearables**

They use sensors to detect physiological responses like heart rate, body temperature, and movement.

Studies show that trackers worn on the wrist are most accurate when used in controlled environments (like in bed sleeping). Wrist trackers also provide valuable information about daily activity and fitness levels that can influence sleep.

**Popular types of wrist wearables:**
- **Smart Watches** (Apple, Samsung Galaxy, Fitbit Versa)
- **Activity Trackers** (Fitbit, Amazfit, Garmin, Whoop)

**Pros**: Easy to wear with many affordable options available.

recPMzH6Y4RIcx1Qh.Name: change 1.5
recPMzH6Y4RIcx1Qh.Bottom Body:
**3. Consistency**

Remember when you learned all about conditioning and how we are very much still animals? Keep that in mind. 

One of the most common reasons people fail to reach their goals is because they lack consistency. In order to make a new skill or habit become automatic, you need to practice. 

**Motivation vs discipline**
One of the most important tidbits of advice we want you to swallow is that you **shouldn't always depend on motivation**. 

While motivation is essential for mustering up the desire to change, it's not what carries you over the finish line. 

**So, like, what carries me over the finish line?** 
Discipline and consistency! The cold hard truth about behaviour change is that it takes hard work and sometimes the motivation simply isn't there. Be consistent and constantly ask yourself:

**"Does this activity bring me closer to my goals?"**

When you sleep, your brain takes that time to recharge. When you dont get enough sleep, your neurons actually get tired too! They fire more slowly, leading to poor concentration, slower reaction times, irritability, and can affect your balance and coordination

**Other causes of low energy**

Low energy can also be a result of vitamin or mineral deficiencies, depression, stress overload, allergies, or various other factors.

So, now we know why you feel bad, but how can you fix it?

But, what does this have to do with your electronics?

recQFBOB7rpAWZ6ae.Name: week 2.5

**Sneaky sleep disruptors**

In order to set you up for success, we want to make sure you have all of the knowledge about common sleep disruptors! In this section, we'll cover substances and activities that can impede sleep.

Why? Because awareness is power! We don't expect you to ever be "perfect" but knowing how certain substances affect your body can be very helpful in making informed decisions.

recQLKgn9YAwan7wy.Name: Tracking 1.2
recQLKgn9YAwan7wy.Bottom Body:
**Benefits of wearables**
Wearables have cool features that give you interesting information about your sleep (and health). Some of them even allow you to set smart alarms that wake you up when your sleep is the lightest! 

**Use with caution**
Wearables arent meant as diagnostic tools, but they will give you a general idea of your sleep patterns.

**Sleep trackers arent for everyone** and thats ok. If tracking your sleep causes more stress than benefits, you can scrap it!

recQRDZvsdgXLZmzX.Name: Mornings 1.7
recQRDZvsdgXLZmzX.Bottom Body:
Whats the best way to get fresh air and sunshine?

**Walk it out!**

Grab your pet, spouse, or your headphones and head on out for a morning walk. Breathe in that fresh morning air, and as a bonus, youll be getting some of that wonderful mood-boosting sunlight, too!

These might sound like basic tips, but they work. Even just getting out in the sun three times a week can give you a boost to your mood and sleep.

See? Morning can be pretty nice.

Well get into some more advanced techniques later. For now, remember:

1. **Grab a glass of water when you wake up**
2. **Get some morning sunshine**

Start out with these tips and begin building yourself a little morning ritual that brings you some health and joy.

recQZ5MOZXJn0bgup.Name: Needs 1.2
recQZ5MOZXJn0bgup.Bottom Body:
**Some important reminders for you:** 
- The number of hours you get each night can vary
- Quality over quantity
- It's normal to have multiple awakenings during the night
- Sleep is never perfect
- You won't die from missing out on sleep

**Awareness is power**
Understanding that sleep is never perfect will help you better cope with those times when you aren't getting your ideal sleep.

Taking control of your sleep doesn't mean getting perfect sleep every night. Nobody sleeps that well! (ok, maaaaaybe Sleeping Beauty did, but she wasn't exactly productive).

recQZwaBcrN9tnM0d.Name: general 1.4
recQZwaBcrN9tnM0d.Bottom Body:
**Visualization for stress relief**

You can pick any setting you want. Here's an example of visualizing a relaxing time at a beach.

**Step 1:** Sit or lay in a comfortable position and close your eyes

**Step 2:** relax the muscles in your face and take a deep breath in through your nose and out through your mouth

**Step 3:** Imagine you are resting on a white sandy beach. You can hear the waves gently rolling and you can feel the warm sun on your face. Visualize the turquoise water. Smell the sweet salty air. Feel the gentle breeze across your skin. Listen to the gentle crash as the waves reach the shore. 

Allow your breath to slow and match the rolling waves. Stay as long as you like. 

**Ahhhh that was nice.** 

Now let's look at a quick stress relief technique for when you're in the moment with stress!

recQhmhQ48NQQZAGI.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.2
recQhmhQ48NQQZAGI.Bottom Body:
**Lets spend some time in the SHEETS!**

Heh heh

There is no better feeling in the world than climbing into fresh sheets at the end of a long day, right?

But, did you know that your sheets can impact your sleep?

The quality of your sheets can actually have a big impact on how well you sleep. Dont worry, expensive isnt always better.

Lets look at some guidelines to follow when choosing the material youll spend a third of your life in...

recQmfXStuxAVvOPV.Name: Lighting 1.2
recQmfXStuxAVvOPV.Bottom Body:
**Dim lights one hour before bedtime!**

About one hour before youd like to be sleeping you should make an effort to use dimmed lighting to help induce relaxation. In an ideal world youd dim them at two hours before sleep (thats when your body starts pumping melatonin). To get started, one hour is enough.

**How to dim them**
That could mean installing dimmer switches where possible or just using lamp light with 40 watt light bulbs instead of turning on overhead lights.

This will help better ready your body for sleep and itll even make things more cozy!

See, thats such an easy tip that you can start doing tonight!

Want another one?

recQncHtRlTd5skgM.Name: alcoholSleep 1.4
recQncHtRlTd5skgM.Bottom Body:
**2. Alcohol and Adenosine**
Another way alcohol helps us feel sleepy is due to its action on adenosine. Adenosine is a chemical in the body that helps to regulate sleep (remember sleep drive?).

Consuming alcohol boosts levels of adenosine which then blocks cells in an area of your brain called the basal forebrain (this area promotes wakefulness). 

**The result?** This leads to increased initial sleepiness but also disrupts homeostasis, which reduces the quality of your sleep and can increase your risk of sleep disorders.

recQsJPVlgie7fUgA.Name: worry 1.2
recQsJPVlgie7fUgA.Bottom Body:
**Your subconscious mind**
Before we talk about subconscious sleep stress, let's talk about your subconscious mind! 

Your subconscious mind controls about 99% of your actions and interpretations during the day. It is 100% in control during sleep.

**What does my subconscious mind do?**

Similar to a computer, your subconscious mind creates programs for how your body should behave in certain situations.From stopping at red lights to smiling at cute dogs, it's got a program for everything. 

You build these programs from interacting with your world, repeating certain habits or activities, and learning new skills.

recQyyigJIOTrUXgE.Name: week 4.2
recQyyigJIOTrUXgE.Bottom Body:
**Find your (circadian) rhythm**

You've already learned what a circadian rhythm does, in this section we'll take a closer look at how to tell if your circadian rhythm is off and what you can do to optimize it!

Learn how to identify the symptoms of a misaligned rhythm, use cues from your environment to get your body on track, and feel what it's like to find your rhythm.

recR3adJaYYcYTKND.Name: quickwin 3.4
recR3adJaYYcYTKND.Bottom Body:
Try and combine a new habit this week with an existing one. It may take some trial and error to see what works, but, habit-stacking is an excellent technique to set yourself up for success. 

Awesome! Let's get on to our next journey!

recR3t4A43QRBrrMJ.Name: change 1.6
recR3t4A43QRBrrMJ.Bottom Body:
**4. Accountability/Support**

The final roadblock that many people face is a lack of accountability or support. 

In order to get to where you want to be it requires tracking your progress and getting the support you need. 

Tracking is essential for evaluating your goals and making adjustments and changes as needed. Support gives those little boosts you need along the way. 

**How do I get support and accountability?**
Support can come in the form of family, social networks, and professional support systems (like Rested Health). 

As for accountability? Write down your goals, track your progress, tell people about your changes, and lean into your support systems! 

We'll give you some more specific tips for tracking your sleep progress as well.

recR6AIx9G0CYdWxa.Name: actionplanweek2 2.7
recR6AIx9G0CYdWxa.Bottom Body:
Great! Thanks for answering those. 

You're just about done week 2, well done! We'll do a little summary and then you can begin week 3. 

Remember, you can always go at your own pace and revisit any section that you found helpful. This is all about YOU!

recRALvNXeME5tzal.Name: Intake
recRALvNXeME5tzal.Bottom Body:
In order to help you improve your sleep, we need to know a little bit more about your problems. 

**Help us help you**
The following questions will gather information about your sleep habits, goals, and things you've done in the past to improve your sleep.

Answer honestly! The purpose of the questions is to guide the sort of advice we give you. 

**Block a little time**
This journey may take around 3-5 minutes and will require you to answer some multiple choice questions. Come back later if this isn't a great time for that. 

Otherwise, let's get to know you better!

recRJ6Gh2pi4g1gK1.Name: caffeinesleep 1.5
recRJ6Gh2pi4g1gK1.Bottom Body:
**Rule #3**
**Moderation is key**

Research shows that the healthy caffeine limit for most adults is 250- 400 mg. That's about 3-4 cups of coffee. 

Get your caffeine fix in before 2 pm (or 6 hours before bed) to avoid the lingering anti-sleep effects of caffeine.

recRQMKnxrpFO0nqj.Name: general 1.6
recRQMKnxrpFO0nqj.Bottom Body:
Learning how to effectively manage stress will vastly improve your quality of life. 

To get started at kicking stress in the butt: Try implementing some visual or guided imagery into your nightly winddown routine and use the 333 method any time you find yourself feeling stressed or overwhelmed. 

Learning how to find calm in the midst of any storm will serve you greatly. You can do it. Your mind is a powerful tool. 

Ok, back to journeys!

recRUCFZsVBySVGz1.Name: Tracking 2.4
recRUCFZsVBySVGz1.Bottom Body:
**Youll get more proactive about your sleep**

A sleep diary not only creates awareness but also gives you a sense of accountability. 

Youll find that keeping a diary will naturally make you more diligent about engaging in behaviors that promote sleep.

**Ch-ch-ch-changes**
Logging behaviors leads to changes! For instance, if you got the absolute best sleep of your life the day you went on a long bike ride youll probably have more motivation to go on long bike rides. 

If watching crime documentaries before bed gave you nightmares you might skip that activity in the future.

WAIT THERES MORE!

recRUIElSw5ucoiLJ.Name: circrhythm 1.5
recRUIElSw5ucoiLJ.Bottom Body:
**It makes us alert close to bed **
Ever feel a second wind close to bedtime? Thats your circadian rhythm giving you one last energy boost before it sends you to sleep. This is why its easier to stay up late than it is to go to sleep earlier than usual.

**Why?** Historically, predators like lions and tigers were on the hunt close to our bedtimes. Our biological clocks still send alertness signals in the late evening to protect us from predators.

Now we just use it to fuel our trip to the snack cupboard...

**It gives you afternoon lulls**
Your energy levels have peaks and troughs throughout the day. You generally experience an energy boost in the morning and a lull in the late afternoon. This is why afternoon naps are so popular!

**Why?** Many animals are wired to have an energy peak in the morning and a lull in the late afternoon. This is when the day could typically get the hottest and everyones biology agreed that its best to just nap it out.

recRZbH9JJvKr0tNg.Name: week4summary 4.6
recRZbH9JJvKr0tNg.Bottom Body:
**5. Problem solving- feeling groggy/low energy**

- **The groggies**: Waking up feeling tired or groggy isn't fun. Understanding that sometimes it has to do with your quality of sleep or when you woke up during your sleep cycle and other times it has to do with factors beyond sleep (such as stress or illness). If you regularly wake up feeling unrested despite getting sleep, check with your doctor as this can be caused by many health conditions or vitamin and mineral deficiencies. 
- **Get energized:** You don't have to rely solely on stimulants to get you through the day when you feel tired. Try using positive self-talk (or faking it until you make it), filling yourself with delicious green foods, and maybe grabbing a little nap or stacking coffee with l-theanine. Sometimes you'll just have an off day, and that's ok too. We can't be 100% all of the time!

recRggLwYYovL12UL.Name: caffeinesleep 1.6
recRggLwYYovL12UL.Bottom Body:
There you have it! Your official guide to using caffeine AND getting good sleep. 

**As a recap:**

**Rule #1**: Don't consume caffeine within the first 90 minutes of waking up

**Rule #2:** Don't drink caffeine too late in the day

**Rule #3:** Moderation is key

**Helpful Tip:** Stack caffeine with L-Theanine

Remember to watch out for sneaky caffeine and do your best to limit your intake to around 400mg a day (that's around 3.5 cups)

recRhPISoxkd7uqQw.Name: Basics 1.2
recRhPISoxkd7uqQw.Bottom Body:
**1. Circadian Rhythm**

What is it? Its a biological clock! Similar to how you organize your daily schedule, your brain organizes your various bodily schedules with a biological clock.

Your biological clock has **24-hour cycle circadian rhythms** running in the background which regulate processes like hormone production, body temperature, metabolism, and your **sleep-wake cycle**.

So, like, all the good stuff. 

**Circadian rhythm and sleep**
Your circadian rhythm pumps out signals to your body that determine when you feel sleepy and when you feel alert. It is regulated by environmental cues called zeitgebers (its a German word that means time giver). 

Due to modern environments (i.e. constant light/noise/stimulation), our circadian rhythms are often negatively impacted  leading to sleep disruptions. 

**Learn your rhythm**
Learning how to optimize your body's natural rhythms is one of the most effective ways to improve the quality of sleep you get (along with a bunch of other health benefits). 

We'll show you how to use cues in your environment to get your circadian rhythm on track!

recRj0BVuCKN34x6d.Name: Day 1.1
recRj0BVuCKN34x6d.Bottom Body:
**Obstacles to Rebooting your sleep**

If you want to optimize your sleep, it's important to have a close look at some activities you do during the day that may be negatively impacting your slumber!

In week 4 we'll focus more on activities you can do during the day that will improve your sleep. Today it's all about the most common sleep disruptors and how to avoid them!

After all, you don't want to do all of this hard work just to have it ruined by a silly habit!

Let's get started with sneaky sleep disruptors...

recRrQDrqCurIUxFc.Name: wakingup 1.5
recRrQDrqCurIUxFc.Bottom Body:
**Getting Hygge with it**
Hygge (pronounced hue-guh) is the Danish and Norwegian word for coziness. In general, hygge refers to the concept of happiness and encompasses all things cozy and relaxing. 

We dont expect you to go completely hygge, but by borrowing from the concept, its possible to create a corner of your home that evokes hygge. Not only will this give you a space to relax, but it will also serve as an important refuge for you on sleepless nights.

**If you build it, sleep will come**
Select a section of your home (away from your bed) where you can retreat on sleepless nights. Equip it with cozy blankets, pillows, books, candles, fairy lights, and whatever else evokes relaxation and comfort. 

This is now your refuge of comfort when you need to leave your bed and relax. Once you feel sleepy again, simply head back to bed. If sleep still won't come? Back to hygge.

recRzFrYdbHFZngyN.Name: Quickwin 12.3
recRzFrYdbHFZngyN.Bottom Body:
Grabbing any of these snacks in the evening is a great way to fill your belly with healthy food and also improve your sleep. Eat them alone or combine them! Oatmeal and salmon anyone? (this isnt a recipe app, ok?)

You can also incorporate them as a part of a healthy lifestyle to optimize your bodys production of these important brain chemicals.

Food is connected to every body process, well be sure to flag all of the ones that can help you sleep!

recSJDRN28FG0nmzS.Name: week 4.4
recSJDRN28FG0nmzS.Bottom Body:
**Diet and sleep**

It's probably not a big surprise that diet can impact sleep, but you may be surprised to learn that you can eat your way to higher quality slumber.

Learn how the timing of meals, meal quality, and even supplements can harm or hinder your sleep. We'll even give you a few tips for some safe all-natural supplements that can help you fall asleep faster!

recSc5ceLybUaUDfr.Name: Why Rested 1.1
recSc5ceLybUaUDfr.Bottom Body:
It's possible that you've already tried a lot of things. We get it. We also want you to trust us when we say that this is different.

**How is this different?**
Sleep is our business. That means we've recruited the greatest minds in sleep to create a program unlike any other.

recSeOcBPwQtrOfeK.Name: meditation 1.2
recSeOcBPwQtrOfeK.Bottom Body:
**Decreased stress hormones and improved emotional resilience**

**Cortisol kicker**
You've already learned that stress is detrimental to sleep. When stressed, we have increased cortisol levels, which can negatively impact sleep (and everything else). Meditation can lower cortisol levels and improve sleep even after just one session. 

**Emotional regulator**
Ever wish you had more patience and mental calm in tough situations? Meditation can help with that. 

Brain scans of meditators show that regular meditation causes growth in areas of the brain associated with enhanced resilience and emotional regulation. This means stress doesn't wreak havoc in the same way. Less stress = better sleep.

recShEggxHQmkXH3G.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.2
recShEggxHQmkXH3G.Bottom Body:
Fortunately, it's possible to deal with these cognitive distortions! 

Psychologists use a technique called **cognitive restructuring**.

Cognitive restructuring is an extremely effective way to deal with thoughts that are unhelpful by challenging them! If you've ever participated in a debate or wrote a paper evaluating two separate views  you've already got some practice with this technique!

**Here's how it works:**

**Step 1:** Identify the irrational or exaggerated thought
**Step 2:** List any supporting evidence for or against it 
**Step 3:** Try reframing the thought in a way that's more in line with the supporting evidence. 

Let's use an example...

recSq9SJwCQW5rg7B.Bottom Body:

In addition to improving your overall quality of sleep, it can **help you to fall asleep faster** AND it may even decrease your risk of dementia!

recSv5H1TPWR8qI6G.Name: Circadian 1.3
recSv5H1TPWR8qI6G.Bottom Body:
**Environmental cues that regulate your sleep-wake cycle**
As you may recall, environmental cues that affect your circadian rhythm are referred to as zeitgebers (its a German word that means time giver). Zeitgebers send important signals that keep your inner schedules regular.

The key environmental cues that impact sleep are:
- Light
- Temperature
- Eating
- Activity

Lets take a closer look at how each one of these zeitgebers impacts your circadian rhythm...

recT0LCrkQ24YG9sn.Name: Sleepdrive 1.4
recT0LCrkQ24YG9sn.Bottom Body:
**Your circadian alerting system!**
This super neat alerting system contrasts the building sleep pressure of your sleep drive!

During your waking hours, your circadian alerting system sends arousal signals (oh la la) so you wont fall asleep prematurely.

By the end of the day, your circadian rhythm turns off this alerting system so that your body can receive the signals from your sleep drive that its _finallyyyyy_ time to sleep.

recTBEKQH2Dy5T3Ax.Name: Quickwin 11.3
recTBEKQH2Dy5T3Ax.Bottom Body:
As much as society loves the BEEP BEEP BEEP sound of a traditional alarm clock, being abruptly jolted from your slumber is not always the best greeting in the morning.

So why not try a light alarm?

**...What exactly are light alarms?**

Instead of the melodious BEEEEEEP, light alarms wake you up by shining a bright light. It basically mimics a sunrise in your own bedroom.

recTKmI2fgHSj6axL.Name: Difficulty Falling Asleep 1.1
recTKmI2fgHSj6axL.Bottom Body:
Having difficulties falling asleep can be incredibly frustrating. There are several reasons that this problem can occur. We'll dive more into that later!

**Tiny changes**
We want you to focus on small changes to get things started. Even if we ask you to implement habits you've tried before, we ask that you trust the process!

**Why start small?**
It's normal to want quick results and to dive headfirst into change. Unfortunately, that leads to us making changes that aren't sustainable and eventually we give up. 

By starting small you allow yourself tiny victories which makes the quest for change more manageable and more rewarding! You'll be sleeping for the rest of your life, so there's plenty of time to figure out how to optimize it.

Be patient. Start small. Trust the process.

recTQ2OHUJDOo4F7y.Name: summary 1.6
recTQ2OHUJDOo4F7y.Bottom Body:
**Cognitive restructuring**

In this section, we taught you how to be a rational scientist for your own thoughts. Gaining awareness of how your thoughts trigger emotions and behaviors is one of the most effective skills for lowering your stress. 

We practiced some cognitive restructuring techniques to get you started!

recTZlFcUwpDmbtHV.Name: wakingup 1.2
recTZlFcUwpDmbtHV.Bottom Body:
**1. Mental decompression routine**

We'll give you guidance on how to create an awesome bedtime routine later. For now, let's look at a very helpful decompression technique for people who regularly wake up in the middle of the night feeling stressed. 

It is **journaling!** There are a lot of ways you can approach journaling (you'll meet those later). The absolute best journaling technique for people who wake up stressed is: Making to-do lists. 

**Why a to-do list?** 
Spending 10 to 20 minutes writing out to-do lists and tasks for the next day gives your mind a chance to close up any loose ends on the day and feel secure and ready for the day ahead. 

It's basically like giving your brain permission to go offline!

recTkh9Rq780SmMqT.Name: QuickwinFA2.3
recTkh9Rq780SmMqT.Bottom Body:
**Grounding techniques** 
Grounding techniques are quick and easy to implement. They rely on your senses to help pull your mind out of unhelpful thought patterns and bring you back to the present. 

It's basically just creating a distraction from..umm.. yourself.

One of the most effective grounding techniques for sleep is...

**Making lists!**

Let's explore how...

recTr64IqmF0uDymr.Name: summary 1.4
recTr64IqmF0uDymr.Bottom Body:
**Sleep Basics**

In this section we learned about
1. **Circadian rhythm:** Your body's internal clock that regulates your sleep-wake cycle. It sends signals that lead to feeling alert or make you sleep! 
2. **Sleep drive:** During the day a chemical called adenosine builds up in your brain which leads to sleep pressure. Each night this pressure is cleared out and the process starts all over again.
3. **Sleep architecture:** During the night you travel through several stages of sleep, each with its own qualities and benefits. 

Once you mastered the basics, we moved on to talk about the impact of stress on sleep...

recTrEgilmiweXmgb.Name: QuickwinFA2.2
recTrEgilmiweXmgb.Bottom Body:
One of the most common issues people have when they can't fall asleep is a busy mind. Whether you get caught in looping thoughts, ruminating over events, or stressing about tomorrow, it can feel impossible to quiet your own thoughts sometimes. 

**Why?** Because our minds often form automatic thought loops. 

**How do you stop it?** Prevention is always ideal (a proper decompression routine), but sometimes we need a quick fix in a bind. 

**Grounding Techniques** has entered the chat!

recTrHK0HQ30brDXQ.Name: Overview 2.4
recTrHK0HQ30brDXQ.Bottom Body:
**How your diet might impact your sleep**

Avoid snack-related sleep disruptions by having your **last snack at least 3 hours before bedtime**, or choose snacks that are not high-sugar, high-fat, or spicy.

Adequate hydration is known for improving sleep. **Hydrate your way to better sleep** by choosing to **drink water** and including **lots of fruits and veggies in your diet**!

There are also many natural and safe supplements that can improve your sleep such as **multivitamins, vitamin D, iron, and magnesium**!

recTs1T4LdWbqvHox.Name: Overview 2.6
recTs1T4LdWbqvHox.Bottom Body:
**Why you wake up feeling tired**
We talked about all kinds of reasons why you might wake up feeling tired (even if you feel like you slept well) including:
1. You didnt get enough deep restorative sleep.
2. You woke up on the wrong side of your sleep cycle
3. Social jet lag from differences in your sleeping patterns on weekdays vs weekends

**How to beat it?**
1. **Fake it til you make it**. When you wake up tired, try thinking I feel good, I feel energized, Im going to have a good day.
2. **Try a green smoothie.** Drinking one every day can seriously improve your energy levels!
3. **Take a little nap.** Aim to have your nap between 1-3pm and nap for no more than 20 minutes!
4. **Pair your coffee with L-Theanine**. Taking a dose of 50 mg of L-Theanine with 100 mg of caffeine can significantly improve attention and cognitive performance!

recTvsd7Hojj8nBqF.Name: Supplements 1.6
recTvsd7Hojj8nBqF.Bottom Body:
That covers the very basics. If you are more interested in supplements you can reach out to your sleep coach to discuss the topic further! 

For now, focus on getting your basics in order with vitamin d, a multivitamin, iron, and magnesium.

If youre feeling sassy, you can try out using a next-level option like hops before bed this week to see if it helps you!

Also, **make sure you always talk to your doctor** before beginning or stopping any medications or supplements!

recTyX1mIQCKv16bz.Name: getRidStress 1.3
recTyX1mIQCKv16bz.Bottom Body: Great! Let's get started on showing you some stress management techniques made just for you!

recTyo5gKlBpakkWZ.Name: Noise 1.1
recTyo5gKlBpakkWZ.Bottom Body:
The next thing we are going to focus on when creating a sleep sanctuary is your **sleep environment.**

The best environment for sleeping is a quiet one.

Why?

**Even if noise doesn't wake you up  your brain still processes noise while youre asleep!**

recUNC9nbdj6c1N4p.Name: Tracking 1.3
recUNC9nbdj6c1N4p.Bottom Body:
**How do you pick a tracker?**

Here are some of the key measurements you need from your wearable to help you monitor sleep:

- **Movement:** Most devices use actigraphy (continuous measurement of activity) to measure movement with an accelerometer. Measures: Daily activity levels and sleep-wake cycles.

- **Biometrics:** At a minimum, you should get a device that measures your heart rate. Measures: Sleep, health, recovery, and stress levels.

recUOUDmYPLojUhDR.Name: change 1.2

1. **Ability**

recUPddWYxaYuOMwM.Name: boostnight 1.1
recUPddWYxaYuOMwM.Bottom Body:

It's probably not a big surprise to learn that there are many things you can do at night to improve your sleep. 

**I'm too tired to be disciplined**
Implementing habits in the evening is sometimes the most difficult. This is due to your end-of-day mental fatigue.

recUZgSDfKOYTkslm.Name: goals 1.7

recUfbx8lEbaD65Bx.Name: Overview 1.4
recUfbx8lEbaD65Bx.Bottom Body:
**Your daytime activities affect your sleep**

Daytime activities, such as exercising or substance use, can have a huge impact on your sleep.

Aim for at least 20 minutes of daily exercise to reduce stress, improve your health, and help you sleep better! You may have to keep vigorous exercise to daytime hours so it doesnt disrupt your sleep!

Avoid substances that can disrupt your sleep too close to bedtime. No caffeine after 2 pm and no alcohol at least 3 hours before bed!

recUitk5JpQEvyRge.Name: intake 1.4
recUitk5JpQEvyRge.Bottom Body: In your own words, what would success look like from using this program?

recUiyN270bzU64vy.Name: sleep stability 1.2
recUiyN270bzU64vy.Bottom Body:
**1. Get Regular**

You've already gotten a head start with this one! Keeping a regular sleep schedule is one of the best ways to optimize sleep stability. Since you can't always control when you get tired, getting up at the same time every day is the best way to keep your body on track.

Your internal clocks appreciate a regular schedule and do their best work when things are predictable. This means that consistency brings stability!

recUz5cFFwcfbGz1V.Name: Quickwin 9.2

recV1x7eTZJm2BgoE.Name: Quickwin 7.1

recV8BNPWOtPLAAc4.Name: intake 3.9

You have now dedicated 4 weeks to rebooting your sleep.

recVMaOPF9YMGRwHU.Name: summary 1.7
recVMaOPF9YMGRwHU.Bottom Body:
In week 2 we'll continue building on your action plan for better sleep and explore how your environment impacts your sleep! We'll also be introducing you to **how your body gets programmed for sleep** and **how you can undo bad programming**!

Remember that you can complete these cards at any pace that works for you. We'll continue building tiny changes together that will lead to a gradual transformation of your sleep. 

Great job on making it through week one! It shows you are really committed to change and that's awesome. 

Give yourself a pat on the back!

recVVEB9b0LH1wN3T.Name: Needs 1.3
recVVEB9b0LH1wN3T.Bottom Body:
**Growing pains**
As you begin to master the foundations of better sleep, you'll also learn to deal with the unhelpful thoughts and feelings that accompany sleep problems. 

You may also find that some changes feel disruptive to your sleep. 

**Think of it like this:** When you try a new exercise you get sore. The more you do that exercise  the less sore you feel (and you get better at it).  

**Little sacrifices for long-term gains**
New sleep habits can leave you more tired at first but after you adjust, you'll see improvements in the quality and quantity of sleep you get. 

As you climb that competence ladder, you'll get better sleep with less effort!

recVa6scQMXuZdXob.Name: BoostMorning 1.1
recVa6scQMXuZdXob.Bottom Body:
To get things started with Reboot camp, let's talk about mornings. 

Mornings are an important part of your reboot. 

**Why?** By following a few simple rules, you can use your mornings to:
- Reset your circadian rhythm
- Boost happiness and productivity
- Optimize your body's internal clocks

Let's take a look at how to boost your mornings in a way that improves your sleep!

recVbhj0RJeTfVc2O.Name: Quickwin 13.3
recVbhj0RJeTfVc2O.Bottom Body:
This type of deep meditation can be done live or even with recorded audio that will instruct you to slowly **descend into your sleep stages while still being consciously aware of your thoughts**.

Yoga Nidra sessions induce delta brain waves (similar to when you are asleep) which are associated with restoration and healing.

Yoga Nidra is not traditionally used as a way to fall asleep but rather to replenish our bodies when were sleep-deprived. However, many practices have now been tailored to induce sleep by leaving participants in a relaxed state rather than guiding them back to alertness at the end of a session.

You can use Yoga Nidra for restoration or for sleep! The choice is yours.

Lets see how to do it...

recVbsdDhi88Kkg1N.Name: Substances 1.8
recVbsdDhi88Kkg1N.Bottom Body:
Fortunately, you can still enjoy alcohol and good sleep too!

**Just follow these rules:**

- Have your last drink of alcohol at least 3 hours before you want to be sleeping.
- Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate! Experts recommend that you drink one glass of water for every serving of alcohol.
- Swap out for a non-alcoholic beer at night! Believe it or not, hops can help you sleep better and you wont get the negative side effects of alcohol.

**Knowledge is power**
If drinking is something you enjoy, we'll be back with some more tips on how to incorporate alcohol into your life and still get great sleep. 

**Substances and sleep**
There are many substances that impact sleep. Learning how to time substance use to reduce its impact on your sleep is the first step towards better sleep.

We know change can be hard, so just do the best that you can and well be here cheering on every one of your victories!

recViAw2yomKsSwqZ.Name: Orientation 2.1
recViAw2yomKsSwqZ.Bottom Body:
Welcome to Reboot Camp week numero two!

After this week you will earn your reboot badge, meaning that youll be ready to start diving headfirst into more advanced sleep stuff.

After last week, youve established the most basic of your foundation for good sleep, and this week were going to dig a little deeper!

Are you ready?

REBOOT CAMP WEEK 2: COMMENCE!

recVjYtsIVEqwgMC7.Name: level up 3.3
recVjYtsIVEqwgMC7.Bottom Body:
As an overview, your action plan this week is to:

1. **Wakeup at the same time every morning**
2. **Unplug and decompress before bedtime**
    1. Put electronics away at least 30 minutes before bedtime
    2. Do mental decompression as part of bedtime routine (journaling or progressive muscle relaxation)
3. **Only go to bed when sleepy!** 

We'll continue to check-in on your progress.

recVjaX1Ps7eA2LuA.Name: quickwins 5.3
recVjaX1Ps7eA2LuA.Bottom Body:
Let's say you currently watch TV before sleep. You have determined that it helps you unwind and relax.

**The problem?** TV before sleep can interfere with your quality of sleep and develop unwanted associations between your bed and nonsleep activities. 

**The fix?** Replace it with something else you enjoy that is relaxing and helpful to sleep. You can try reading instead! Make it fun and pick some books that really bring you joy. Audiobooks or podcasts are other great options.

You can also swap scrolling on your phone in bed in the mornings to making your bed in the morning! Try one of these or think of your own habit swap to try out this week! 

Swapping habits may come with a little discomfort at first (change is never easy), but it is an excellent strategy for building routines that move you toward your goals.

recVrHxgMqDvAGjTJ.Name: goalqual 1.3
recVrHxgMqDvAGjTJ.Bottom Body:
**2. Add noise**
Adding noise to your sleep may sound a little counterintuitive, right? Let's explore:

Environmental noise during the night is disruptive to sleep. Even if you aren't waking up, research has shown that it can still disrupt the quality of sleep you get. 

One of the best ways to combat environmental noise while improving your sleep stability is a noise machine! Pink noise (such as rain falling and waves rolling in) has been shown to increase sleep stability. 

Many people also find that soothing white noise and nature sounds help them fall asleep faster and maintain a higher quality of sleep. 

So, if you're looking to boost sleep quality  try a noise machine!

recVsFcByTMronNVd.Name: Sleepdrive 1.5
recVsFcByTMronNVd.Bottom Body:
The sleep dynamic duo is not finished when youre sleeping, though! Theyre still hard at work.

Your sleep drive declines rapidly during the first half of your night. But, fortunately, your circadian rhythm makes sure that the circadian alerting system stays quiet and you remain in sleep mode.

As you recall, your circadian rhythm relies on cues like darkness to keep this sleep mode thing going. Thats why light is so disruptive to sleep!

recVxUHJHz3McK3GY.Name: Bedroom 1.7
recVxUHJHz3McK3GY.Bottom Body:
**No laptops either!**

You thought you found a loophole, didnt you? Laptops also give off blue light and train your mind that bed is also for activities other than sex and sleep.

Doing work or checking emails on your laptop from bed is an especially big no-no as it can be very emotionally stimulating and make it hard to sleep.

recW0lKQY6MrWJWsl.Name: Elimhabits 1.3
recW0lKQY6MrWJWsl.Bottom Body:
**2. Swap it out**

It will take some discipline to reduce electronics before bed. One great way to approach it is to swap it out. If your habit is watching TV from bed, try listening to a podcast instead. 

If you like scrolling on your phone before bed, try journaling about your day, reading a fun book, or even doing a crossword puzzle.

Finding relaxing ways to unwind is possible. It may take some adjusting and discomfort, but the improvements in your sleep will be worth it!

recWNEfC9zIqNGESO.Name: snoring 1.2
recWNEfC9zIqNGESO.Bottom Body:
**Does snoring affect my health?**
Snoring is associated with high blood pressure, cardiovascular disease, and metabolic disorders. It often causes throat irritation and may lead to daytime sleepiness and reduced overall energy. 

**How do I know if I snore?**
You can actually measure your snoring now using apps like [Snorelab](https://www.snorelab.com/). It records your snoring and can help you better understand your problem and monitor your progress.

**Ok, what can I do to stop snoring?**
Fortunately, there are many solutions you can try to reduce or even eliminate snoring!

recWW9hZkGivw7Btq.Name: Sleep Basics 101 Overview 1.6
recWW9hZkGivw7Btq.Bottom Body:
Thats the basics of sleep science! Isnt it exciting to learn about all of the things that make up your sleep?!

And if you ever find yourself being quizzed, youll have all of the information you need to put that quiz to bed!

Speaking of quizzes...

recWePFDZhGKqACFg.Name: Overview 1.1
recWePFDZhGKqACFg.Bottom Body:
You did it! You made it through the first week of Reboot Camp and we are **so proud** of you! Pat yourself on the back (wed do it for you but we havent figured out that feature on the app yet)

recWjNHu04VTSvcuN.Name: worry 1.1
recWjNHu04VTSvcuN.Bottom Body:
**So, youre in a relationship with sleep  and its complicated**.

You now understand why having sleep problems can lead to dramatic and anxious thoughts. 

But, what impact does that have on your sleep? 

A pretty big one. The more time we spend in bed struggling with sleep, the more stress and anxiety impacts our ability to sleep. 

One of the main reasons is due to **Subconscious Sleep Stress.**

recWkzEE3gIWVso5x.Name: basics 1.3
recWkzEE3gIWVso5x.Bottom Body:
**2. Sleep Drive**
Your sleep drive is a teammate to your circadian rhythm! (GO TEAM SLEEP!) and their goal is a healthy sleep-wake cycle. 

**Circadian rhythm vs sleep drive**
See that graph up there? The signals from your circadian rhythm are a separate process referred to as "circadian alerting system" which either sends the signal "HEY BE AWAKE" or "TIME FOR SLEEP." 

While your circadian rhythm is doing its thing, sleep drive is running its own program for sleep using a whole other set of processes.

**What exactly is sleep drive?** 
Your sleep drive is your bodys **Need for Sleep** (No, it doesnt star Vin Diesel).

**How does it work?** 
When youre awake, a chemical called _adenosine_ builds in your brain and creates **sleep pressure.** The longer you're awake, the more pressure builds  which creates your need for sleep. 

Every time you sleep, the whole process gets reset and begins again the next day.

When all is aligned, sleep pressure peaks just as your circadian rhythm stops sending alert signals and starts sending its sleep signals. The result? Zzzzzzzzzzzz

**Get your sleep drive on**
Building healthy sleep habits will help you optimize your sleep drive. It can be disrupted by things such as stress, caffeine, naps, and irregular schedules. We'll show you how to get it back on track!

recWu5CHiv1INVkPc.Name: action 1.4
recWu5CHiv1INVkPc.Bottom Body:
We don't want you to feel like you're changing too many things about your sleep at once. Why? Because tiny changes bring greater rewards. 

So, let's get started on the reboot and wake up at the same time every morning. After a couple of weeks we promise you'll begin to notice a difference. 

For now, let's dive back into learning more about sleep!

p.s. We'll be checking in with you soon about your wake-up time

recWz3JhzPr7zBE9A.Name: Decompression 1.1
recWz3JhzPr7zBE9A.Bottom Body:
Now that you understand how blue light messes with sleep, you may see why its a bad idea to decompress using electronics.

You also now understand that stress can have a serious impact on your sleep. That means finding an effective way to unwind at the end of the day is pretty essential. 

**Bedtime routines have entered the chat...**

Bedtime routines are one of the most important things you can do to decompress at the end of the day and get your mind and body ready for sleep. As a bonus, they tend to act as a cue for "bedtime" which can further help your sleep!

In the spirit of starting simple, we'll give you some general guidelines about bedtime routines and then add the most effective tips into your action plan this week.

recX9Ix1JUVBwZTfx.Name: worry 1.5
recX9Ix1JUVBwZTfx.Bottom Body:
That means- you dont have to worry about sleep.

- Well help you better understand _your_ problems.
- Well tackle subconscious sleep anxiety.
- Well show you how to reprogram your brain for better sleep.
- Well teach you how to get the sleep you deserve.

Let us take the stress out of sleep.

recXHemUQV9exuPQF.Name: restructure 2.3
recXHemUQV9exuPQF.Bottom Body:
**Cognitive Restructuring**

In the box below, try rephrasing this cognitive distortion in a way that makes it more rational and logical:

**Thought:** "Tomorrow is ruined if I don't get enough sleep"

**Evidence for:** Losing sleep can make it hard to function optimally
**Evidence against:** My body is pretty resilient in the face of sleep disruptions

**Revised thought:**

recXTcFjVQRrYapyQ.Name: Sleepstress 1.1
recXTcFjVQRrYapyQ.Bottom Body:
**So, youre in a relationship with sleep  and its complicated.**

The unfortunate reality is that sleep is an essential need and our brains tend to panic over essential needs. 

This can lead to unhelpful automatic thought patterns that put the stress in sleep. 

If you've ever tossed and turned at night while cursing the sky, you are familiar with why sleep and stress don't mix well.
recXTcFjVQRrYapyQ.Top Body: ## You can control your relationship with sleep

recXcqkgLSlT8J9wU.Name: Importance 1.3
recXcqkgLSlT8J9wU.Bottom Body:
**Get started**
Rule numero uno, and were going to remind you of this often:

**Your bedroom should only be for sleep** (and sex). Seriously.

By participating in any other activities in your bedroom, your mind begins to make associations between your bedroom and wakefulness/alertness/stress/work/true crime documentaries.

You want your mind to **only associate your bed and bedroom with sleep**.

recXepVxtyVa6FTbB.Name: Quickwin 9.3
recXepVxtyVa6FTbB.Bottom Body:
**How to do positive affirmations**
There are many ways you can use positive affirmations. Lets just focus on how to use them for crushing your sleep goals!

Each day, choose a habit you already have and add positive affirmations to it. For instance, after your brush your teeth? Look in the mirror and say your positive affirmations.

You should choose a phrase that boosts you and helps you overcome an area that youre struggling with.

Lets look at some examples...

recXfnPvwSSA6y7Ds.Name: Waketime 1.1
recXfnPvwSSA6y7Ds.Bottom Body:
Waking up is the very first thing youll do every morning, so its kind of important that you get it right.

With that being said  were going to teach you the golden rule of mornings!

\*cue dramatic horn intro music\*

**Wake up at the same time every day**

This is one of those tips well repeat over and over. It is a tip that can be life changing for many people.

**But, why is it so important?**

recXkLYvnZvTK2Ki7.Name: caffeineSleep 1.2
recXkLYvnZvTK2Ki7.Bottom Body:
Before we give you the Rested Rules of caffeine consumption, let's look at why caffeine is such a popular stimulant (and why it's not great for sleep):

- It pumps you up by boosting adrenaline (activating your fight-or-flight response)
- It reduces melatonin.
- It blocks an important sleep regulator called adenosine (Adenosine slowly builds up in your brain over the day creating sleep pressure which is your body's need for sleep)
- You can't build up a tolerance to the sleep-disrupting effects of caffeine. Even if you **feel** less stimulated, the negative impacts on sleep only intensify with increasing doses of caffeine. 

OK, so how do you enjoy your caffeine without it impacting your sleep?

recXlGWrOY2AKReLG.Name: week3summary 1.6
recXlGWrOY2AKReLG.Bottom Body:
You also continued to practice cognitive restructuring and you were introduced to box breathing for relaxation! 

In week 4 you'll continue building on your action plan for rebooting your sleep, learn about optimizing your circadian rhthym, discover the impact of diet and exercise on sleep, and even learn about natural foods that boost melatonin!

Great job finishing week 3! You've made some serious changes and you are on your way to rebooting your relationship with sleep.

recXoKmxwDAUw4kI9.Name: BasicsQ 1.1
recXoKmxwDAUw4kI9.Bottom Body:
Wow, you've really learned a lot! Don't worry, you don't need to memorize all of your learnings, we'll keep reminding you of all the most important stuff. 

However, we do want you to remember some key facts! 

ARE YOU READY TO SHOW US WHAT YOU LEARNED?? ARE YOU? (sorry for yelling, we get really excited about quizzes)

recXrQd18pnajoIsA.Name: Trackingprogress 1.4
recXrQd18pnajoIsA.Bottom Body:
**Should everyone track their sleep?**
Nope! If you find that tracking your sleep leads you to feel more stressed about sleep, you can skip it. 

Tracking is a powerful accountability tool, but it isn't your only tool. 

You may choose to track how Rested you feel each morning, your productivity, or your general well-being. 

We always want you to figure out what works for you! 

Try tracking your sleep for a week and see how it goes!

Believe it or not, you now have all of the sleep basics youll need to start your REBOOT.

I know we pumped you with all kinds of sleep science, so lets take a quick minute to go over those concepts so that when we bring them up again youll know exactly what were talking about!

Lets review!

recY53LY0ZZRczJnR.Name: Quizset 3.12

recY75n7o3W0kWvxW.Name: Tracking 1.1
recY75n7o3W0kWvxW.Bottom Body:
**So, you'd like to learn more about wearables! Let's go!**

The traditional way for people to track their sleep is by using a **sleep diary**. However, it can be pretty difficult for people to accurately track their own sleep (Doing work while youre asleep can be tricky).

recY8cUGfKEdvyLZX.Name: racingmind 1.3
recY8cUGfKEdvyLZX.Bottom Body:
**Step 2:** With your hand still on your heart, slowly repeat this mantra  "I am at peace"

As you say the words inside your mind, make an effort to believe them. Notice the comfort of your bed, the steady and smooth beat of your heart, and sink into the feeling of peace.

recYIPbKJWp16bMxE.Name: Substances 1.1
recYIPbKJWp16bMxE.Bottom Body:
**Dont let your daytime ruin your night**

Learning about which daytime activities can impact sleep can help you make better choices as you go about your day.

You may have already heard that certain substances we consume can have a negative impact on sleep...but is it really such a big deal?

Lets explore the two most popular daytime substances that impact sleep:

**Caffeine and alcohol**

recYPeXlVMuJLa5bZ.Name: snoring 1.4
recYPeXlVMuJLa5bZ.Bottom Body:
Snoring can be a big roadblock on your journey to better sleep. 

Try assessing whether you snore this week using an app like Snorelab and then determine whether you need to take some action. 

Snoring doesn't have to ruin your slumber. Many people are able to reduce or eliminate it with some basics lifestyle changes and healthy habits.

recYUQlYnOKk1P6Qp.Name: Onboarding1.1
recYUQlYnOKk1P6Qp.Bottom Body:
**Welcome to Reboot Camp!**

Youve learned the basics of habit mastery and the importance of learning by association (and why it complicates sleep). Now, its time to reboot your relationship with sleep!

Well start by teaching you the basic science that goes into your sleep (forget street smarts, were all about sleep smarts!)

Youll learn how to use that information to build sleep skills and habits that will change your relationship with sleep _forever._

So, are you ready to reboot?
recYUQlYnOKk1P6Qp.Next Button: Get ready! Get set! Get Rested!

recYhPkl7OfqQT3kA.Name: meditation 1.3
recYhPkl7OfqQT3kA.Bottom Body:
**Increased melatonin**

Meditation also helps boost our natural production of melatonin by slowing down its metabolism or boosting the synthesis of melatonin in our pineal glands. 

Melatonin naturally declines as we age and finding ways to boost it naturally can help strengthen your sleep-wake cycle. 


**Better sleep stability**

People who meditate regularly have been found to have enhanced slow-wave deep sleep and REM sleep states. Both stages are extremely important to the restorative properties of sleep. 

People who regularly meditate have also been found to have an enhanced number of sleep cycles and improved synchronization of gamma brain waves, which is associated with a healthy brain and healthier sleep.

recYzfjtqnth2M8Y7.Name: spower 1.1
recYzfjtqnth2M8Y7.Bottom Body:
You now understand the basics of learning by association and how that can negatively impact our sleep.

As you may have expected, we'll be asking you to make some changes in order to help you sleep better. 

- **Is it worth it?**

- **Will better sleep actually change your life?**

- **Will you actually gain any health benefits?**

Let's take a look at sleep  your superpower.

recZ06BAh0AkWc60u.Name: unlearn 1.2
recZ06BAh0AkWc60u.Bottom Body:
**Your brain the programmer**
Your brain is constantly scanning your surroundings and updating its files. These files contain information and protocols that are meant to make your life easier.

**Passive learning**
If two separate events occur together repeatedly (sometimes even just once) your brain associates them. This is why certain scents are linked to memories and also why dogs freak out when they see you grab their leash (see, we have other examples besides ice cream).

This cognitive shortcut makes learning (and life) easier! Except when unwanted associations get formed!

\*cue sad trombone sound\*

**Active Unlearning**
Don't worry, you can also unlearn associations between things, although it tends to take a little longer than learning them.Don't worry, we'll help you!

**So, how does this impact my sleep?**

recZ59Rvevjm2grnI.Name: UnexpectedStress 1.1
recZ59Rvevjm2grnI.Bottom Body:
**Stress and Negative Thoughts**
Stress is detrimental to sleep. It can feel incredibly difficult to control stressful thoughts when you're already tired.

Effective stress management is a life-long pursuit. Its important to recognize that a lot of the habits we have were formed long before our brains were fully developed and may not be the best way to cope with stress.

**So what now?** You can retrain your brain! Thats right. By adopting some healthier coping mechanisms, you can find better ways to deal with stress and minimize the impact it has on your sleep.

You can't always control the stress you encounter, but you do have a lot of control over the conversations you have with yourself and how you react to the world around you. 

We already talked about cognitive restructuring (we'll practice that more soon).

Next, we're going to focus on the **two-arrow approach**!

recZI9EosuiWVQg3l.Name: QuickwinFA 13.2
recZI9EosuiWVQg3l.Bottom Body:
**Box Breathing!**

Did you know that anytime you feel stressed you can calm your body down nearly instantly by engaging in something called _box breathing. _It can also boost your alertness! Cool, right?

**What the heck is box breathing???**

It is a technique where you engage in deep breathing in a specific pattern.

Deep breathing activates your parasympathetic nervous system which sends signals to your body to calm down and relax quickly so youre able to slip into a peaceful slumber!

recZL7smTIdXDTRrs.Name: mythBuster 2.2
recZL7smTIdXDTRrs.Bottom Body:
**Genetic variants**
Some people have a rare genetic mutation (called ADRB1) which reduces their sleep needs to only 4.5-6 hours of sleep a night!

**Morning person vs night owl**
There are also genes that affect how sensitive your circadian rhythm is to cues in your environment, and your body's preferred sleep schedule! More on that later. 

**The takeaway**
 In general, developing good sleep habits (with support from your friends at Rested Health) will show you how to achieve higher quality sleep. 

That means that even on nights when you get less, you can still feel Rested.

recZMoo4ItfqYvDgQ.Name: HypeUp 1.2
recZMoo4ItfqYvDgQ.Bottom Body:
As you recall, we did a little dive into Sleep Basics 101! We talked about how your:

- **Circadian rhythm** is responsible for regulating your sleep-wake cycle

- **Sleep drive** is your bodys need for sleep

- **Sleep Architecture** accounts for the quality of sleep you get and its made up of several stages with unique benefits

recZOAKnVdKmK1EaU.Name: QuickwinFA4.3
recZOAKnVdKmK1EaU.Bottom Body:
To avoid the dreaded "melatonin suppression" effect of regular light, try switching out your bedside lamp with a **red light bulb**!

**Wait, what?**
Unlike other forms of light that suppress melatonin (we're looking at you blue light), red light actually helps you produce more of it!

**What does that mean?**
That means using a red lightbulb in your bedside lamp won't disrupt your sleep and may even actually help you fall asleep faster!

Plus, your room will look super cool.

recZTmzaBJgTXHG3T.Name: Circadian 1.4
recZTmzaBJgTXHG3T.Bottom Body:
**Light**

Light intake is the **_most_** important environmental influence for adjusting your sleep-wake cycle. Its #1. Numero uno. It is the king of zeitgebers.

Cells in your eyes (specifically your retina) measure the amount of light in your environment and then send signals directly to your SCN. Light results in a signal to stop melatonin production and boost wakefulness.

Similarly, darkness results in the opposite effect. During the evening, your body is programmed to release melatonin. Darkness acts as a cue to allow the secretion of melatonin.

Thats why dim lighting before bed is helpful for making you sleepy!

recZWrcrNH6COxlmv.Name: QuickwinFA4.2
recZWrcrNH6COxlmv.Bottom Body:
**What to do about light at night**

Here's the good news: We don't expect you to wear night vision goggles

Here's the tough news: You may need some new light bulbs

OK, that wasn't so bad. Was it? 

Here's a quick tip on how to avoid messing up your sleep with too much light before bedtime...

recZc4z6RN6t7Ssht.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.3
recZc4z6RN6t7Ssht.Bottom Body:
**Step 1: Identify the thought-** Generally this is a thought that appears and creates stress. As an example  "I'm going to get sick and die if I don't fall asleep"

**Step 2: List evidence for or against it**- Do your best to be neutral and honestly provide evidence for and against this thought.
**Evidence for:** Losing sleep can weaken your immune system and sometimes makes you feel off.
**Evidence against:** Nobody has ever died from lack of sleep. I've missed sleep before and it didn't kill me.

**Step 3: Reframing the thought-** "If I don't sleep well I may not feel my best tomorrow"

As you can see, the reframed version of the original thought doesn't quite carry the same emotional burden! 

**Finding our peace**
Quite frequently our thoughts contribute heavily to our experience of stress and anxiety in daily situations. You can't always control your environment, but you DO have some control over how you react to it!

recZe9T5Xf5kZbv0a.Name: restructure 4.3
recZe9T5Xf5kZbv0a.Bottom Body:
**Cognitive Restructuring**

In the box below, try rephrasing this cognitive distortion in a way that makes it more rational and logical:

**Thought**: "Nobody understands how much this sucks"

**Evidence fo**r: I don't feel understood by the people around me
**Evidence against**: Some people may understand that I'm in pain 

**Revised thought**:

recZizQWqH8ZfVsyL.Name: Quickwin 11.4
recZizQWqH8ZfVsyL.Bottom Body:
**Waking up is easier with light**
You can set a light alarm to your preferred wake-up time and allow your body to gently stir awake to a lovely sun-like glow each morning.

Not only can a light alarm wake you up naturally, but if used on a regular basis can also strengthen your sleep-wake cycle!

See? Not all alarms are mean. Level up your morning by grabbing yourself a little simulation sunrise!

recZtv1dnlwolJRnz.Name: Sleepstress 1.3
recZtv1dnlwolJRnz.Bottom Body:
Your bodys energy levels and desire for sleep are driven by two key processes:
1. **Sleep Drive**
2. **Circadian alerting system** 

**Sleep Drive:** As you go about your day, your sleep drive builds and builds until finally, you get that gee, Im sleepy feeling. It's due to a chemical called adenosine and sleep is the only way to reset it.

**Circadian alerting system:** Your circadian alerting system operates by creating dips and rises throughout the day that drives sleepiness and wakefulness. It's basically a biological clock, which means it's one of your body's natural timing devices." It has its own rhythm but also gets regulated by cues in your environment.
recZtv1dnlwolJRnz.Top Body: ## Sleep Drive vs Circadian Alerting System

recaCzzNoCNKSkVPK.Name: QuickwinFA 14.2
recaCzzNoCNKSkVPK.Bottom Body:
If you are being woken up during a deep sleep stage, youre likely going to feel groggy.

By waking up during a lighter stage of sleep, youre probably going to find yourself feeling more refreshed and alert.

**Smart alarms have entered the chat!**

What is a smart alarm?

recaFFSo4qllun3G4.Name: Waketime 1.4
recaFFSo4qllun3G4.Bottom Body:
**Dont hit snooze**

Well repeat this one a lot because its important DO NOT HIT SNOOZE IN THE MORNING!

We want you to learn how to work with your bodys natural rhythms and snoozing in the morning is very disruptive to your natural biological processes. It can leave you extra sleepy, disoriented, and make it harder to start the day.

Learn what you can do instead of pressing snooze...

recaNLE2SBSi6dNUf.Name: levelup4 1.1
recaNLE2SBSi6dNUf.Bottom Body:
Your current action plan for rebooting your sleep is:

1. **Wakeup at the same time every morning**
2. **Unplug and decompress before bedtime**
    1. Put electronics away at least 30 minutes before bedtime
    2. Do mental decompression as part of bedtime routine (journaling or progressive muscle relaxation)
3. **Only go to bed when sleepy! **
4. **Drink a glass of water as soon as you wake up**
5. **Get 10-20 minutes of morning sunshine**

Today, we're going to add one more item to this list...

6\. **Build a consistent** **meditation practice **

recaT35gUbMqLJq7Q.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.5
recaT35gUbMqLJq7Q.Bottom Body:

Remember, think of evidence for and evidence against, then rephrase it in a way that's in line with the evidence!

**"I'm never going to stick with this new habit"**

recaaUBUQggAnEjX0.Name: sleepmyths 2.1

**5. You sleep better as the night goes on**

recacBBmwexdav1OV.Name: Quickwin 1.5
recacBBmwexdav1OV.Bottom Body:
Try grabbing a warm bath or shower around 1-2 hours before your desired bedtime. Stay in there at least 10 minutes (you can stay longer if you want, we don't pay your water bill) and notice how much it helps you sleep!

That's it for today's Quick Win. But, don't worry, we have many more of these sweet little tidbits coming your way!
