recadlfm0tJM8VQxX.Name: QuickWinFA 10.1
recadlfm0tJM8VQxX.Bottom Body:
**iiiiiiiiiiiiiiit's Quick Win time!** 

Today we want to give you another tip that can help you fall asleep faster. 

Having various tools to deal with stress and unwanted wakefulness can help you feel more confident in your ability to manage the discomfort of being unable to fall asleep. We want you to have all the tools!

Let's check out today's tip!

recafVUpISOdrgGCj.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.4
recafVUpISOdrgGCj.Bottom Body:
**Reducing stressful thoughts**
You can use this technique with any thought that brings you stress. The more you practice the better you'll get!

To get started, try writing out an unhelpful or stress-inducing thought in a notebook. Pretend you are an external critic and write out arguments for and against your thought. Then proceed to reframe the thought in a way that honors the evidence you've presented! 

Over time, you'll develop the skills to better manage these types of thoughts as they come.

**A thought on thoughts**
Remember, a thought is just a thought. You always have more control over your thoughts than you realize. 

Learning to find that space between a thought and a reaction takes some time, but it will empower you to find logic when your mind is leaning into dramatics. 

Learning how to lower your stress will improve every area of functioning  especially sleep!

recaljIq2DJqt8LmE.Name: models 1.7
recaljIq2DJqt8LmE.Top Body:
**Awesome!** 

Building new habits can be hard. We want you to succeed! We want you to sleep better! We want you to feel better! 

That means we're here to support you and help you move up that ladder. 

So, let's just drop everything and start at the bottom of the ladder together. We'll build out a program that will help you gain mastery over **your** sleep.

recanRaTP5iNyW4LH.Name: goalfallasleepfaster1.4
recanRaTP5iNyW4LH.Bottom Body:
**Did that sound familiar?** When you have trouble falling asleep, lying in bed and wrestling with sleep only creates subconscious sleep stress. 

The more you do it, the more your mind anticipates stressing over sleep.

**The fix?** Only go to bed when you are tired.

**What if I don't get tired?** Your body will eventually succumb to sleep. While you're waiting for sleep, do a relaxing activity in a dimly lit room.

**But, I'll be tired the next day!** Yes, this is possible. However, in order to reboot your sleep, it means you may have to have some sleep disruptions at first. 

**Do I still have to wake up at the same time if I stayed up late?** Yes! But make sure you are able to move your schedule around if you're extremely sleep-deprived. 

This technique will also help to regulate the physiological processes that drive sleep (more about that later).

recaxcHo6lILg3YNC.Name: alcoholsleep 1.7
recaxcHo6lILg3YNC.Bottom Body:
**What can I do about it?**

It's possible to enjoy booze and still sleep well. Here are a few guidelines:

- **Skip the nightcap:** Most guidelines say that you should wait 3-4 hours between your last drink and bedtime. However, research has shown that alcohol consumed even six hours before bedtime can negatively impact your sleep.

- **Stay Hydrated:** You can reduce some of the side effects of alcohol by keeping hydrated. Experts recommend that you drink one glass of water for every serving of alcohol.

- **Know your limits: **Just one drink can disrupt your sleep. One drink is usually equivalent to about a can (12 ounces) of beer, a glass (5 ounces) of wine, or a shot (1.5 ounces) of spirits. The more alcohol you drink, the more your sleep can be disrupted.

- **Anti-Hangover Supplements**- Taking supplements like Dihydromyricetin or N-Acetyl cysteine and a multivitamin two hours before you drink can help reduce some side effects of alcohols toxins. They arent a cure but they can reduce the pain (especially on a night of heavy drinking). 

\*Always talk to your doctor before beginning any new supplements.

recbApQBjRo5F0aiX.Name: summary 2.3
recbApQBjRo5F0aiX.Bottom Body:
**2. You vs Blue Light**

- **Blue light is activating**: This short wavelength, high-intensity source of light can boost focus and energy levels.  
- **Blue light is everywhere**: The sun, TVs, digital devices, fluorescent lights, LEDs, and more. 
- **Blue light in the evening disrupts sleep:** Blue light suppresses melatonin, stimulates your brain, and you absorb it all. This makes it very disruptive to sleep!
- **Fixes for blue light**: You can reduce the negative impact of blue light on sleep by reducing your time on devices and putting them away before bed. You can also try using blue light blocking software, blue light blocking glasses, and swapping out some of your bulbs for bedtime-friendly bulbs.

recbCWR8Lbd8OjNfJ.Name: Sleepdrive 1.1
recbCWR8Lbd8OjNfJ.Bottom Body:
Your sleep drive is responsible for your bodys road to slumberville. It is your bodys **need for sleep.**

**How does it work?** There is a chemical in your brain called _adenosine_ that is constantly building while you are awake (yep, like _right now!_).

After about 16 hours of being awake, the built-up adenosine creates a feeling known as **sleep pressure** that tells you its time to go to bed.

Its one of the reasons you start feeling tired at the end of the day!

_So, what exactly is adenosine?_

recbFDdalJa2l1DjC.Name: Quickwin 14.1
recbFDdalJa2l1DjC.Bottom Body:
Surprise! You didnt think wed end this week of Reboot Camp without a final quick win, now did ya??!

Not a chance. We want to make sure that you have as many quick wins in your sleep toolbox as possible.

So heres the next one!

recbHqGcUPugLxC1g.Name: caffeineSleep 1.5
recbHqGcUPugLxC1g.Bottom Body:
**Helpful tip**
**Stack caffeine with L-Theanine**

To help reduce your caffeine intake and also ease those caffeine jitters, try taking your coffee with an amino acid called L-Theanine. 

L-theanine is naturally found in tea leaves. On its own, it improves focus and reduces stress. 

Taking a dose of 50 mg of L-Theanine with 100 mg of caffeine can significantly improve attention and cognitive performance, better than just coffee alone. 

This powerful little supplement is easy to take and boosts coffees good effects while reducing your stress response. 



\*always talk to your doctor before stopping or beginning any new supplements

recbIjnUlBTcyqJyT.Name: Architeture 1.5
recbIjnUlBTcyqJyT.Bottom Body:
**Your brain stem**
Your sleep architecture seems to be controlled by an area of the brain called the brain stem. This area also controls breathing, blood pressure, and heartbeat.

Fluctuating activity in the brain stem appears to coordinate the timing of wakefulness and the architecture of the 90-minute sleep cycles that you go through each night. 

**The great balance** 
When you are sleep-deprived, your sleep architecture will adjust on subsequent nights to adjust for lost restorative rest. For instance, if you missed out on valuable REM sleep, you'll experience REM rebound where you spend more time in REM on subsequent nights!

This is why you don't need more hours to make up for lost sleep, your body prefers to do it's thing by sleeping more efficiently.

recbN3hCVWn3fpfBy.Name: racingmind 1.1
recbN3hCVWn3fpfBy.Bottom Body:
A racing mind at night is one of the most common reasons people have trouble falling asleep. In your journeys, we'll teach you how to build a routine that decreases your end-of-day stress.

But how about a quick fix for when it happens? We got you. 

There are many different techniques you can use, with some trial and error, you can definitely learn how to tame a busy mind before bed. 

Let's take a look...

recbShj6Z6QF3PPQH.Name: Bedroom 1.2
recbShj6Z6QF3PPQH.Bottom Body:
**Dont see the light**

You know all about how your body naturally produces melatonin when the sun goes down, so this next tip shouldnt come as a surprise to you!

A sleep sanctuary needs **DARKNESS**

Sleeping in a dark environment is going to give you a better quality sleep by allowing continuous melatonin production through the night!

Even though its generally dark at bedtime (unless youre a shift worker), the majority of people have a lot of light pollution in their rooms. Whether its digital devices, outdoor lights, or even a fish tank, theres light and its interfering with your sleep!

We have some things you can do that will help you bathe in darkness.

recbTjN8q0EjeLDxl.Name: Tracking 1.6
recbTjN8q0EjeLDxl.Bottom Body:
**Choices, choices, choices...**
Since you are so interested in better sleep, we'd like to show you all of the options you have for wearables!

Many people don't even realize that there are many options out there for tracking sleep!! 

Let's take a look at the different kinds of wearables, maybe you'll find something super spectacularly awesome for you!

recbUghRjRH5gxTGE.Name: models  1.2
recbUghRjRH5gxTGE.Bottom Body:
Psychiatrist Milton Erickson developed this model of learning and skill development. It applies to pretty much every skill you've ever started, worked on, or mastered!

As you learn a new skill or habit, you travel through 4 stages of competence. 

**1. Unconsciously incompetent**: "I don't realize I have a problem, so I don't know I need to fix it"

**2. Consciously incompetent:** "I know I have a problem, but I don't know how to fix it"

**3. Consciously competent:** "I know how how to fix my problem, but it takes a lot of energy to implement the habits" 

**4. Unconsciously competent:** "I know how to fix my problem, and I've been practicing a lot, so my habits feel automatic"

The competence ladder shows us the steps we need to take to master a new habit. 

**Started from the bottom**
With this ladder, it's important to spend time at each rung. Yes! Even the bottom! 

**Now we're here**
Think of it as a ladder we'll slowly climb together.

Let's look at each rung on the ladder...

recbhCFrHVIuXYgpi.Name: CircRhythm 1.1
recbhCFrHVIuXYgpi.Bottom Body:
In week 1 you learned the basics of your circadian rhythm.

**Overview:**
- **It's a biological clock**: Your body operates on a 24-hour schedule and regulates biological processes such as temperature and hormones. 
- **Circadian rhythm and sleep**: Your circadian rhythm controls very important sleep processes like melatonin production and suppression which helps regulate your sleep cycle and keeps you sleeping through the night
- **Cues:** Your circadian rhythm uses environmental cues called zeitgebers to keep your schedule on track.


This week we're going to talk about how to tell if your circadian rhythm is off and what you can do to optimize it!

recbimyYZl5aWtpk1.Name: unlearn 1.4
recbimyYZl5aWtpk1.Bottom Body:
**Other links**
When you do things in your bed and bedroom that aren't sleeping or sex, your bed and bedroom become linked with feelings of stress, worry, alertness, and frustration.

As you can imagine, these arent exactly helpful programs for sleep.

**Some examples include:**
- **Watching TV in bed**
- **Working from bed**
- **Scrolling your phone in bed (morning or night)**
- **Eating in bed**

Ok, so how do you reprogram?

recbmKSiuSsJTvBqa.Name: Blue light 1.6
recbmKSiuSsJTvBqa.Bottom Body:
**2. Blue light blocking programs:** 

You can install programs on your computer (i.e f.lux) that automatically adjust the color and brightness of your screen based on your timezone.

As it gets dark outside, the program gives your monitor an orange hue by blocking blue light. There are similar apps available for smartphones, and some phones have a built-in night-mode. Use it!

These programs won't completely eliminate the impact of using electronics, but they may help reduce it. 

**3. Blue light blocking glasses:** 
You can buy a pair of amber-tinted blue light blocking lenses. The clearer lenses block 30% of blue light, while amber or brown tinted lenses block up to 100% of blue light! 

If you want to really go all out, be sure to get the style that wrap around your eyes  blocking blue light from all angles. Blue light blocking glasses are generally superior to blue light blocking programs.

recbwMDeacU7t6q1u.Name: week 3.3
recbwMDeacU7t6q1u.Bottom Body:
**Picking a bedtime**

This one may feel obvious, but it's not always that simple. We'll give you guidelines on how to pick your ideal bedtime and tips for differentiating feeling fatigued vs feeling sleepy.

**Your sleep environment**

Next, we'll take a look at your sleep environment and give you some tips on creating a sleep sanctuary. Some things may seem obvious, but we're pretty sure you'll learn something new!

recbxBi88n19NYeKx.Name: relearn 1.2
recbxBi88n19NYeKx.Bottom Body:
In order to weaken the associations between nonsleep activities and bed AND to strengthen the association between bed and sleep  there are two key action items we'll ask you to do!

**Key action items to reboot your relationship with sleep:**
1. **Only use your bed for sleeping (and sex**)
2. **Leave the bed when you cant sleep**

These action plans arent just light suggestions, they are the recipe you need to begin rebuilding your relationship with sleep. 

They will help you improve your healthy connections and unlearn those that do not serve you. 

Lets take a closer look at each action item...

recc3QhxdinD5e5Gr.Name: QuickCheckIn 1.3
recc3QhxdinD5e5Gr.Bottom Body: Thanks for answering! Always remember, it's about progress and implementing tiny changes. We'll keep checking in on your progress and gradually adding more action items to your sleep reboot plan.

recc7ATFbeRY4CeEg.Name: to know you 1.1
recc7ATFbeRY4CeEg.Bottom Body:
We want to get to know you better. We'll regularly drop by with questions that help us learn more about you and your needs. 

As you may have already noticed, needs change sometimes! So, we'll regularly check in to make sure you're getting the advice you need. 

Let's learn a little bit about the current problems you are having with your sleep...

reccSL6XACmWnkWU4.Name: Architecture 1.4
reccSL6XACmWnkWU4.Bottom Body:
**What should my sleep architecture look like?**

Average sleep architecture for adults** **usually consists of four or five alternating non-REM and REM periods. 

Most deepsleepoccurs in the first half of the night. As the night progresses, your periods of REMsleepget longer and tend to alternate with lighter sleep stages (N2). 

As a result, most of your restorative sleep is done in the first half of the night and the second half is focused on reorganizing memories, processing emotions, and general housework.

reccYKQtpC6WEDRc3.Name: Supplements 1.4
reccYKQtpC6WEDRc3.Bottom Body:
**What about melatonin?**

Melatonin is the most popular sleep supplement

But its often overused.

Many experts believe that long-term use of melatonin supplements may deplete your natural production of melatonin. Additionally, most doses are **way too high**. If you do need to take it, stick with a dose of 0.3 mg, which more closely mimics your bodys natural production and has been shown to be more effective than higher doses.

Ideally, save your melatonin supplement for when you have jet lag or after an all-nighter!

reccYu5ZxfJvqwuOa.Name: relearn 1.4
reccYu5ZxfJvqwuOa.Bottom Body:
**2. Leave the bed when you cant sleep**

Staying in bed when you can't sleep can lead your mind to associate bed with activities like rumination, stress, mental anguish, and existential dread. 

As a rule, if you are laying in bed trying to sleep and its been longer than 20 minutes  leave the bed!

**Where do you go?** Ideally, go somewhere that you can relax and do something boring. You can head to your living room, a cozy nook, or any room other than your bedroom.Avoid using your phone, working, or exposing yourself to too much light. The key is to engage in a relaxing activity and refrain from trying to sleep. 

We'll give you more tips along the way to help you out, for now, the important thing is to just get out of bed!

reccfIFGHhJr2vBok.Name: Quickwin4.3
reccfIFGHhJr2vBok.Bottom Body:
First of all, you should dim the lights in your environment two hours before bed. That's when your body begins to produce melatonin for sleep. 

Next, for the next-level melatonin surge  swap out your bedside light for a red light bulb. Research has found that red light doesn't disrupt melatonin and may actually boost it! Cool, right?

reccpkRa3WII3pfEM.Name: goalsleepschedule1.1
reccpkRa3WII3pfEM.Bottom Body:
We want to help you reach your goal of sticking to a sleep schedule. 

**Defining your goal**
A solid sleep schedule helps your body's rhythms stay aligned which leads to better quality sleep. However, sleep is complicated and sticking with a schedule can be tricky. 

To get you started, we're going to talk about two things you can do to help you stick with your sleep schedule!

1. **Get alarmed**  
2. **Don't nap**

reccvWQqL7isuc6tS.Name: goalqual 1.2
reccvWQqL7isuc6tS.Bottom Body:
**1. Move it** 
Exercise has a lot of health benefits. It also happens to be one of the best ways to optimize your sleep!

Exercise has been shown to increase the amount of time you spend in restorative slow-wave sleep. Physical activity has also been shown to reduce stress by 40%, which also helps get them high quality Zzzzs. 

**How much do I need?** Ideally, aim for at least 150 minutes a week with at least 90 minutes at moderate intensity (80% of your maximum heart rate). Strength training and aerobic exercise are both helpful to sleep!

reccwiD5fQlx7Ugl4.Name: Exercise 1.3
reccwiD5fQlx7Ugl4.Bottom Body:
**How does exercise help you sleep better?**
- It helps you sleep longer and more efficiently
- It helps you fall asleep more quickly
- It increases the amount of restorative deep sleep you get

Exercise also helps reduce sleep apnea, lowers your stress response, improves blood flow, and helps regulate your circadian rhythm. Exercise even boosts serotonin which helps regulate mood and sleep.

The health benefits of exercise are numerous and can improve your sleep in many ways.

Lets take a look...

reccz1CgAYS5yfdrn.Name: Why 1.3
reccz1CgAYS5yfdrn.Bottom Body:
**Adaptations**
Unlike certain other animals, humans have evolved neurological tricks in the face of severe sleep deprivation (similar to some birds and aquatic mammals).

**What tricks?** The human brain has the ability to shut down certain parts while sort of staying awake. 

Think of it as microsleeps. They aren't as helpful as a real sleep, but it keeps things going in the face of severe sleep deprivation. 

A sleep-deprived state is not how you want to live, but it's nice to know that lack of sleep won't kill you. 

Remind your brain about Mrs. Weston every time it starts acting up with drama on sleepless nights! 

**Ok, if my brain is planning on keeping me alive, why is it being so dramatic when I can't sleep?**

recd2BORcBgNHB2QP.Name: Lighting 1.1
recd2BORcBgNHB2QP.Bottom Body:
Are you ready to talk about lighting? Of course youre ready to talk about lighting.

As you may recall, light is the most important environmental cue to your circadian rhythm. Your exposure to light in the morning, daytime and evening all impacts how well you sleep.

To recap, heres what weve covered so far:

1. Darkness is one of the most important cues for sleep
2. Exposure to bright light before bed or during the night can disrupt sleep and suppress melatonin levels.
3. Black out curtains and sleep masks are awesome for blocking environmental light while you sleep.

Great!

Now lets move onto some extra tips for dealing with environmental light **before** bedtime!

recd3Ilq5EL1QcGdE.Name: QuickwinFA8.3
recd3Ilq5EL1QcGdE.Bottom Body:
**The 54321 method!**

You can use this method any time you feel stressed. It can be super helpful on those nights when you are laying in bed with a busy mind that just wont seem to shut off.

**How does it work?** Normally, this grounding technique uses the environment around you to name various objects that appeal to your senses. However, when doing it from bed, youll be relying on your imagination (or memory).

**Simply imagine**
- **5 things you can see**
- **4 things you can feel**
- **3 things you can hear**
- **2 things you can smell**
- **1 thing you can taste**

Take your time and try to truly visualize and experience each of the senses. 

If you want to repeat it, use your imagination to transport you to another room, planet, or dimension and do it all over again!

recd8YXblQ9eRdZXA.Name: meditation 1.6
recd8YXblQ9eRdZXA.Bottom Body:
**Is meditation for me?**

Meditation has been found to improve insomnia and boost the quality of sleep for people without sleep problems. This means that it's got benefits for everyone!

Incorporating a regular meditation practice is one of the most cost-effective and efficient ways to improve your overall health and wellbeing. 

You can try adding a track right before bed, doing a morning meditation with your coffee, or simply chanting some mantras in your car on the way to work. Do what works for you! Just try your best to be consistent and make it easy on yourself by stacking it with an already established habit. 

Message your sleep coach today if you'd like more info or tips on a meditation practice for sleep!

recd8fhtKoByvZ7VF.Name: goalsleepschedule1.4
recd8fhtKoByvZ7VF.Bottom Body:
Sticking to a schedule can be tricky. A lot of times it comes down to discipline. 

When those mornings come and you want to hit snooze, or something is good on Netflix and you want to stay up late, just ask yourself  "does this bring me closer to my goals?"

By obeying the call of your alarms and skipping daytime naps, you'll be able to move toward your goal of sticking with a sleep schedule.

recdCLThLLYXJ5oEt.Name: Sleepstress 1.4
recdCLThLLYXJ5oEt.Bottom Body:
When everything is in order, by the end of the day, these systems work together to send you off to slumberville.

When there is a mismatch in signalling, you can experience sleep-disrupting scenarios where you feel sleepy but alert, or simply dont feel tired when you should.

Learning how to use your own biology along with cues from your environment can help you regain control of your sleep. You can quite literally program yourself to sleep better.

recdDBihrQMl2EygH.Name: action 1.1
recdDBihrQMl2EygH.Bottom Body:
In order to get started on your journey to better sleep we wanted to give you one of the most important changes you can make. 

This little adjustment will help to regulate your circadian rhythm, boost your sleep system, and improve the sleep you get. It will also serve as a basic part of your overall sleep plan.

What is it?

recdZZtZm4vfdmKFz.Name: cantsleep 1.1
recdZZtZm4vfdmKFz.Bottom Body:
Some nights it's hard to fall asleep. We get it. In fact, 60% of people experience awakening during the night and find it hard to get back to sleep.

Even though it's uncomfortable, knowing how to deal with sleeplessness is vital in your path to rebooting your sleep. It will also ensure you don't develop unhealthy patterns with sleeplessness that leads to (or worsens) insomnia.

**Action plan**
We've already told you that it's best to leave the bed when you can't sleep. Now let's take a deeper dive into the dos and don'ts of sleepless nights and how you can be better prepared to handle them with ease!

recdbmH23RZ0ZL8mx.Name: aboutyou 1.1
recdbmH23RZ0ZL8mx.Bottom Body:
In order to help you get the best sleep, we'd like to address one of the most common sleep disruptors that people experience  snoring. 

Snoring can occur due to a number of reasons and it can actually be pretty detrimental to your health! It can be a sign of a serious sleep disorder called sleep apnea.

Take [this quiz](https://www.mdcalc.com/stop-bang-score-obstructive-sleep-apnea) to see if you may be at risk. Always talk to your doctor if you feel like you may be experiencing symptoms of sleep apnea. 

**The snoring partner**
Even sleeping with a partner who snores can mess with your overall quality of sleep. Research has shown that sleeping with someone who snores can lead to awakenings up to 30 times per hour.

recdgMLGn6hPPPmh7.Name: wakingup 1.3
recdgMLGn6hPPPmh7.Bottom Body:
**Get started**
You should aim to journal somewhere within an hour before bedtime. Right before you go to sleep is fine!

Grab a journal, a pen you enjoy, and take 10-20 minutes to journal out your to-do list before you plan to sleep. 

If there's a looming duty that you have no action plan for, simply write "will revisit tomorrow". This allows your brain to close the curtain on that item. 

**ok, let's look at the next part of your action plan..**.

recdp76YzLYYw627O.Name: Wokeuptired 1.5
recdp76YzLYYw627O.Bottom Body:
Waking up tired can be incredibly frustrating. Especially if you felt like you slept ok. 

It's also important to know that waking up tired isn't always related to your sleep. It could simply be an off day and your body is fatigued. It could be nutrition, allergies, stress, or many other factors at work. 

So, what do you do when you wake up groggy?

Lets explore some ways to get that energy up without disrupting your sleep!

recdz6FxUQ0qEJfyz.Name: meditation 1.1
recdz6FxUQ0qEJfyz.Bottom Body:
**Meditation**

Meditation is one of the most effective tools for improving your sleep. It has been shown to improve the quality and stability of sleep through a few different mechanisms. 

Research has found that meditation practice is associated with:
- **Decreased stress hormones and improved emotional resilience**
- **Increased melatonin**
- **Better sleep stability**
- **Improved brain function**

Even just 10 minutes of meditation a day has profound benefits. 

Let's take a closer look at how meditation can boost your sleep...

receFaHM8wBgtoBii.Name: QuickwinFA 1.1
receFaHM8wBgtoBii.Bottom Body:
It's time for your first Quick Win! 

_Wait_, what the heck is a Quick Win again?

In case you forgot, Quick Wins will appear throughout your journeys. They are tiny habits, behaviors, or facts that help give you a boost in your journey toward better sleep!

receJIiV4DrHylCFR.Name: Why 1.1
receJIiV4DrHylCFR.Bottom Body:
Being unable to sleep sucks. Have you ever wondered why it feels like your mind is in such great turmoil when you can't sleep?

**It's because your brain is a little dramatic!**
You may have already noticed that trouble sleeping is often paired with catastrophic thoughts like:

- "my life is ruined if I can't sleep"
- "I'm going to die if I don't sleep"
- "ughhggaargghhhhhhhhhh"

**Physiological needs**
Here's the thing  sleep is an essential need. Just like how suddenly being unable to swallow might make you panic, being unable to sleep can also lead your brain to make dramatic conclusions. 

However, just like you won't die if you can't eat for a day, or week or even a month  missing sleep won't kill you. 

**wait, REALLY?**
receJIiV4DrHylCFR.Top Body: ## I can't sleep and it sucks

receKSXvaawaxB2VD.Name: UnexpectedStress 1.2
receKSXvaawaxB2VD.Bottom Body:
**Two-Arrow Approach**
Everyone knows what it's like to experience unwanted thoughts. You may also feel very familiar with the concept of "beating yourself up" over something that happened. 

This technique is designed to minimize the emotional pain you experience when something stressful or unexpected happens. 

**One arrow is better than two**
Stressful events cause negative feelings. This is a reality. The triggering event, or the reason you feel mad or upset, is known as an **arrow**. We often have a tendency to seek answers about _why _an event happened which causes feelings of guilt, shame, and failure. 

This reaction of turning blame inward is known as the **second arrow**.

**To recap**:
**Arrow 1**= The triggering event that causes emotional distress (i.e. a bad interaction with a cashier)
**Arrow 2**= Your reaction to how you responded to the triggering event (i.e. I'm a bad person because I was rude to the cashier)

The two-arrow approach is a means to eliminate unnecessary mental turmoil by limiting your pain to the first arrow. 

Think about it this way youve been hit by one arrow and it hurts. Now youre hitting yourself with a second arrow. Doesnt that hurt even more? Instead of waging a war on yourself, focus on the first arrow. It hurts, its uncomfortable, but it doesnt need to attract additional wounds. 

**Eliminate the second arrow**
Whenever you notice that youre being hard on yourself over a difficult event, remind yourself that one arrow is enough pain.

Eliminating the second arrow reduces the measure of discomfort surrounding a difficult event and can help make stress more manageable. 

It can also be a fairly quick fix for rumination.

receoV8SD0Ok9Q9k6.Name: caffeineSleep 1.4
receoV8SD0Ok9Q9k6.Bottom Body:
**Rule # 2** 
**Don't drink caffeine too late in the day**

Drinking caffeine after 2 pm can significantly disrupt your nightly slumber. Even if you feel like you sleep ok, it can decrease the quality of sleep you get. 

**Why?** It can take your body 8- 14 hours to metabolize caffeine. If you drink 200 mg of coffee at 5 pm, by 10 pm theres still 100 mg kicking around inside of you

**TIP:** Decaf has 15 to 30% of the caffeine dose of a regular cup of coffee! Also, watch out for sneaky caffeine in sodas, over-the-counter medication, chocolates, treats, and teas.

recewN0ZcC2HBuWsv.Name: Quickwin 1.3
recewN0ZcC2HBuWsv.Bottom Body:
**Quick win of the day**

Did you know that taking a warm shower or bath one hour before bed can help you fall asleep up to 36% faster? It's true! 

But why? Your body sleeps better when it's cool. Believe it or not, a warm shower or bath actually cools your core temperature, making ideal conditions for sleep!

ummmm, wait, what? how?

recf3foH2aai9UIzJ.Name: cantsleep 1.3
recf3foH2aai9UIzJ.Bottom Body:
**DO NOT GRAB YOUR PHONE**
The most common mistake people make when they cant go back to sleep is grabbing their phone. Its usually right there on the nightstand, its got entertainment in it, and its what we do when were bored.

When you wake up unexpectedly and cant fall back to sleep **do not grab your phone**. Why?
- **It emits blue light **which your eyes interpret as sunlight and is the most stimulating of all types of light. Blue light sends a signal to your brain that its daytime so stop producing melatonin. Melatonin helps us sleep. You see the problem here?

- **Its stimulating. **Your phone has a lot of stimulation risks in there. Notifications, emails, messages, work, ads, news, ahhhhh! Phones do a lot of great things but helping us fall back to sleep is not one of them.

recfEtRS63kpgG9aR.Name: Decompression 1.4
recfEtRS63kpgG9aR.Bottom Body:
**Journal**

Journaling is a very effective and scientifically supported way to reduce stress that might be keeping you up at bedtime.

By setting aside 10-20 minutes to journal every night, you will allow your mind to decompress and give yourself closure for the day!

Vent your thoughts, make notes about your day, create a to-do list for tomorrow, or just write whatever randomly pops into your mind!

Check out this [article](https://intercom.help/rested-health/en/articles/5128187-journal-your-way-to-better-sleep) for more details.


**Reading**

Picking up a good book can be a great way to unwind before bed. It doesn't work for everyone but it works REALLY WELL for some people. Reading is especially helpful as a habit swap for people who enjoy mindlessly scrolling on their phones before bed. 

Try grabbing a bedtime-friendly lamp bulb or book light, and set aside 30 minutes or so to wind down with a good book. If you're studying for anything, reading right before bedtime is also a great way to boost the information you retain! 

Talk about sleep smarts!

recfGd6bgG9fHvrsi.Name: sneaky 1.3
recfGd6bgG9fHvrsi.Bottom Body:
You may have guessed that caffeine and sleep don't mix so well. However, what you may not have known is that caffeine shows up in a lot of common foods, supplements and beverages. 

**Why should you care?**
It takes your body from 8-14 hours to metabolize caffeine. This means that it can impact your sleep long after you consume it. For instance, drinking two diet sodas in the evening is equivalent to a cup of coffee!

**Much too much** 
High doses of caffeine (>400mg), even if consumed earlier in the day, can also interfere with sleep quality. This is because caffeine blocks adenosine, a chemical that helps regulate sleep. 

So, where is caffeine sneaking in?

recfrFdVSS9w4vMyr.Name: alcoholsleep 1.8
recfrFdVSS9w4vMyr.Bottom Body:
The world loves alcohol, but at the end of the day, our bodies treat it as a toxin. 

That doesn't mean you need to quit (that's always up to you). However, understanding the negative impacts that alcohol has on your sleep can help you to make informed decisions and better understand some struggles you may be having with sleep. 

At a minimum, skip the nightcap and swap in some non-alcoholic beer, chamomile tea, or another soothing beverage. These can fill the void and actually help you sleep better! 

If you have any questions about what you've learned here, you can check out our [article on alcohol](https://intercom.help/rested-health/en/articles/4973555-alcohol-ruins-sleep-more-than-you-think) or message your sleep coach!

recfsCM69JEKAzfmz.Name: summary 1.5
recfsCM69JEKAzfmz.Bottom Body:
**Sleep and Stress**

In this section, we learned about how stress can have a negative impact on sleep. One of the key reasons is due to **subconscious sleep stress**  that's when your brain creates unhelpful programs for how your body reacts to trying to fall asleep!

Stress can impact your ability to fall asleep but can also lead to lower quality of sleep and even impact your dreams! Learning how to effectively manage your stress is one of the most effective ways to improve your sleep. 

In order to help you get started on lowering your stress, we then talked about **cognitive restructuring**...

recftk27o36wBfhL7.Name: QuickwinFA 8.1
recftk27o36wBfhL7.Bottom Body:
Its that time again! Time for another Reboot Camp Quick Win!

Yay!

This one is awesome because you can do it while youre already all comfy in your bed.

Are you ready to hear how another classic grounding technique can help you sleep faster at night?

recftsiO7tBRI29uQ.Name: Circadian 1.8
recftsiO7tBRI29uQ.Bottom Body:
Now youve learned how various environmental cues can impact your circadian rhythm.

Living in a modern society means that our environmental cues are no longer all taken from nature. With artificial light sources, confined work schedules, and common bad habits, its easy to see how so many people have circadian rhythms that are misaligned.

The true secret to better sleep is learning how to live in modern society and still work with your bodys natural rhythms.

It takes some time to figure out, but were here to help you every step along the way.

recfxy1JTcHMNMUt7.Name: bedtimeroutine 1.1
recfxy1JTcHMNMUt7.Bottom Body:
**Bedtime routines**

As we discussed in week 2, bedtime routines are one of the most important things you can do to decompress at the end of the day and get your mind and body ready for sleep. 

They also tend to act as a cue for "bedtime" which can further help your sleep!

You already started building a bedtime routine by putting away your electronics at least 30 minutes before bed and adding in some mental decompression.

Let's talk about how you can level up your bedtime routine...

recg1pVtXZYwTniPB.Name: Whatsitabout 1.2
recg1pVtXZYwTniPB.Bottom Body:
**Skills on skills**
Together we'll be working on a variety of skills that will help you better manage negative thought loops and stress, and build healthy routines that naturally optimize your sleep system. 

By gaining and building on skills like mental flexibility, cognitive restructuring, and mindfulness, you'll feel empowered to tackle whatever life throws your way!

You don't need to go to a doctor's office or pay thousands to a sleep therapist. Everything you need is right here in the palm of your hand.

recg58MdrzMF9A4pV.Name: basics 1.1
recg58MdrzMF9A4pV.Bottom Body:
**Don't hit snooze on the basics**
In order to become a true sleep master, well need to get aligned on sleep language and basic sleep knowledge. Even if you feel like you already know it all, a little review is helpful (plus, you might learn something new!)

To kick things off, well cover:
1. **Circadian rhythm**
2. **Sleep drive**
3. **Sleep architecture**

Let's go!

recg6AU5H73sr8Xcs.Name: BasicsQ 1.5
recg6AU5H73sr8Xcs.Bottom Body:
Next, let's take a moment to remember everything you learned about "Your relationship with sleep"

If you recall, this journey looked at your relationship with sleep! It's complicated. 

Let's take the quiz...

recg8kvOQYyzwRE5u.Name: Mornings 1.1
recg8kvOQYyzwRE5u.Bottom Body:
Do you ever find it hard to get out of bed in the morning?

Have you ever ran headfirst into your day feeling overwhelmed before noon?

Morning rituals can help with that.

Developing a morning ritual is an excellent way to boost your mornings, get more out of your day, and promote better sleep at night. You can also use it to optimize your circadian rhythm!

Even if you arent a morning person, theres still a routine for you!

Lets take a look at how morning rituals can improve your life...

recgHhU392gliFqt0.Name: Substances 1.4
recgHhU392gliFqt0.Bottom Body:
Drinking too much coffee or drinking it too late in the day can disrupt your bodys natural processes for sleep and keep your system in a state of arousal long after the caffeine buzz has worn off.

**Why?**

**Because caffeine is slowly metabolized**

Did you know that it can take your body **8- 14 hours** to metabolize caffeine? This means that if you have any caffeine after 2 pm it can leave you buzzing into bedtime.

As an example, if you drink 200 mg of coffee at 5 pm, by 10 pm theres still 100 mg kicking around inside of you. Yeesh.

recgLAAtpYuIHpN5Y.Name: week 3.4
recgLAAtpYuIHpN5Y.Bottom Body:
**Problem solving- snoring and sleepless nights**

In the last part of this week, we'll look at the best way to deal with sleepless nights and introduce you to building a Hygge Space! Then we'll talk about how to assess whether you snore and what you can do about it if you do! 

**The extras**
Along the way, you'll also get more quick wins, tips for stress relief, and continue to work on restructuring unhelpful thoughts!

As always, feel free to go at your own pace and reach out to your sleep coach if you have any questions!

recgNoJcLfIRnkHi6.Name: Unlearn 1.4
recgNoJcLfIRnkHi6.Bottom Body:
Remember subconscious sleep stress? It can lead to chronic sleep problems.

**Sleep stress leads to sleep stress**
In the same way that watching TV in bed leads your brain to associate TV + Bed, stressing in bed over being unable to sleep leads to chronic sleep problems.

**Why?** Because being stressed out in bed over the inability to sleep leads to a program in your brain that anticipates the inability to sleep. 

**Journey with us a moment:**
Imagine this...It's 2 am, you're trying to sleep and just cannot fall asleep. You feel stressed, angry, overwhelmed and you lay in bed cursing the sleep gods.

Your brain then begins creating a new program: 
- "cursing the sleep gods" + "bed"  

After a few times, your mind will then anticipate stress and inability to sleep with your bed! The more it happens  the stronger the links grow. 

**Forecasting the pain**
This is why many people with sleep issues tend to anticipate sleep issues which then becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.

recgPKjuWewdrAJaD.Name: goalfallasleepfaster1.5
recgPKjuWewdrAJaD.Bottom Body:
Like with everything else, we don't expect you to perfect these two things immediately.

However, it's really important that you begin to learn the difference between fatigue and sleepiness   and only go to bed with you are sleepy! 

It won't fix your difficulties falling asleep immediately, but, these steps are your keys to retraining your mind and body for sleep.

recgPu16rBmivP2cN.Name: quickwinFA 3.1
recgPu16rBmivP2cN.Bottom Body:
It's time for another handy-dandy quick win!

As you begin to implement some new habits that bring you closer to your goal of falling asleep faster, it can be hard. Change isn't always easy!

We want you to be successful, so today's quick win is one that will help you more easily build new habits...

recgeVrwdBbUDtmRz.Name: quickwins 3.1

We see you out there trying to make positive changes in your life. It can be hard sometimes, right?

recgjr7uf2yaGEKQD.Name: Noise 1.3
recgjr7uf2yaGEKQD.Bottom Body:
You may struggle to eliminate all of the noises in your sleeping environment, such as a partner snoring or if you live too close to a high-traffic area.

Luckily, we have some tips to help with that!

Want to hear the first tip?

recgm0rfCm3qw0i5n.Name: Bedroom 1.3
recgm0rfCm3qw0i5n.Bottom Body:
**Black out curtains!**

Even if the sun has gone down, there can still be environmental light such as street lights that can impede on your circadian rhythm.

Blackout curtains will block any light pollution from your environment (which can be extremely helpful for shift workers or anyone who many need to sleep during daylight).

Not ready to invest in new curtains? Dont worry, we have another tip...

recgofuoxzifACR1Z.Name: week3summary 1.3
recgofuoxzifACR1Z.Bottom Body:
**2. Picking a bedtime**
You learned how to calculate a good bedtime using this formula:
- The average sleep cycle is 90 minutes long and you should get around 4-5 full sleep cycles a night.
- 90 x 5 = 450 minutes, or 7.5 hours
- Starting at your wake time, work back 7.5 hours to find your ideal bedtime!

We also discussed how it's important to only go to bed when you are sleepy, not when fatigued. Learning to differentiate sleepy from just feeling tired is very important for keeping a regular schedule, optimizing your sleep system, and ensuring you don't have your head hit the pillow and suddenly feel alert.

recgqyOkdZl3JeCRm.Name: spower 1.4
recgqyOkdZl3JeCRm.Bottom Body:
**Your brain on sleep**
As you slumber each night, your brain stays very active. What's it doing?

Each night your brain goes through several unique stages of activity that each come with their own benefits. 

**Sleep is when your brain stays busy:**
- Clearing out toxic waste and byproducts
- Normalizing connections (called synapses) to prepare your brain for new experiences
- Storing memories
- Processing and regulating emotions
- Reorganizing thoughts and experiences (it even boosts creativity)


Want to know a fun fact?

recgrnMfpdmZLfofv.Name: Waketime 1.2
recgrnMfpdmZLfofv.Bottom Body:
**The importance of waking up at the same time every day**

Heres the thing, its very difficult to go to bed at the same time every night. That means waking up at the same time every day is your number one key to regulating your circadian rhythm.

**But, I wanna sleep in!?!?**
Yes, it can be a pain. Yes, you sacrifice sleep from time to time. But, its actually worth it! Once you get over the difficult part, you will reap the many benefits to gain from optimizing your circadian rhythm.

Your body is designed to function this way and it will help optimize all your body processes that run on a circadian rhythm. Thats basically everything.

So, make sure you stick to this one. Set your alarm in advance so that it goes off at the same time every day.

And just get on up and start your day. You wont regret it.

recgxZGXHidVVlIcn.Name: Orientation 1.2
recgxZGXHidVVlIcn.Bottom Body:
**Pace yourself**
If youre loving Reboot Camp and psyched to keep going at a faster pace, great! If youre enjoying Reboot Camp but youd prefer to learn at a slower pace, thats also great!

There is no wrong way to do it as long as youre committed to better sleep.

This next part is going to focus on **YOU** and **your relationship with sleep**.

And were going to start reeeeeally basic.

rech49ezPU10od4di.Name: Noise 1.6
rech49ezPU10od4di.Bottom Body:
So, now you know that environmental noise can impede on your sleep and mess with your deep restorative sleep. Boooooo!

But! You can eliminate environmental noise by using a **sound machine** or **ear plugs**! Yaaaaaay!

Ok, cool. Lets journey on and find out more sweet facts about your sleep environment!

rechaV0I3huyr9R5O.Name: relearn 1.5 copy
rechaV0I3huyr9R5O.Bottom Body:
**When leaving your bed because you cant sleep:**
1. **Dont use your phone, computer or watch TV:** These will all suppress your melatonin and make it harder to fall asleep. The only exception is cueing up a podcast or meditation track to help you relax.
2. **Dont fall asleep in the new location:** As soon as you feel tired again, head back to bed and try for round 2.
3. **Do something relaxing/boring:** Try reading or listening to the radio or an audiobook. You can also do a meditation track, some light stretching, or yoga.
4. **Low light:** Stay away from bright lights to help your body know that it's not "wake-up" time. Dimmers and motion-sensor nightlights are great tools for this!

If you head back to bed and have trouble sleeping again, repeat the process. Youll keep repeating it until you finally find sleep (we realize this sounds awful, but it works).

rechiewylyHP2LSdM.Name: Circadian 1.6
rechiewylyHP2LSdM.Bottom Body:
**Eating**
Your circadian rhythm enjoys a consistent schedule and eating at unusual times can disrupt it.

The relationship between the timing of meals and your circadian rhythm is primarily controlled by insulin. Your metabolism shifts throughout the day and most people benefit by eating larger meals earlier in the day.

Skipping breakfast, eating large meals late at night, and fasting can all be disruptive to your circadian rhythm. However, everyone is unique.

The most important factor with eating is to remain fairly consistent in your mealtimes.

rechkTo2lCnUh49nR.Name: general 1.3
rechkTo2lCnUh49nR.Bottom Body:
**Visualization or guided imagery**

This powerful decompression technique uses your imagination to transport yourself to peaceful and relaxing settings. Studies have found that visualizing an experience can lead to patterns of brain activity that mirror how your brain reacts to the real-life experience!

**Get started**
The easiest way is to use a guided track that's targeted at stress reduction or relaxation. 

If you feel comfortable, you can try it on your own.

**Here's how...**

rechmbU34CwXkIvWL.Name: Blue light 1.5
rechmbU34CwXkIvWL.Bottom Body:
**1. Unplug, reduce, put away**
Do your best to reduce your screen time during the day. Ideally, you should put your electronics away 2 hours before you intend to go to sleep. If that's too difficult, start out by putting them away 30 minutes before bed and work your way up. 

It can be hard to make these changes right away, especially if your current bedtime routine includes watching tv or scrolling your phone (we know change is no fun, especially when were coming for your electronics!)

If you were using your phone to "unwind" before bed, try swapping in a book, crossword, or even a bedtime story or meditation! Do something you enjoy that doesn't involve a screen.

If you **must **use electronics in the evening, you can use the following tips to minimize the impact of blue light...

rechpWDhyLUt6o3ZS.Name: Substances 1.3
rechpWDhyLUt6o3ZS.Bottom Body:
First, well start with caffeine.

**Caffeine and sleep**
Caffeine is a stimulant. You probably already know that.

It pumps you up by boosting adrenaline. It also reduces melatonin. These are perfectly fine qualities for the morning.

Another way caffeine makes you feel alert is by blocking adenosine (remember, thats what builds sleep pressure all day!).

So, how does this affect your sleep?

reciWZpePV8kD9tnx.Name: sleepmyths 2.3
reciWZpePV8kD9tnx.Bottom Body:
**4. Getting used to less sleep**

Another common myth is that your body can adjust to getting less sleep. Many people believe that they can train themselves to need less sleep. This is false. While you may adjust to some of the feelings of fatigue during the day, your body never adjusts to a "shortened sleep schedule." 

Over time, chronic sleep deprivation can increase your risk of many health problems such as heart disease, diabetes, and even dementia. Consistently undersleeping may even shorten your lifespan. 

**Fun fact: Humans are the only mammals that willfully deny themselves of sleep**

**Get Rested**
While the optimal amount of sleep will vary from person to person, purposefully denying your body of the sleep it needs on a regular basis is never a good decision. 

If you are regularly missing sleep due to problems sleeping, you're in the right place! We can show you how to reboot your sleep system and get the rest you deserve!

recidbH3hIdrOX3ml.Name: Sleepstress 1.2
recidbH3hIdrOX3ml.Bottom Body:
To better understand sleep, it's important that you understand some of the biological processes that drive sleep!

We won't expect you to be an expert and we'll give you cool graphs to make it more fun.

To kick things off, let's look at the two main processes that drive your need for sleep! 

**Sleep drive** and **Circadian Alerting System**

recivLQEqPJgL89gI.Name: Oriented 1.1
recivLQEqPJgL89gI.Bottom Body:
**Let's get oriented**
Rested Health wants you to sleep better. We want you to feel like you have a fully-loaded support system that you can depend on.

Let's introduce you to each part of your Rested Health support system.

Within Rested Health you have access to:
1. **Journey Cards**
2. **Sleep Library**
3. **Sleep Coach**

What does each of these contain? Let's take a look!

recj0KmIsU1cM5Loj.Name: models 1.6
recj0KmIsU1cM5Loj.Bottom Body:
**4. Unconsciously competent**: "I know how to fix my problem and I've been practicing a lot so my habits feel automatic"

Look at us, we're at the top of the ladder! It's nice up here!

The final rung on the competence ladder is when your new habits and skills become automatic. That means, they don't require so much mental energy to do.

You now have confidence in your new skill! 

**Can I get off the ladder now?**
No! If you stop practicing your new skills, you'll end up sliding back down the ladder. 

Improving your sleep is just like any other skill, there's no true ceiling. Just like if you went through bootcamp to get fit, you'd need to keep working out in order to stay fit. 

However, those new habits and skills you build become your **foundation for good sleep**. 

Sound good?

recj0acYTRbC0OlEr.Name: change 1.4
recj0acYTRbC0OlEr.Bottom Body:
**2. Scope**

Another common mistake people make is being unrealistic in the scope of their goals. By diving headfirst into too many changes, you are more likely to fail. 

**How do I avoid it?**
As you begin implementing changes that bring you closer to your goals, have patience. Setting smaller achievable goals and making tiny changes will set you up for success. We'll help you out. 

**It's raining wins**
Those daily small wins add up and bring you closer to where you want to be. 

The author of Atomic Habits, James Clear put it this way:
"If you get one percent better each day for one year, youll end up thirty-seven times better by the time youre done"

recjHn3VuIhMRXCPb.Name: week 2.4
recjHn3VuIhMRXCPb.Bottom Body:
**Tracking your progress**

Tracking your progress can be very helpful in making sure you are on track to achieve your goals. 

In this section, we'll talk about some different ways to track your sleep quality and you can decide what works best for you!

recjRpRE7QBP9zAA8.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.7
recjRpRE7QBP9zAA8.Bottom Body:
**Sleeping in a warm room is disruptive to the quality of sleep you get**.

A warm temperature might make you feel warm and cozy, but it goes against your bodys natural sleep state.

Heres the deal, your circadian rhythm causes your body to cool down at night and continue cooling until the wee hours of the morning. This is to optimize melatonin and maintain quality sleep.

Therefore, sleeping in a room with **a cooler temperature will give you a better quality of sleep.**

Research has found that sleeping in warmer rooms reduces sleep quality and quantity.

The exact temperature is personal, but there is an official ideal temperature for sleep that you should try and stick with.

So, what temperature should you set it to?

recjlW87RTPNsepxE.Name: CircRhythm 1.3
recjlW87RTPNsepxE.Bottom Body:
**Finding your Rhythm**
Understanding your circadian rhythm becomes a little bit easier when you learn about _why_ its designed the way it is. This can also help you better understand what is normal! 

**The call of the wild**
Circadian rhythms are present in all animals. Our bodys ability to regulate our sleep-wake cycle was essential for survival back when we had to hunt and gather. 

We used environmental cues and relied on staying in tune with our bodys natural rhythms in order to optimally use the world around us and to provide for our families.

Nowadays we are less likely to live in caves and more likely to eat packaged foods, but these same biological processes are still going strong.

Here are some cools facts about your circadian rhythm...

recjmMuVbweXCqpLF.Name: Tracking 1.9

Headband trackers are new on the market and targeted specifically for sleep. Headbands are light, comfortable, and come with associated apps aimed at helping you understand your sleep habits improve your sleep schedule. 

They come equipped with sensors that measure brain wave activity (similar to devices used in sleep study labs).

**Popular Head wearables:**
- **Headband** (Dreem, Muse, Sleep Sheppard)
- **Smart Sleepmask** (Neuroon sleepmask)

**Pros:** They offer information that used to only be available through sleep studies and can more accurately measure sleep cycles.

reck17LC9uO2soaTn.Name: sleepmyths 2.4
reck17LC9uO2soaTn.Bottom Body:
**5. You sleep better as the night goes on**

A lot of people believe that all of the "good sleep" happens in the second half of the night. 

The truth? You actually get more of your deep sleep in the first half of the night! This is the most restorative sleep from which it's more difficult to be awoken. So, your sleep is actually deeper and more restorative during the first half of the night.

**Traveling through sleep cycles**
As the night goes on, your body cycles through several stages of sleep and spends more time in light stages and REM sleep (when you do most of your dreaming) as it gets closer to morning. 

This is why it's more common for people to experience awakenings in the second half of the night. It also means that a great deal of restoration is done in the initial hours of your sleep. 

**Fun fact:** Waking up during the lighter stages of sleep is pretty normal. It's a genetic instinct from prehistoric days when you had to be on high alert for dangers!

reckQWjWy2Jc7bclQ.Name: Circadian 1.5
reckQWjWy2Jc7bclQ.Bottom Body:
**Temperature**

Temperature is another important environmental cue for your circadian rhythm. Your body temperature fluctuates throughout the day to sync with your sleep-wake cycle.

For example, it rises toward the morning as your body produces wakefulness-boosting cortisol. Your temperature then drops at night, as your body releases melatonin for sleep.

Sleeping in a cool room at night is a way to improve your sleep because it works with your bodys natural preferences! Similarly, getting too warm before bed or sleeping in a hot room can disrupt your circadian rhythm.

reckYwTB8uT4WxTMv.Name: Quickwin 8.3
reckYwTB8uT4WxTMv.Bottom Body:
**How to do Box Breathing**

Simply sit or lay down somewhere comfortable and do the following:

1. **Inhale**: Slowly inhale through your nose for the count of 4. Notice your belly pushing out as your lungs fill up with air.
2. **Hold your breath**: Hold your breath for another count of 4.
3. **Exhale**: Slowly exhale through your mouth for a count of 4.
4. **Hold your breath**: Once your lungs are empty, hold your breath again for another count of, you guessed it, 4!

4x4x4x4 just like a box! This should make it super easy for you to remember.

And since 4 is the magic number here, we are going to recommend you repeat it 4 times to get started. As you get better you can do it for longer!

**Boost your mornings and exercise**

Building a simple morning routine can be beneficial to your sleep in a number of ways.

Learns the dos and don'ts of mornings and how to structure a morning routine that boosts your productivity and sleep!

reclXWoKhpQkZW5r5.Name: pickingbedtime 1.2
reclXWoKhpQkZW5r5.Bottom Body:
**Your ideal bedtime**
Everyone's sleep needs are unique. To get started, you can calculate your sleep needs by using simple sleep cycle math. 

**Get your ideal sleep time**
- The average sleep cycle is 90 minutes long and you should get around 4-5 full sleep cycles a night.
- 90 x 5 = 450 minutes, or 7.5 hours
- Starting at your wake time, work back 7.5 hours to find your ideal bedtime!

So, since you've been waking up at the same time every morning (you have, right?), this math should be pretty easy.

For instance, if you wake up at 7:30 am, your ideal "I'm asleep" time is 12am, which means you should aim to be in bed around 11:40pm.

recljpiXUXEKtJ7sm.Name: week 2.2
recljpiXUXEKtJ7sm.Bottom Body:
**Stimulus Control**
One of the most important tools used by sleep therapists is something called **Stimulus Control**. It is the foundation of rebooting your relationship with sleep. 

**What is stimulus control?**

Stimulus control is a set of habits and instructions that strengthens the relationship between bed and sleep and weakens the relationship between bed and wakefulness. 

The entire process is built upon how your brain builds its programming. Believe it or not, you've already started working on stimulus control by building a consistent wake time!

**We'll cover the basics of stimulus control in these sections:**
- Unlearning how to sleep
- Relearning how to sleep

recmAE9wTbizcpZKV.Name: Substances 1.5
recmAE9wTbizcpZKV.Bottom Body:
**The friend that won't leave**
Because it takes your body so long to metabolize caffeine, if you consume it later in the day it can:
- make it harder to fall asleep
- reduce the quality of your sleep

To make things even trickier, caffeine can be really sneaky! You can find it in snacks, sodas, and even in some over-the-counter medications!

**How to avoid caffeine problems**
So, to avoid the impact of caffeine on sleep, follow these rules:
1. No caffeine after 2pm
2. Try and stick with around 400mg a day (~2-3 cups of coffee)
3. Watch out for sneaky caffeine in things like headache medicine, pre-workout, chocolate, and sodas!

OK, that wasnt so bad, right? Lets move on to alcohol and sleep...

recmMR10no04sXcqm.Name: week3summary 1.2
recmMR10no04sXcqm.Bottom Body:
**1. Sleep stages and sleep stability**
- **Stages: **We learned that there are 2 types of sleep, non-rapid eye movement and rapid eye movement sleep which can be further broken down into:
    - Stages N1, N2, N3, and REM
- **Sleep Cycles:** Your body goes through around four 90 minute sleep cycles each night. During the first half you spend more time in deep sleep and as the night goes on you spend more time in REM.
- **Health benefits:** Each stage of sleep has unique health benefits that help prepare your body for the day ahead. N1 and N2 help with processing emotions and memory, deep sleep is very restorative to tissues and muscles, and REM helps with memory consolidation, emotional wellbeing, and creative thinking. 
- **Sleep stability**: Sleep stability is a measure of your quality of sleep as you travel through the sleep stages. It can be improved by keeping a regular schedule, stimulus control (bed + sleep), exercise, and pink or white noise machines.

3. **Venting**: It helps you get better at expressing your emotions, frustrations, and stress.
4. **Historical masterpiece:** It creates a cool little historical log! 

To get started, dedicate yourself to journaling at least 3 nights this week. Pick those nights now!

To make sure it sticks, you can send your sleep coach a message saying "Please remind me to journal at 9pm on Tuesday, Thursday, and Sunday this week." Otherwise, we suggest you put a reminder in your phone.

recmlMqui5XbV4ikP.Name: quickwinFA 3.2
recmlMqui5XbV4ikP.Bottom Body:
**Habit-stacking**

You may or may not have heard of habit-stacking. Either way, it's important to understand how you can use this concept to help you build new habits around sleep!

**What is habit-stacking**
Building new habits is hard and mentally taxing. One excellent technique that makes building new habits WAY easier is habit-stacking. 

You take your new habit that you want to build and you combine it with a habit you already have! For instance, if you want to add diaphragmatic breathing to your day  combine it with your morning cup of coffee (but, like, not while there's coffee in your mouth).

recmqoBMdmtcH2ctp.Name: Tracking 2.2
recmqoBMdmtcH2ctp.Bottom Body:
**What should you track in a sleep diary?**
Sleep diaries are meant to give helpful information and insights into what affects your sleep. It's ok if everything is not 100% accurate.

**What to track in your sleep diary:**
1. **Sleep and wake times**
2. **Awakenings during the night and why**
3. **Notes on any difficulties falling back asleep**
4. **Medications or drugs used that day**
5. **Naps during the day**
6. **Extras**- general mood, caffeine and alcohol consumption, time of last meal, exercise, and whether you completed your morning or evening rituals.

Athletes and people seeking peak performance might get extremely specific with noting factors like meal timing, fasting schedule, types of workout, and supplements used. 

For now, just keep it simple!

Why bother with a sleep diary, though?

More research needs to be done on all of the health-bosting benefits, but as for now, millions of people around the world swear by cold therapy!

**What about sleep?** Another helpful benefit of cold water is that it lowers your body temperature. This can help you fall asleep faster and get deeper sleep.

Lets look at how to do it!

If this happens, you can begin the entire process again. It may mean that you get less sleep, it may feel counterintuitive, but it will ensure that you don't get caught up in an endless cycle of struggling to sleep.

1. **They help set your day off in a positive tone**
2. **They are happiness boosting**
3. **They help you sleep better at night by optimizing your circadian rhythm**

Your morning ritual doesnt have to be elaborate or time-consuming. Its actually pretty important that you look forward to doing it (otherwise it will feel like a chore).

Understanding how morning rituals can improve your life is also important because were more likely to do things when we know why they benefit us!

You've already started out a morning ritual by getting up at the same time every morning and grabbing a glass of water.

recnsXyV69ItSQ95d.Name: sleepstages 1.2
recnsXyV69ItSQ95d.Bottom Body:
**The different stages of sleep are also associated with unique health benefits:**

**NREM Stage 1 (N1):** You spend a great deal of time in light sleep. During that time your brain processes emotions and memories and your metabolism regulates itself. 

**NREM Stage 2 (N2):** During this stage of sleep you experience little bursts of brain activity called sleep spindles. These are believed to be important for forming memories. 

**NREM Stage 3 (N3):** This deep stage of sleep is extremely important for muscle repair, tissue regrowth, and strengthening the immune system. 

**REM Sleep: **REM sleep is believed to be important for forming memories, stimulating our nervous systems, and balancing chemicals in our brains. It is also believed to be important for creative thinking and problem-solving!

**Fun fact:** When you dream your brain does not follow logic. That's why dreams are so weird and also why they are hard to remember. The benefit is that your brain is able to process complex ideas and experiences without the constraints of logic, which researchers believe plays an important role in creativity and problem-solving!

Caffeine is the most widely consumed psychostimulant on the planet. The most popular form is coffee. Mmmmmm coffee. 

In order to make sure that you get the most out of your caffeine without it disrupting your sleep, it's best to follow some guidelines. 

Come along, let us show you the Rested Health guide to caffeine...

recoN6HZzgYiqSER5.Name: Decompression 1.2
recoN6HZzgYiqSER5.Bottom Body:
As we mentioned, developing a consistent bedtime routine acts as an **environmental cue** that lets your brain know its time to sleep.

Your brain appreciates consistent signals and routines.

**Dividing your day from your night**
A bedtime routine removes any confusion about whats next and brings closure to your day. This separation between day and night cues your brain to send out those sleepy-time hormones.

You can also implement strategies within your evening ritual that help to quiet your mind, relax your body, and improve the quality of your sleep.See, we told you bedtime routines are great!

recoP2eRLxOqQwQgC.Name: summary 1.2
recoP2eRLxOqQwQgC.Bottom Body:
**Sleep Myths: Fact or Fiction**

- **Sleep needs:** Everyone is unique. The recommendation of 7-8 hours a night is an estimate and you may need more or less!
- **Sleep quality:** Sleep quality has nothing to do with how many dreams you remember or whether you moved during the night. Also, when it comes to sleep, quality is better than quantity. 
- **Getting up on the wrong side of the bed:** Feeling irritable or stressed during the day is not always due to how you slept. 
- **Catching up on missed sleep:** You can't really catch up on missed sleep, instead, try sticking with your sleep schedule and letting your sleep homeostat do its thing!
- **Getting used to less sleep**: Your body never adjusts to chronic sleep deprivation and you cannot train yourself to need less sleep.
- **You get better sleep as the night goes on:** The first half of the night is when you get the majority of your restorative sleep. 

Next, we began your first habit toward rebooting your sleep system...

recoe8v6ZiRaLXSkn.Name: Overview 1.5
recoe8v6ZiRaLXSkn.Bottom Body:
**A bedtime routine can help you fall asleep faster**

Bedtime routines are one of the most important things you can do to decompress at the end of the day and get your mind and body ready for sleep, as long as it doesnt include sleep disruptors like electronics!

Design a Power Down Hour that youll do every night. After some consistency, your brain will associate your power down activities with bedtime which will trigger your bodys sleep signals.

Try to include things like journaling or progressive muscle relaxation to decompress.

Unplug from your electronics at least 2 hours before bed or use blue light blocking programs or blue light blocking glasses to ensure that blue light isnt going to be energizing you when you want to be decompressing.

recofSlqOQ7iSNqWC.Name: QuickwinFA 13.3
recofSlqOQ7iSNqWC.Bottom Body:
**How to do Box Breathing**

Simply sit or lay down somewhere comfortable and do the following:

1. **Inhale**: Slowly inhale through your nose for the count of 4. Notice your belly pushing out as your lungs fill up with air.
2. **Hold your breath**: Hold your breath for another count of 4.
3. **Exhale**: Slowly exhale through your mouth for a count of 4.
4. **Hold your breath**: Once your lungs are empty, hold your breath again for, you guessed it, another count of 4.

4x4x4x4 just like a box! This should make it super easy for you to remember.

And since 4 is the magic number here, we are going to recommend you repeat it 4 times to get started. As you get better you can do it for longer!

recogqlqr4Xh2ri4T.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.1
recogqlqr4Xh2ri4T.Bottom Body:
**Your brain on sleep stress**
We've explained why it normal to have dramatic thoughts when you have trouble sleeping. Let's get to work on techniques for dealing with unhelpful or distressing thoughts!

**Heavy thinking**
A lot of people experience thoughts that are irrational or exaggerated. It can get especially bad when you can't sleep.

**For example, you may find yourself:**

 **Forecasting the future:** "I just know I'm not going to be able to sleep tonight"

 **Overgeneralizing:** "There's something seriously wrong with me, I'll never sleep well"

 **Catastrophizing:** "I'm going to get sick and die if I don't fall asleep"

These are all examples of what psychologists call **cognitive distortions**, and they can have a pretty big impact on your wellbeing.

Even if you have thoughts like this during the day it can impact your sleep because they lead to an activation of your stress system.

recohO9C1mgPR72xa.Name: Grogginess 1.6
recohO9C1mgPR72xa.Bottom Body:
We know youll likely turn to caffeine when youre tired, so heres how to make your caffeine work better for you:

**Caffeine hack on low energy days**
Wait until 90 minutes after your wake up time to drink your coffee. Thats when your wakefulness hormones start to decline and your body will best use the caffeine.

Next, take L-Theanine with your coffee. Taking a dose of 50 mg of L-Theanine with 100 mg of caffeine can significantly improve attention and cognitive performance, better than just coffee alone! As a bonus, it also reduces your bodys stress response.

That means no caffeine jitters (theyre always worse when youre tired, arent they?)


\*\*Always talk to your doctor before starting any new supplements

By setting the record straight on actual sleep needs, how to measure sleep quality, and busting common myths, you'll be able to reduce some anxiety around your sleep immediately! 

Some information may not be new, but it's always good to review the basics when you begin a new program! 

Are you ready? Let's go!

recpU3G68JmVv98PV.Name: goalsleepthrunight1.3
recpU3G68JmVv98PV.Bottom Body:
**2. Leave the bed when you can't sleep**

It's 3am, you've awoken with all of the energy in the world but all you want to do is sleep.

**What do you do?** If you wake up during the night and can't fall back to sleep within 20 minutes  leave your bed. Staying in bed struggling with sleep will only build unhelpful associations between frustration and your bed. 

Instead  leave your bed and go do a relaxing activity in a dimly lit room. Try reading, meditating, or listening to a boring podcast. There are boring podcasts made just for this exact reason! Once you feel sleepy again, return to your bed.

**What if I can't sleep when I go back to bed?** If it's been longer than 20 minutes and you can't sleep  repeat the process again!

It is a technique where you engage in deep breathing in a specific pattern.

Deep breathing activates your parasympathetic nervous system which sends signals to your body to calm down!

recpvZQ6Ss9VcsShq.Name: Mornings 1.3
recpvZQ6Ss9VcsShq.Bottom Body:
**Treat yourself to some sunshine!**

As we discussed, light exposure is one of the most important cues for optimizing your circadian rhythm. Getting even just 10 minutes of sun exposure early in the morning can help you sleep better at night. 

Benefits of early morning sunshine:
- **Happiness boost**: Sunshine boosts serotonin levels which can elevate your feelings of happiness and wellbeing and improve your focus. 
- **Circadian optimization:** Sunshine regulates your circadian rhythm by telling your body when to increase and decrease your melatonin levels. 
- **Stress relief**: The melatonin regulating benefits of sunshine also helps reduce your stress levels and boost sleep (which also reduces stress). 

**When to add in some sun**
The ideal window for sun exposure for most people is between 8am and noon. 

**Do I need sunscreen?** You can skip the sunscreen and sunglasses if you're just going out for a little boost. Your body begins producing vitamin D after about 5 to 35 minutes in the sun. 

If you plan on spending more than 20 minutes in the sun, you should opt for sun protection. 

**How to add sunshine into your morning routine...**

recpzaAvinmOIazd6.Name: Exercise 1.5
recpzaAvinmOIazd6.Bottom Body:
But are there times when exercise interferes with sleep?

There are two ways that exercise can interfere with sleep:
1. **Raising your core temperature**
2. **Energizing you**

In general, exercise only interferes with sleep for some people when its done close to bedtime and when it includes intense aerobic exercise or interval training.

Some research has found that strength training and flexibility training close to bed can actually help sleep.

Engaging in small achievable changes like drinking a glass of water when you get up creates a sense of accomplishment and enforces a new habit. **How do I know if I slept well?**

When you're getting the sleep you need you'll notice a few key things:
- You fall asleep within 30 minutes
- Waking up isn't a huge struggle
- Your hunger pangs aren't out of control 
- You're not craving junk food or caffeine boosts
- You feel less reactive to your world
- Everything is a little better

You can also use a wearable device like a smartwatch to help you monitor some aspects of your sleep. These devices aren't perfect but they will give you a general guideline of your sleep quality.

In general, learning your optimal sleep schedule and getting in tune with your body's cues will help you better monitor when you get "good sleep."

Don't worry, we'll show you how!

Not you though. 

**Failure is an option:** Sometimes this stage can feel like you're going backwards because you'll be trying new things and failing. Failure is one of the most important parts of learning. 

**Fail hard and fail often!**

recrFvBtAkVLCI4xD.Name: action 1.2
recrFvBtAkVLCI4xD.Bottom Body:
**WAKE UP AT THE SAME TIME EVERY MORNING!**

This is one of those "easier said than done" solutions. However, if you incorporate this into your life, it will help you begin building an optimal sleep schedule. 

**What about weekends?**
Sleeping in on the weekend is a popular hobby. However, did you know that disrupting your sleep schedule significantly on the weekend gives you symptoms equivalent to jet lag? It's called social jet lag. 

Social jet lag leads to brain fog, daytime sleepiness, moodiness, and irritability. It can lower your immune system and make it hard to control your cravings for unhealthy snacks. 

**But, I wanna sleep in!**
We get it, sleeping in can be nice. However, if you want to optimize your sleep system, you'll want to try your best to keep things consistent.

recrXXBP28zNOpvQ9.Name: alcoholsleep1.6
recrXXBP28zNOpvQ9.Bottom Body:
**5. Other Issues**

Alcohol can also disrupt your sleep due to its diuretic effects. In other words, it makes you pee more. It also exacerbates (or even causes) snoring and sleep apnea. 

Our ability to metabolize alcohol decreases with age due to changing enzyme levels. That means that the older you are, the more sleep-disrupting effects you'll endure from alcohol.

**How does alcohol tolerance affect sleep?**
Even though regular drinkers tend to build up a tolerance to the sedative effects of booze, sleep disturbances caused by alcohol do not decrease. Its an unfortunate reality, but long-term alcohol use is associated with chronic sleep problems. In fact, studies examining people who drink heavily have found that up to 72% have insomnia.

It can also boost how efficiently you breathe! It's super effective for people with asthma or lung disorders to help improve their lung elasticity. Cool, right?

**What is diaphragmatic breathing?**
Diaphragmatic breathing, or belly breathing, means you fully engage your stomach muscles while taking deep breaths.

This style of breathing activates your parasympathetic nervous system which sends signals to your body to calm down!

You can do it any time and anywhere!

recseE10ArESm994E.Name: relearn 1.3
recseE10ArESm994E.Bottom Body:
**1**. **Only use your bed for sleeping (and sex)**

Youll see us mention this one again and again.This is one of the keys to rebooting your relationship with sleep and strengthening the association between bed + sleep. 

We'll also repeat it frequently because it can be difficult to stick with!

**Make things easier for your own brain**
By limiting the activities you do in bed, your brain is able to clarify what your bed is for! If you're wondering if you should do an activity in bed, always ask yourself  "Is this sleep or sex?" If the answer is "no", then don't do it in bed!

We know this one is easier said than done, so we'll be here to give you some tips on how to conquer it and provide soothing habits and tricks to bring you comfort along the way.

**Let's look at the next key to rebooting your relationship with sleep...**

recsqCHI9irT0Umu4.Name: week4summary 4.2
recsqCHI9irT0Umu4.Bottom Body:
**1. Find your (circadian) rhythm**
- **Disruptions: **Factors such as jet lag, shift work, stress, blue light, and activity can all lead to disruptions and shifts in your circadian rhythm. When our rhythm is off you may experience fatigue, sleep disruptions, stomach issues, and impaired judgment. 
- **Call of the wild:** A great deal of our wiring reflects the needs we had from our days as hunters and gatherers. Your circadian rhythm makes predictions and provides energy at certain times of the day due to these adaptations. 
- **Finding your rhythm:** You can optimize your circadian rhythm by using key environmental cues such as light, temperature, eating, and activity. It works best when you keep a consistent schedule and limit your exposure to late evening forms of artificial light such as digital devices.

recsrt35Jfx1rQjiq.Name: Noise 1.5
recsrt35Jfx1rQjiq.Bottom Body:
**Purchase a sound machine!**

White noise, pink noise, or environmental sounds (such as wind chimes or ocean waves) are also great for blocking a great deal of noise pollution!

They also create a calming environment that helps you relax before falling asleep!

Not only that, but pink noise has been shown to improve sleep stability by optimizing brain wave activity! Bonus!!

We promise youll be impressed by how helpful a sound machine can be for your sleep. They are also great for people who need to be able to hear important sounds at night (like a baby crying or a dog asking for treats at 3am for some reason).

recssfiNZ55LnS58b.Name: Substances 1.6
recssfiNZ55LnS58b.Bottom Body:
**Alcohol and sleep**
You may or may not be aware that alcohol is commonly used as a sleep aid, commonly referred to as a nightcap".

This is because it causes a sedative effect by mimicking an important chemical messenger in your brain, called GABA.

So, a little booze in the evening may feel like its helping you fall asleep, but in actuality, it is secretly wreaking havoc on your peaceful slumber.

Want to find out how?

recswCjQrjTSEj9CW.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.6

**3. Move it** 
Exercise has a lot of health benefits. It also happens to be one of the best ways to optimize your sleep!

Exercise has been shown to increase the amount of time you spend in restorative slow-wave sleep. Physical activity has also been shown to reduce stress by 40%, which also helps get them high quality Zzzzs. 

**How much do I need?** Ideally, aim for at least 150 minutes a week with at least 90 minutes at moderate intensity (80% of your maximum heart rate). Strength training and aerobic exercise are both helpful to sleep!

If you're having trouble getting started, just remember - something is better than nothing! So, even 2 minutes of movement is headed in the right direction.
